PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: States Grants Schools Assistance Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament:
The petition of the undersigned shows:

That the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act, 1988 includes legislation, Part III-Changes to Non-Government Schools and New Non-Government Schools, designed to inhibit the establishment, growth and development of these schools in Australia by the imposition of restrictive provisions in the areas of funding, enrolments and approval criteria.

Your petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should: reconsider the application and implications of this legislation in the light of justice, equity and freedom of choice for parents and have the unfair sections (Section 8 (2), 8 (15) and (11)) repealed.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray

PETITION.TITLE: Animal Patents
PETITION.PARA: To the President and members of the Australian Senate.

The undersigned citizens of Australia, and custodians of the Earth, oppose the patenting of animals and the processes for altering them. Animal patents would reduce biodiversity, compromise animal welfare, concentrate ownership of breeding stock, and allow companies to appropriate the fruit of centuries of selective breeding. We note with concern that many applications for animal patents have been lodged with the Australian Patents Office and without your intervention they may soon be approved.
Please take all possible steps immediately to ensure that:
1. The Patents Office rejects all existing applications for animal patents and declines to accept any more;
2. The Senate amends the Patents Bill 1989 to prohibit the patenting of animals.
We pray that all members of the Australian Senate will act on this petition.

—There are a number of unanswered questions and I know that we will come to these later. I will then ask whether there are any further answers to the questions that have been put.

—The next matter for consideration relates to the circulation of a document entitled A Fair Chance For All. If there is no discussion on that, I turn to the matter of the publication of Streetwize comic, issue No. 18. There being no discussion on that matter, I turn to the matter regarding visits by schoolchildren to Parliament House under the citizens visit program. There being no discussion, I turn to the management of the English language intensive course for overseas students program. —The question with regard to the three-year evaluation plan has not been answered. An undertaking was given six months ago that it would be answered. I think the Department understands that and I do not want to wait six months until the Estimates hearings in October to get an answer. I will be happy to receive a copy of that comprehensive five-year evaluation program as soon as it may be available.

—Senator Teague's request for a copy of the evaluation plan of the Department is being progressed, with necessary clearances, at departmental and ministerial levels and that has to be gone through before the plan can be released. I do not think that will take six months.

—The next matter I want to raise is in regard to the discussion document concerning funding differentials between former universities and former colleges of advanced education (CAEs). —If there is no further discussion on questions, there is one general reservation by the Committee, about performance indicators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like, with leave of the Committee, to go back to point 7, the subject matter of questions taken on notice, if I may.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some of the supplementary answers that were provided to the Committee-in fact, one in particular-related to various Audit reports to do with the Department of Employment, Education and Training and the operation of the office of DEET in Darwin. The question that I put on notice at page D51 asked:

SPEECH.PARA: What reports on the investigations into the alleged misuse of public money (through DEET Darwin) have been conducted? Can details be made available to the committee?
The actual answer that was tendered I can describe only as something out of Yes, Minister. I will read the answer that was given:

Following receipt of allegations some of which were anonymous and therefore difficult to pursue, the Department's Central Office recently conducted an initial investigation into the possible misuse of running cost funds some 1-2 years ago in the Darwin Office.

The resulting report recommended certain changes in the approach to financial administration in the Darwin Office and that the actions of a few individuals be the subject of further investigation. In accordance with standard Service-wide procedures a senior officer has been ordered under the Public Service Act to formally conduct that further investigation.

Since the initial report contains unconfirmed allegations, and personal details of individuals-some of whom are no longer public servants-and formal action is proceeding, it would be inappropriate to release details to the Committee.

That answer only heightens my desire to go further in asking questions. Initially it said, `Following receipt of allegations'. When were those allegations tendered? It then says, `The Department's Central Office recently conducted'. I ask when that happened in a date form. It says that the resulting report made recommendations. When was that report tabled-in more specific detail? Then it refers to `further investigation'. When did that further investigation start? When will it report? Has it already reported? What were the results? The point is made that it would be `inappropriate' to give further information to the Committee. When would it be appropriate? What formal action is now taking place? It is certainly just a Yes, Minister answer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the last part of Senator Tambling's question, I think it is best to say that investigations are continuing and, as we have had in one or two other areas in this particular Committee-and Senator Tambling has been quite cooperative in those areas-one could prejudice the sorts of investigations that are continuing. Having said that in respect of the last part of Senator Tambling's questions, I am advised that in respect of the earlier questions there are a couple of answers.

SPEECH.PARA: What I would prefer to do is defer answering those questions fully until later on this morning when we can check the details. I could, for instance, give him an answer to the question about when the investigations were conducted. The answer is late April or early May. With respect to when the allegations were first made, at this stage I could not give him a precise answer. If we can just defer those questions, I will take on board the point Senator Tambling makes that the answers have not been as precise as he would have liked.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I will take that pointer, given the assurance from the Minister that the information will be provided. I would also ask him to clarify his point that some of this detail may prejudice other actions. I would like to know what actions it could prejudice and what specific charges are being laid against individuals that could, therefore, be prejudiced by releasing some of this information. Are court cases proceeding, or are disciplinary actions taking place against departmental officers?

—It is at a difficult stage. It is described to me as the boundary stage where the report has been received and action is being considered. I think it is fair to say, without saying too much, that one course of action that would be available and is being contemplated is referring the matter to the Australian Federal Police for investigation and their further action. That is the sort of bind that we find ourselves in.

—There is one further matter, the reservation by Senator Michael Baume concerning the Auditor-General's report. Does anyone wish to raise anything on the Auditor-General's report? If not, that completes the full consideration--
—I want to raise the unanswered question relating to Streetwize comics, which is No. 13 on the list.
—It was also a matter that was listed for consideration by the Committee. I did call it out.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Teague

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to speak on that matter.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have received answers with regard to the questions that were put. I have in my hand Streetwize comic No. 18. We have now received copies of some dozen earlier editions of this publication. The answer that is given is that the Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET) has spent $146,000 on Streetwize comic No. 18, of which $125,000 was paid in this financial year. The total moneys provided from DEET to the Streetwize comic series in the 1989-90 year was $209,756. But it is not clear what has been spent over recent years on Streetwize comics. What has been DEET's contribution for the whole series?
—The reason we have not provided that answer is that I do not think Senator Teague asked for it. But we will get the answer for him. Unfortunately, it may not be this morning, but we will try.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would surmise that if one of the issues, No. 18, cost $146,000, then the whole series would cost over $1m. Maybe the contribution of the Department of Employment, Education and Training is as substantial as that. Whatever the amount of public money that has been given to this publication, it is not at all clear to me who the members of Streetwize are.

SPEECH.PARA: I have an answer here that a national steering committee operates which comprises members of Streetwize and officers from the departments of Employment, Education and Training, Community Services and Health, Attorney-General's, Primary Industries and Energy, and Justice and Community Affairs, and from the Electoral Commission and the National Campaign Against Drug Abuse, and others on an ad hoc basis.

It would appear that there was a pre-existing publication that was produced by a group called Streetwize and that they have gained the endorsement and very substantial resources of the Department of Employment, Education and Training and some cooperation from representatives of many departments of this Government.

I do not know what the nature of Streetwize was before it gained this very substantial support from the Commonwealth. Could I have an answer as to how Streetwize originated? Is it an incorporated body? Is it a private body? Is it a cooperative? Is it a publisher? What is the nature of Streetwize?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Teague's question demands a lot of detail. At the outset I must say that in my previous portfolio, consumer affairs, I had the opportunity to use Streetwize as a mechanism to get information to young people. I found it extremely useful and important. I do not purport that this answer will be comprehensive because, as Senator Teague knows, we received no notice of the question. Any part that I have not answered this morning I will provide at a later time.

SPEECH.PARA: Streetwize comics began in mid-1984 as an initiative of Sydney legal education workers. I am told that the Redfern Legal Centre was vitally involved. A production team of two artists and two writer-researchers was employed and five years later 16 comics have been produced with more in production. Streetwize has also produced a number of special comics targeted at adults: Jailwise-AIDS education for prisoners; Top-up Money for Kids-Family Allowance Supplement for remote Aboriginal communities; and A Place for Us-the promotion of community health centres.

Initially the comics were distributed free to young people in youth refuges, youth centres and institutions throughout New South Wales. Distribution throughout government agencies and schools followed. Specially adapted State editions were then distributed through separate Streetwize projects set up in each State. Linking up the State projects has provided a national network for the comics. The first comic to be simultaneously distributed in all States was Social Security Rights and Benefits, No. 9 of the series. From comic No. 12 onwards all have been produced for national distribution.

The Streetwize concept has been successful. It has also taken root in England where health authorities are currently distributing 45,000 copies of a United Kingdom edition of the Streetwize AIDS comic in the Midlands. Canada and New Zealand have also adopted our ideas and now have their own Streetwize style youth information projects. Streetwize has also conducted a number of comic skills workshops in Sydney and Alice Springs working with young Aboriginal artists to develop and produce Centre comics and Shelter Me, a housing comic for the Tangentyere Council.

The list of funders and supporters is massive. Nationally it includes: the Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET); the Department of Social Security; the Department of Primary Industries and Energy; the National Campaign Against Drug Abuse; community employment program; the Commonwealth Department of Community Services and Health; Office of Youth Affairs; Bureau of Consumer Affairs; Office of the Status of Women; and the Commonwealth Attorney-General's Department. In New South Wales it includes: The Law Foundation of New South Wales; the New South Wales Department of Health; the New South Wales International Youth Year; the Drug and Alcohol Authority of New South Wales; and the Anti-Discrimination Board. In Victoria it includes: the Youth Affairs Division; the Department of Labour; the Health Department; the Law Foundation of Victoria; and the Victorian Commission for Equal Opportunity.

In South Australia it includes: the Legal Services Commission; South Australian Health Commission; Law Foundation of South Australia; South Australian Commission for Equal Opportunities; and the South Australian Electoral Department. In Western Australia it includes the Health Department of Western Australia and the Law Society of Western Australia Public Purposes Trust Fund. In Tasmania it includes the Law Foundation of Tasmania and the Tasmanian Department for Community Welfare. In the Australian Capital Territory it includes the ACT Health Authority and the AIDS Action Council of the ACT Inc., and in the Northern Territory it involves the Northern Territory Department of Health and Community Services.

It is a very successful concept and one, which I did no know until this morning, has taken off internationally. It is a successful mechanism for conveying information to target groups and has been seen by the legal profession as being a useful mechanism for providing information for those groups. DEET rarely pays for the total amount of a production. That is obvious from the Streetwize funders and supporters which I have just referred to. Per edition comic prices range from $100,000 to $160,000. I cannot give a total all-up figure. That would not be within DEET's capacity. I will take on notice the question of whether a company runs Streetwize, whether it is incorporated or whether it is a collective.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be interested in the answers to those questions that have not been answered so far. In a paper that was given to me at 10 o'clock this morning-about 20 minutes ago-there is a statement that the committee of officers of various departments both agree on the scheduling of the topics to be covered and reviews the broad content. Streetwize authors develop the detail and style of the text to best communicate the message to the target audience.

SPEECH.PARA: For a few minutes I will look at the question of broad content on the one hand that is seen to be the responsibility of officers of the departments, and on the other hand to look at detail and style which is seen to be the responsibility of the Streetwize authors. In differentiating these two parts, I note that the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) and the Government entirely endorse the 18 comics that have been produced, endorse the mechanism that has been put in place and endorse the spending of this amount of taxpayers' money. I can assume from the Minister's statements that he not only endorses the broad content but also is entirely happy with the detail, style and message.

I outline briefly to the Committee one article that caught my attention in comic No. 18. It is all about the last Federal election and the encouragement for young people to enrol if they are older than age 17 and then to vote. I have no difficulty with encouraging all Australians to gain their rights by enrolling, by voting and by being as informed as possible in order to exercise their vote in their own best interests and in the best interests of the whole country. Those principles are unexceptionable. In this exercise I am sure there have been such good intentions by the Government and by the Australian Electoral Commission. In answer to a question asked about the Department of Administrative Services estimates yesterday I learned that $20,000 of the Electoral Commission's money went into comic No. 18 for an article which I will outline.

My difficulty is not with the concept of speaking in the vocabulary of a particular minority group of young Australians. In this Parliament I was once responsible, with other honourable senators, for a national language policy. I acknowledge the importance of recognising the language that all of us have, whether it is a language other that English or whether it is a subset of English. I also acknowledge that other countries have had degrees of success with this style of presentation to a particular vocabulary group.

Let me go to what disturbs me about this particular article. In the first picture in the comic we have a young Australian male pushing his way disrespectfully into, what I presume to be, a post office to get his enrolment form. Then there is a diagram where Tarzan-like he goes with his enrolment form back to his home. The caption says, `Where your family lives' and it depicts a couple of gorillas, one of whom is smoking a pipe. Then underneath it shows a great big black hole with a caption, `Where you were born'. It also shows a series of snow-capped mountain peaks with the caption, `Where you enrolled before'. Maybe, all of this--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. I ask Senator Teague to incorporate the two pages and that way shorten his contribution.
—I think there might be a problem in incorporating a comic strip. In fact, it cannot possibly be done.

—I thank the Minister for his attempt to be helpful, but I will be describing the comic as I see it. In the first two frames is an impression of disrespect for the notion of where people once lived, whether it matters, where their family lives, where they were born-all of this parodied. Even a person coming to get the form is parodied as going in to the post office with something less than courtesy to get an enrolment form. It then goes on to show a television with a gaping, teeth-like screen, with a hand reaching out of the television set to a young Australian and the caption:

SPEECH.PARA: Hello fellow Australians . . .Let's be friends! Shake your hand! Kiss your baby?
In other words, it is saying not to trust the political process, the department or anybody-that they are all going to set the voters up and take them down. In the fourth frame it states:
When an election is called you have 7 days to enrol before the list of names (rolls) are closed!
The television set is going wild with excitement about enrolling.
The next frame is a parody of a politician standing up over a poster which says to `vote 1' for him. He is saying:
Free pizza for the long term unemployed! All yuppies have to go to the toilet upside down.
Underneath it states:
It's up to you to decide who to vote for-your vote is secret.
Above that caption it states:
During the election campaign all the people and parties say what they have done and what they will do to get your vote!

The next drawing is of all sorts of grinning politicians or political party advocates and one has an elbow in another one's face. All of them are thrusting forward pieces of paper telling people how they should vote. The young Australian goes through them all and says:
. . . No thanks! And believe me, the parties will hand out cards that tell you how to vote for them!
Above the next caption it states:
If you get your ballot paper in a mess-ask for another one!
The young Australian is asking:
Can I have another one please?
It is a clear statement which is actually true. It then states:
If your vote is not clear or you don't have a number in every square, they won't count it!
The next square in the comic has the young Australian going into a polling booth, saying:

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Although that is certainly in the comic, I do not think it should not go into Hansard in that form. It is an improper word. It is certainly not improper for Senator Teague to have quoted it, as it is in the comic, but it is the sort of remark that would not be pleasant in Hansard.
—Mr Chairman, I ask a question regarding your ruling. How on earth can we get across our concern if Hansard is not permitted to print what the Department of education is sending around to schools?

—My ruling that it would not be proper to put those words in Hansard would dramatise the point even more clearly than having the actual words in. People could imagine much worse words than the actual words in it. It is not a proper expression to appear in Hansard and that is why I am ruling this way. The fact that it will appear in Hansard that I ruled that the words should not be there will dramatise very effectively the fact that they were improper words.

—Mr Chairman, I do not often find myself agreeing with Senator Walters, but I think that in this particular case, given that Hansard is the record of events, it will be very hard for people in the future, if they are browsing through the Hansard of this particular day, to get the real intent and concern that Senator Teague and Senator Walters have with this comic unless they know what the honourable senators are concerned about. Even though the language may be more appropriate for Streetwize than Hansard, it may, for the fullness of the record, be appropriate to have the expression appear in Hansard.

—I understand the problems of honourable senators, and I share them to some extent. The point of the Chair is that those are words which have not previously been allowed to appear in Hansard. Once they are allowed to appear, that sets a precedent for them to appear in the future. In the past, words of this nature have always been ruled out as not being proper words to be included in the record of the proceedings of the Senate. If the opinion of the Committee of the Whole is that it would like such words to appear in Hansard and have the precedent set, that is a different issue. But I am not prepared to set that precedent; it is up to the President to do that.
—Mr Chairman, I abide by your ruling and ask that Hansard have dots where there is an objectionable word.
—The discussion that took place here will be in Hansard. It will dramatise the fact that the words were considered by me to be improper and were ruled out for that reason.

—I want to give the full context of that drawing which is the punch line of the two-page comic. It also shows a horse voting in the polling booth, as though to show that not only people, but all sorts of oddball persons, go to polling booths to vote. There is actually a horse in that drawing with a question mark. Presumably, the horse is working out whether he is going to vote Liberal or Labor.
—It is a donkey-it is the donkey vote.

—Maybe it is a donkey. So the cartoon goes on. Along the top of the polling booths are written the words `scratch', `scrawl', `scratch', `scritch', `scratch'. This gives the impression that it does not matter too much what one writes on the ballot paper. It is a derogatory description. It is a parody of what people are doing in exercising their vote in polling booths. Underneath the drawing, it states:

SPEECH.PARA: Sometimes people organise protest votes and put a sticker or something on the ballot paper-
And in great, bold letters-
That's OK!

It is as though it is saying that it is all right if, as a result of reading this article, people go into a post office; slam open the door; demand an enrolment form; make some rude remark to their family on returning home; show a direct distancing from responsible television announcements from the Australian Electoral Commission; hear various political spokesmen but send them up and regard them all as dishonest because of all the ironies of this comic; see a competition in how-to-vote cards and believe that politicians are not interested in the voter but only in their own smile or good fortune; then, on coming into the polling booth, regard not only themselves but others as just scritching and scrawling rather than exercising their responsible vote on election day; and then put across their ballot form a protest such as, `Go .... . .... It is as though the comic is saying that that degree of participation in the polling booth at a general election is okay. This comic can come out a matter of weeks before an election and be distributed much more than usual, with more taxpayers' money spent on that process than usual.
At the end of the last caption it states:
Goodnight and good luck voters!

It is as though it is saying that young Australians will not achieve very much by putting this little protest on a ballot form; that it will not be taken very seriously by anybody, and it wishes good luck to them. Frankly, this is not a set of attitudes that I and colleagues who have spoken to me wish to reinforce amongst young Australians.

If the themes of this story, circulated to thousands of young Australians, had been carefully examined and considered by the Electoral Commission and the Department of Employment, Education and Training, I would be surprised if they would have endorsed this kind of parody of what it means for young Australians to exercise their votes as citizens of this country. I know it is a matter of editorial judgment to use the vocabulary of a minority group of Australians in order to communicate to them in an effective way--

TALK.START.PARA: —You need a sense of humour.

—Senator Zakharov is quietly interjecting. I cannot hear her words but I understand that she endorses what the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) has said, and that this Labor Government endorses this style of approach.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not bore the Committee by going over the 17 or 18 other comics which are about sex, drugs, pollution of Sydney's beaches, sex discrimination, homosexuality, mistreatment in a place of employment and so on. I do not doubt that all of these subjects are important in terms of information going to all Australians so that they are aware of what is truthful and what it is in their interests to know in order to avoid the trampling of their rights or the endangering of their lives as far as some of the health issues are concerned.

I am two-thirds in agreement with the principle of this communication. I agree that it is essential to understand the vocabulary of a minority group of Australians, and I agree that it is important to raise a certain range of topics-such as those I have seen. But the vital area which I am not convinced about, which my colleagues who have spoken to me are not convinced about-and I put it to the Minister and to this Committee that the majority of Australians would not be convinced about it-is the style of presenting a caricature that reinforces antisocial and other negative attitudes among the young Australians to whom these publications are directed.

I therefore again bring this to the attention of the Government, the departments I have named, the Electoral Commission and, indeed, the State bodies that have been mentioned, and ask that they re-examine this third part of the overall basis of this publication and satisfy themselves that this is not having a counterproductive effect. Yes, certainly, it is in a language style that is received by the group; yes, certainly, it raises some important topics; but it fails actually to communicate the messages that, presumably, are intended because of the overemphasis on reinforcing negative attitudes. These negative attitudes are not going to serve Australians well and are not going to serve individuals well in the way in which they exercise their right to vote and their right to make decisions in their personal lives in the areas that have been addressed by these comics.
I make that protest and I ask the Minister to bring these comments to the attention of the various departments I have mentioned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak very briefly on the dilemma which the Committee currently finds itself in as to whether the words directly quoted by Senator Teague from the comic Streetwize--

—Order! Senator Jenkins, you may not dispute a ruling I have made except to dissent from it. You cannot discuss a ruling I have made. I have ruled that those words should not appear in Hansard, and that is not a subject for discussion. If you disagree with my ruling you are entitled to dissent from it.
—I was under the impression that a final ruling had not been made.
—I ruled that those words will not appear in Hansard.
—In that case I would simply like to make a comment, if I may.
—No, you may not.
—Is no comment permitted at all?
—No.
—I would like to make a comment on language in general, in that case.
—That is perfectly in order, as long as it is relevant to the matter we are discussing, which is Streetwize comics, issue No. 18.

—I have often been appalled by the crudity of expressions and sentiments expressed in this place by honourable senators one to the other. Expressions which have been allowed in Hansard, such as `putting the snout in the trough', are unnecessarily crude. The use of words such as those is allowed in Hansard.

—Order! Senator Jenkins, you seem to be defying my ruling. I said you will not discuss that ruling I made. This seems to be a very direct discussion of it. The matter before the Chair is Streetwize comics, issue No. 18. You may discuss that.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. Streetwize comics obviously use language which is particularly direct, and it is used because it is language which is easily understood by the teenagers who read Streetwize comics. SPEECH.PARA: I received a submission from the Parliamentary Education Office that it was the obvious office to pay the subsidy and administer the scheme with a view to offering these students the opportunity to take part in a parliamentary education program. The Speaker and the Minister have therefore decided that initially the Sergeant-at-Arms should administer the scheme. I do not believe that the members are directly going to receive the cheque to pay the subsidy. I am still checking that fact.

The answers given in the Estimates are still inadequate and no doubt further answers will be given. It is my view-and I believe that the more this matter is discussed it will be the wider chamber view-that this scheme ought to continue in terms of meeting some of the costs of school groups, particularly those from distant States, but that there ought to be an efficient and single administration. As the President has reported to this chamber, that ought to be the Education Office of this Parliament-not the Department of Employment, Education and Training, the Sergeant-at-Arms or the Usher of the Black Rod. There needs to be one reform that will consolidate the standing of the Education Office in this Parliament for this to proceed.

With Senator Patterson, Senator McLean and some others I took part in a Senate inquiry which looked at the rights of citizenship. We considered the encouragement that ought to be given to Australians, including young Australians, so they know that they have access to decision makers at the local government, State government and Federal government levels. As a result of our report stressing the importance of enhancing the information about citizenship that is provided to Australians, the Education Office of this Parliament was established, but as yet the office has been unable to find a secure place within the structure of this Parliament.

I believe that the Education Office could well be placed as a discrete unit associated with the Parliamentary Library and therefore under the general supervision of the elected members of the Library Committee. At the moment the Education Office does not come under any scrutiny by elected members of the Senate or the House of Representatives, other than the Presiding Officers. I see this as a temporary position. I believe that the Education Office, like all the other departments and activities in this building, should find a place such as the Library where there is a Library Committee of elected members which is chaired by a Presiding Officer.

If the Education Office is given that kind of stability and scrutiny, I believe that it ought to administer the parliamentary education scheme. Whilst administering the subsidies that are provided by the Department of Employment, Education and Training, it should also supervise the education information that is given in this building-involving, wherever possible, the relevant members and senators associated with any school group that visits the building-and at the same time make arrangements for seating in the galleries and the morning or afternoon tea that is provided in discussion in the usual way. I put that proposition forward for further discussion over the coming months. I do so in response to the questions that have been only partly answered in the Estimates Committee.

There was a general answer made available yesterday as to the means that we all have to evaluate reform by the Labor Government in higher education over the last few years. One of those reforms was the establishment of the higher education contribution scheme (HECS)-colloquially known as the graduate tax.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that included in the papers which I have received, since the Estimates Committee is the report entitled The Impact of the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS) Evaluations and Investigations Program. The authors are Frances Robertson, Judith Sloan, and Neil Bardsley. It is a publication of the Department of Employment, Education and Training. Included with this summary document were two more empirical publications-one a study in Victoria by the same authors, and another in Western Australia.

I briefly wish to note that the findings of this two-part inquiry, based upon samples in Victoria and Western Australia, are of very considerable importance. I note that in a survey, those who did not enrol were asked what factors had led them not to be enrolled in higher education, and only a quite small minority regarded the HEC scheme as being very important in determining their non-enrolment, not proceeding with their undergraduate degree, or not enrolling in post-graduate studies. The figures that are given here are 2 per cent, 5 per cent and 10 per cent respectively. Page 23 of the report concludes that there is a greater deterrent from the introduction of HECS amongst post-graduate students.

The conclusion I want to explore, only briefly now but at various points in the months ahead, is that the present number of students exempt from HECS, which this Government has established at only 18,000, ought to be expanded, particularly with regard to post-graduate students. Before the last election the Opposition put forward the view that 85,000 students should be exempt from the user-pay element-whether HECS or an up-front fee. I believe that the document before us demonstrates that we are losing the potential of many bright graduating students from contributing more to this country through gaining experience in post-graduate study. Indeed, in some particular areas of post-graduate specialisation there is a serious shortfall in the numbers of students who are enrolling.

One way to address indeed, give encouragement to, enrolment in critical areas such as post-graduate work in engineering, in mathematics, in some areas of science, and even in some applied areas such as languages, is to extend exemption from HECS to a group of students. One way of responding to this evaluation of HECS would be to extend the number of students exempt, particularly at the post-graduate level. There is reference to external students. There is also a recognition that a knee-jerk reaction from some students would be to find in a new government program a scapegoat as the reason they did not continue with their studies.

Taking all that into account, it is actually heartening, I believe, to see that a majority of students do not dissent from a student contribution to the cost of their education. At the moment, HECS is levied at about 20 per cent of the cost of undertaking a higher education course-that is, the taxpayer provides 80 per cent of the cost and the student undertaking the course 20 per cent. The Opposition was wanting to bring in a more comprehensive user pay element but, at the same time, reduce it to 12 per cent of the overall cost. To that extent, there was a common element in Government and Opposition that there be now entrenched a user pay element in higher education.

This was disputed by some representatives of independent parties and the Democrats, who still have the view that there ought to be a zero user pay element for higher education, that students ought not to pay anything at all with regard to their studies. However, this report shows-a view that I have put forward on a number of occasions publicly in the last six months-that a majority of students accept that they ought to pay a proportion of the costs of their studies. In fact, even in this survey that had a 45 per cent return bias towards those who were more troubled by HECS, it was clear that over half of the sample agreed that students should pay something towards their higher education.

I believe that that issue is now settled in Australia, and in answer to my questions then about evaluating reforms over the last two years the forwarding of this document is significant. I believe that it is now clearly established that a large majority of students and overwhelming numbers of representatives in the Parliament recognise that about 12 to 20 per cent of the cost of higher education ought to be borne by the student through one mechanism or another. I would like to introduce a number of other ways of evaluating HECS into debates in this chamber in the coming months.

Finally, in regard to the reforms that have been outlined by this Government, colloquially called the Dawkins reforms, I note that a clear answer has not so far been given by the Government with regard to a proposition that there be a charter of academic freedoms. If the Minister has anything to add at this point, I would be grateful.

I conclude by saying that it is now my assumption, and the Opposition's assumption, that the Government will not proceed with this concept that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins, so crudely put forward without proper consultation and without any careful preparation, and which has now fallen flat on its face-and that is, the so-called charter of academic freedoms. Once one begins to enumerate the actual freedoms in our higher education institutions, one will end up by limiting those freedoms, in the same way that once there is a Bill of Rights, if ever anything was still to be debated in this Parliament, one would end up by putting in concrete and enumerating those rights in a way that detracts from the rights of Australian citizens. That is why this side of the House is opposed to a Bill of Rights and opposed to a charter of academic freedoms. We are in favour of enhancing people's rights and this profession's freedoms, and I would like to hear the assurance of the Minister, if he can give it, that this mistake of many made by the present Government in higher education will in fact now, because it has been so discredited, not be proceeded with.

In terms of the immigration selection procedures, the Opposition, along the lines of the FitzGerald inquiry, has been pressing for younger, well qualified, skilled migrants to take a larger proportion of the 140,000 places currently available under the immigration program. In part, one of the arguments for this is not only the direct economic benefit to this country through such changing of priorities, but also that the immigration to this country of persons of a younger age will help to give a more even balance to the age of the total population of Australia.

I wish to touch upon a number of the elements that ought to be referred to in the intersection of population policy and immigration policy. However, when we ask questions of this Government as to its population policy, we find it does not have one; it has nothing to say. It does not have a carefully determined approach to these matters. There are all manner of groups in the community that have views about this, yet we have not seen any statement of Government policy with regard to population.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose at the outset I should say that we on this side of the Parliament are looking forward to the forthcoming election that Senator Teague is running for. After that we might come back to some rational time constraints in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Teague made a point about optimum best population for Australia. For the sake of comprehensiveness and decency in this debate, let us acknowledge that no past government has actually put a figure on a final outcome. Unless I am totally wrong, I do not think even any political party has a particular figure that it puts forward as the optimum population for Australia.

There is extensive literature on what might be an optimum or best population for Australia; there is also literature on what may very well be a sustainable population on an indefinite basis. The key conclusion that that literature, the parties and governments have come to is, basically, that no single figure is meaningful. I would have thought that Senator Teague, with his experience in this area, probably would have understood that point.

Any estimate, of course, depends on a whole range of factors. It depends on the quality of life involving the choices that the population makes about the consumption of water and other resources; it depends on the geographic distribution of people, effort expended on environmental management and so on; it depends on future technological developments; and it depends on the future discovery of non-renewable resources and the like. To actually put a figure on the best or the optimum population for Australia is basically something that no government, past or present, no party, past or present, has done.

As I said, research is going on. It is very easy to seek the short and simple answer. A consultant's report, entitled The Physical Limitations to Population Growth in Australia, to the inquiry conducted by the Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies, known as the CAAIP inquiry, provides a very useful overview on a range of issues and the wide range of figures suggested for Australia. It also provides an overview of the literature that is available, and it might be worthwhile going into that. Of course, the Government understands generally that research can be done on many aspects which affect decisions on the appropriate rate of population levels. The Bureau of Immigration Research has identified this as one of its priority research areas leading up to the National Outlook Conference to be held late this year. As Senator Teague might know, we have also initiated discussions with the Commission for the Future on the development of a joint research program.

A whole range of interrelated issues are involved. Senator Teague raised two points which dealt basically with youth and skills in our migration program. The short answer is that at the moment we have a higher level of skills coming into this country than at any time since figures have been kept. We have a points test which provides great emphasis on youth. In fact, the highest number of points to enter Australia can be attained if one is between the ages of 18 and 24 years. The Opposition should acknowledge that Government policy in these two areas-that is, the recognition of the need for skills and the recognition of the need to emphasise youth-is geared in the direction which Opposition senators claim they want it to be geared and has been effective in achieving those objectives. I apologise for not saying earlier that I have a copy of the BIR Bulletin, issue No. 1, April 1990. For the sake of decency, I will ask someone to take it around to Senator Teague.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to raise the issue of an answer that was given to me in relation to one of the questions at the Estimates Committee hearing relating to the annual cost resources, et cetera, required to handle fishing incursions through Broome and northern Australia. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. With reference to those answers, an analysis of the figures provided in them leads one to draw a number of conclusions which I believe require urgent action by the Government in relation to the business migration program. Among the reasons stated for the Government's introduction of the accreditation system for that program was the Government's desire to increase the intake of business migrants to Australia and also to speed up the processing of business migration program applications. The Government stated that this latter goal was desirable in itself, and that it would also help to achieve the first goal concerning an increased intake.

SPEECH.PARA: If one looks at the answer provided to me to question No. 7, which shows the median finalisation processing times for the five stations about which I asked-Hong Kong, Kuala Lumpur, Singapore, Athens and Damascus-it can be seen that those finalisation times range from five months to 18 months. That clearly shows that the goal of speeding up the processing of business migration applications has not been achieved.

This impression is reinforced particularly when one looks at the figures for Hong Kong, where one can see that the outstanding number of applications is now 23 per cent greater than it was six months ago. As I understand it, when the accreditation processing system was introduced, the time taken to finalise applications was expected to be reduced to about three months. In fact, looking at these figures we see that the processing time seems to be about the same as it was under the old system.

If one looks at the figures for the Hong Kong station, the conclusion can be drawn that the clear reason for this is the Government's inadequate provision of resources to that station. The resources at the Hong Kong station are inadequate to deal, in a timely manner, with the number of applications that are being received. That is demonstrated by the fact that it takes seven months to bring business migration applications to finalisation in Hong Kong and, as I mentioned a few moments ago, the backlog of applications is increasing. The provision of resources to Hong Kong is also inadequate when one looks at the revenue generated in Hong Kong by the fees charged for business migration program applications. The introduction of an annual fee, a lodgment fee and a greatly increased application fee which accompanied the establishment of accreditation was justified on the grounds of the user pays principle. As such, I believe that the introduction of and increase in such fees is quite defensible.

However, when one looks at the situation in Hong Kong, one sees that it is clear that the user is paying through the nose in terms of the service being provided. If one looks at the rate of applications over the last six months, one can see that they are generating some $3 3/4m in revenue per annum-taking six-monthly figures and converting them to a yearly basis. But if one looks at the answer to question No. 4, one sees that it is clear that the cost of resources being provided are on a per annum basis in order to process those applications and is only $500,000. Therefore, there is a clear obligation on the Government, both morally and in order to ensure the efficient management of the programs substantially to increase the number of people and associated resources available in order to process business migration program applications in Hong Kong. If resources were matched to revenue, that station's current resources could be multiplied seven times and, indeed, on the figures provided, that station could therefore get finalisation of processing time down to one month. The original goal of three months could be met by little more than doubling the present resources and that would clearly be achievable, having regard to the massive revenue that is being derived from fees charged at that station.

A perusal of the figures shows that, in Hong Kong, for each Australian average staffing level there is a finalisation of nearly three business migration program applications per day. By comparison, in Singapore the figure is 2.3. In Kuala Lumpur, only 1.12 applications are processed per staffing level per day and in Athens and Damascus it is even worse, with 0.82 per day and 0.62 per day respectively. In other words, Hong Kong, with about 2 3/4 times the number of staff working on the business migration program as Kuala Lumpur has, is finalising nearly seven times the number of applications. That means that the officers at the Hong Kong station are working more than twice as hard as those at Kuala Lumpur or, at least, are certainly more than twice as productive. This fact further reinforces the justification for a substantial increase in the resources being applied to the business migration program in Hong Kong.

From my own experience in assisting business migrants between 1984 and 1987, combined with my consulting experience in organisational structure and work practice, I believe that about three cases being finalised by an Australian officer per day is a reasonable achievement. Certainly the Hong Kong station is achieving that but, as I said earlier, it is falling further and further behind with regard to total finalisation time because of the increasing backlog of applications. I therefore ask the Minister to state in his response why more resources are not being provided in Hong Kong, especially in view of the massive surplus of revenue being generated at that station.

If one looks at the Singapore station, one can see that it is slightly under-achieving with regard to the number of finalisations per Australian officer per day. From that, one can conclude that an improvement in productivity is required. But an increase in resources is also justified for Singapore, because applications there are currently generating about $74,000 on an annual basis, but the personnel servicing the program are costing only about $41,000. It is certainly unacceptable that finalisation of processing takes about eight months in Singapore.

Although Kuala Lumpur at five months has the shortest time for finalisation of processing of all the stations about which I sought information, a vast improvement should also occur there. I have already highlighted the poor performance of Kuala Lumpur when it is compared to Hong Kong. It is also poor when compared to Singapore. Kuala Lumpur has more than four times more staff than Singapore has in relation to the business migration program, according to the answers that have been provided to me, but the Kuala Lumpur station is finalising only twice the number of applications per week. So Australian officers there should nearly treble the number of applications that they are finalising per officer per day. That suggests that the Kuala Lumpur station is not operating in the way in which the Government intended under the accreditation system. There is also some scope for an increase in resources provided to Kuala Lumpur, with applications there generating $225,000 a year, and staffing costing only $185,000 a year.

Likewise, the performance at both the Athens and Damascus stations should improve by some three to four times with their existing resources. At Athens there is a slight shortfall as regards fee income compared with the cost of processing resources provided, while at Damascus there is a slight surplus. So, in effect, in monetary terms they balance each other out. Those resources are finalising much less than one case per Australian officer per day. That is reflected in processing finalisation times of 18 months for Athens and 14 months for Damascus.

So I again ask the Minister to ensure that adequate resources are provided where they are obviously required in stations such as Hong Kong, and where that justification is reinforced on the basis of the fees being earned at those stations. Will the Minister also ensure that productivity improves at those stations which are shown not to be performing adequately? Can we get finalisation times for business migration program applications down to no more than three months?

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the Minister responds, I will make it clear that we are dealing with questions 14 to 20 collectively and the issues arising from those.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first point to make is that Senator Chapman makes a pretty fundamental mistake in comparing apples with pears and in drawing the conclusions he then does out of that. For instance, the situation in Athens, where the median processing time is 18 months, cannot be compared to a situation anywhere else because Athens, I am informed, processes applications out of the Gulf area. Quite often, officers are waiting an extraordinary length of time before correspondence is returned, before the processes take place from the end of those who are making application. The Gulf does present all sorts of different problems and, accordingly, one will find that the median processing time in a place such as Athens is something like 18 months.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure that in respect of most of the posts, one could say that they do have regional problems; some may not. The basic point I make is that Kuala Lumpur, Singapore, Athens and any of those posts cannot be compared on a very simple formula. Making comparisons on that basis is something that should not be done because of those local circumstances.

Kong Kong was mentioned as a special case, and I go to answers to sub-part questions 8 and 9, the number of outstanding applications in each place listed six months ago and listed now. It is interesting to note that one of the problems we do have with Hong Kong is that quite often the visa is not readily taken up after approval. For instance, in respect of the applications listed now, there are 1,721 currently in the pipeline; of those, 647 are in what is called stage 3. That is something like 37 per cent. That is basically people we are waiting on to come in and pick up their visas.

I am told there are also circumstances where people are asking for extensions, and that drags out the median processing time as well. That is not to say that Hong Kong is not receiving attention from the Government. It is quite apparent that not only Australia but other countries also are getting interest from Hong Kong. The workload levels in Hong Kong across all categories, including the business migration program, and the processing times are under ongoing review. As I said, some of the figures showing an increased case load are caused by those collecting the visas dragging their feet after the processing and approval of the applications.

However, that is not a full response. The Government recognises, as part of its ongoing review, that staffing needs should be given attention. Following a visit to Hong Kong last month by a senior departmental officer, it has been decided in principle to increase the staffing levels in that particular post. The additional Australian-based staff resources should be in place by, I am told, August-September this year.

So the two points I make in response to Senator Chapman's intervention are, firstly, do not compare posts and expect a very simple formula to apply to them all; and, secondly, yes, Hong Kong is being given attention. There are particular reasons there why stage 3 is at a high level, but the Government is responding to the needs and will have mechanisms in place later this year.
Progress reported.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Under sessional order the Senate will now proceed to a discussion of matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public interest I raise today is the need for Australian Capital Territory prisoners to have their own gaol in Canberra. This issue is particularly pertinent now because on 1 July responsibility for all criminal law will be passed to the Australian Capital Territory legislature. The Australian Capital Territory does not have a prison. All sentenced Australian Capital Territory prisoners are transferred to New South Wales to serve their sentences. The number of people convicted in the ACT and serving sentences in New South Wales currently stands in the eighties.

SPEECH.PARA: What the ACT Government is going to do about its prisoners has been an ongoing source of controversy. The death of Kirran Alistair Sen in early April has reactivated this debate. Mr Sen, a mentally ill ACT man, hanged himself in his cell after being sent to Goulburn gaol. In sentencing Mr Sen, Justice John Kelly said that an ACT solution would have been best but was simply not available. I believe that wide ranging community discussion needs to occur on this issue.

The current situation is not a satisfactory one for the residents of the Australian Capital Territory. An ACT citizen sentenced to a term of imprisonment could end up in any gaol in the State of New South Wales. The debate for a prison in the ACT began in earnest in 1984 when the Deputy Chairman of the Human Rights Commission argued that the construction of a prison in the ACT was justified. In 1985 the Vinson inquiry into ACT welfare systems recommended the establishment of a medium to low security prison.

In report No. 44 on sentencing, the Law Reform Commission recommended that a prison system be established in the ACT. The Commonwealth has a responsibility to ensure that the welfare needs of ACT prisoners are adequately met. The commissioner in charge, Mr George Zdenkowski, said that the Commission's opinion that the ACT had been relying too heavily on New South Wales to care for its prisoners was shared by Canberra prisoners and their families and by almost all ACT judges, magistrates, police and welfare officials interviewed by the Commission.

My own interest in this matter arises in part from experiences of one of my constituents, Mr Ray O'Shannassy. Mr O'Shannassy, the prisoner whose transport difficulties I raised in the Senate two years ago, has not been returned to Canberra. Mr O'Shannassy was released from Goulburn gaol on 24 January 1984 and given a rail voucher by prison authorities. He exchanged this for a train and seat ticket at the Goulburn railway station. When he boarded the train he found the seat allocated to him was occupied. His attempts to have the train conductor and the station master secure him a seat were unsuccessful. Mr O'Shannassy's attempts to secure alternative transport to Canberra by sitting in the station master's office and later the Rail Superintendent's Office failed. In the course of Mr O'Shannassy's 3 3/4 year campaign to get operating a safe system to return prisoners to Canberra, he has been arrested hundreds of times at consider- able cost to the state.

Since I raised this matter in the Senate on 16 March 1988, the voucher system has been amended but it still does not ensure the safe, prompt return of Canberra prisoners. It is these problems associated with the return of prisoners to the ACT that led me to the conclusion that the Australian Capital Territory needs its own gaol.

The ACT now has a greater population than the Northern Territory and a population not significantly smaller than the whole of Tasmania. A community of this size should care for all its people including those who have been sentenced to a term of imprisonment.

The challenge for the ACT legislature is that a Territory facing up to the responsibility of looking after itself should also look after its own prisoners. Canberra has no control over the conditions of its prisoners and no influence over programs, classifications and overseeing the term of the sentences imposed by the courts. This can lead to particular hardship in retraining and employment prospects of released prisoners.

The people of Canberra must face up to the fact that they lack involvement in the life of the prisoners they will eventually have back as members of the community. This leads to severe disadvantages for both the community and the released prisoner.

Article 10 (3) of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights states that the penitentiary system shall comprise treatment of prisoners, the essential aim of which shall be their reformation and social rehabilitation. A government committed to a humanitarian approach to incarceration should have an intimate approach to a prisoner's rehabilitation and adjustment to community life on release.

Such an approach is not possible in Canberra with the current practice of sending prisoners to New South Wales. Sending Australian Capital Territory prisoners to another State to serve their sentence under the control of a regime that has no accountability to the ACT community strips the community and the prisoner of their democratic rights to a say in how that system operates. I believe that the size of Canberra, the problem associated with the return of prisoners, and the responsibility of the Canberra community to play a role in the rehabilitation of its prisoners, warrants the provision of prison facilities in the Territory. What every person in Canberra must face is that Canberra's convicted citizens have been put into the New South Wales prison system.

The crisis in the New South Wales prison system is well known and is growing worse daily. For many decades the state of prisons in New South Wales was scandalous. Efforts by concerned citizens in New South Wales in publicising the brutality of prison life led to the Nagle royal commission which reported to the Parliament in 1978. The Wran Labor Government implemented many of the recommendations of the Nagle royal commission. The establishment of a corrective services commission led to greater community involvement in prison administration. Gaols became more accessible to the public; educational programs were developed, and efforts were made to return prisoners more quickly into the community.

The climate of New South Wales prisons has deteriorated in recent years. We have seen the Greiner Government under Minister Yabsley institute a series of retrograde steps. Firstly, there has been the abolition of the Corrective Services Commission and its replacement with a single director. This has dealt a heavy blow to community involvement in prison administration. Secondly, the production of gaol magazines has ended with the stated reason being that the Minister wanted to show who was boss. Thirdly, contact visits have been greatly reduced. Fourthly, inducements encouraging prisoners to take educational courses have been withdrawn and the remission system has ended. Fifthly, the Government has signalled its intention to reopen the notorious Endeavour House at Tamworth, with the announcement that spartan conditions will apply.

Life in the New South Wales prison system has always been grim. The current changes being implemented are designed to crush all hope. We can anticipate that some prisoners will externalise their frustrations and anger in violent riots. Others will internalise their rage. According to an article in the Sydney Morning Herald last year, the suicide rate in New South Wales prisons was four to five times greater than the rate in England and Wales. With overcrowding getting worse and prison policies harsher in New South Wales, the crisis there can only result in more deaths in custody.

Those responsible for Australian Capital Territory prisoners can no longer ignore the trends that are developing in New South Wales. The present policies being practised in New South Wales fly in the face of humane strategies to rehabilitate prisoners.

At Australia's first international congress on corrective services, held in Sydney in 1989 and attended by 749 delegates from 36 nations, Ms Mary Tuck, head of the Research and Planning Unit, Home Office, London, said:
The treatment of offenders to genuinely reduce recidivism is likely to be found in ways of dealing with offenders that encourage their relationship with a living community.

How can the ACT apply such strategies when it abandons its prisoners to another State away from their own community? This is the human side to the need for the ACT to have its own gaol. Apart from inflicting prisoners on an inadequate and overcrowded gaol system in New South Wales, there is the problem of distance from home and family which makes visits difficult and expensive, remembering that these prisoners can be sent to any gaol in New South Wales. Canberra offenders are put at a greater disadvantage than prisoners of other States and Territories.

In November 1984 the Australian Institute of Criminology issued a report which found that all ACT prisoners serving sentences in New South Wales were in favour of an ACT prison. Cost has been noted as a significant aspect of this debate. I have some figures from 1987-they are not recent-which show that to house the ACT prisoners who were then being held in New South Wales prisons would cost more than $6m a year with capital costs of more than $10m. This is compared with the $2.4m in payments to New South Wales in 1986-87 for the care of ACT offenders. There is no question that this poses a difficult problem for the ACT Government.

I do not pretend to have the answers as to how the financing of a Canberra gaol should occur. However, Canberra cannot continue to rely on New South Wales to take its prisoners. To do so is to ignore the reality that the current system is completely inadequate. It is time to take the difficult decision and put in place proper planning to allow for the funding of a Territory gaol. The Law Reform Commission report on sentencing points out that the cost should not be the prime consideration. It states:

The NSW system has often been criticised for its inadequate facilities and resources. The prisons there are overcrowded and antiquated. The alternative to humane containment in the Australian Capital Territory is worth pursuing even though it is likely to involve greater Federal expenditure.

I raise these matters because, with the attainment of self-government, all Canberra people and their government can face the fact that a goal in Canberra is long overdue. To those critics who claim that a gaol will result in more offenders ending up there, I say that will surely depend on those determining the form that sentences ought to take. The alternative is to continue the present policy of banishing ACT offenders into New South Wales. Surely such archaic methods, popular in eighteenth century Britain, should now be abandoned in the Australian Capital Territory and its prisoners kept within its own community.

I received a great deal of additional material on the decline of standards and morale in New South Wales gaols. At the same time, Mrs Chadwick, the Minister, has plunged the juvenile system into chaos in New South Wales. I will detail these facts in a subsequent speech. Obviously, it is something that is of great concern and only emphasises the points that I have made.
I conclude by thanking Mr Ray O'Shannassy--

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha ha!

—I notice Senator Puplick reacting. Mr O'Shannassy has not always presented his case in a way that people would accept but, nevertheless, he has highlighted two very serious things: first of all, the unsatisfactory way prisoners are returned to Canberra, which brought me into this issue; and now the fact that in this modern day Canberra has to have its own gaol.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators are well aware that for the last 18 months I have been pursuing in this place the issue of serious allegations of bank malpractice and corrupt practices. It is my intention to return to the bank issue with a vengeance. During that period I have placed before the Senate for the consideration of honourable senators, examples of what I have no alternative but to accept as evidence of malpractice and corrupt practice in banking. I now have in the vicinity of 350 such cases and I have tabled, for honourable senators' deliberation and consideration, somewhat in excess of 80 case studies ranging across all major banks in his country, concerning millionaires to battlers and drawn from all States of the Commonwealth. It is now my intention to seek leave to table a further four case studies. I will continue to do so whilst ever I believe that it is to the advantage of both constituents and honourable senators in their deliberation of these serious allegations. I seek leave to table four affidavits and associated documents.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The documents that I have just tabled concern one Maurie Turland, who is in dispute with the Advance Bank; Jeffrey Leddin, who is in dispute with the National Australia Bank; Cecilia Joyce Milverton, who is in dispute with the Commonwealth Trading Bank; and Mr Owen Stolpe, who is in dispute with the Commonwealth Trading Bank.

SPEECH.PARA: The outcome of this process of tabling documents has been interesting. I believe that the community is now tremendously interested in the allegations contained in the documents I have tabled. Most honourable senators, I think, read the cover article in the Bulletin of May 1989 called `Why the Banks are Bastards'. It was as a result of that very potent article that I received literally hundreds-if not thousands-of phone calls. My staff and I have literally spent thousands of hours considering and deliberating over these cases.

Honourable senators are aware of the fact that twice I have called for a Senate inquiry into banking practice in this country. My proposal was debated in this chamber and was defeated on both occasions by the combined vote of Government and Opposition.

I think that even the affairs of the last two or three days have drawn attention to the fact that banking, as a phenomenon process in this community, is a matter to which Australians must direct a maximum of attention, not only for economic reasons but also for social reasons-specifically of justice and injustice. There are record levels of indebtedness; record levels of bankruptcy. I have been arguing in this place for 18 months that some of these cases are the result of bank malpractice and indeed bank corrupt practice.

Eighteen months ago when I tabled the first three case studies it was suggested in the debate that these matters would be best resolved in the courts. After approximately 15 months I would like now to return to those three cases and to see what those constituents have experienced at the hands of the courts and the banks in that time. I particularly draw the attention of the media to what I am offering in this place today because I believe it will be a very potent statement.

In April 1988 an article titled `Fraud Investigation in Nowra' appeared in the Coastal Life magazine which is published in Nowra. As a result of that article customers of the Commonwealth Bank made complaints to me about the conduct of the bank. At that time I tabled affidavits and other material in this place relating to those complaints. Those were the first three cases which I cited and for which I tabled evidence and other associated documents.

In a prepared statement the Managing Director of the Commonwealth Bank, Mr Don Sanders, said that the affidavits tabled by me, `do not justify allegations of corruption against the Commonwealth Bank'. Mr Sanders went on to say that action had been taken by the bank `to protect its position in circumstances where the borrowers had not met payment commitments'.

In the light of subsequent events I now propose to revisit those cases believing that they show that the bank was corrupt in the action taken against its customers. In one case, that of Mighty Chef Products, the bank purported to appoint receivers to the assets and undertakings of the company. I now seek leave to table a case history and a statutory declaration of Mr Wilfred Taylor made on 5 May 1990, and exhibits thereto.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The fact is that the receivers committed blatant fraud. I call for urgent legislative reform to make receivers answerable for their conduct. I call upon the Commissioner for Corporate Affairs for New South Wales to initiate an investigation with a view to laying criminal charges in relation to this case.

SPEECH.PARA: In another case, and a very important one in my view-that of Tony Rigg-the bank obtained a summary judgment against Mr Rigg. I seek leave to table a case history and copies of the supporting documentary evidence.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again I thank the Senate. The fact is that a bank officer manipulated an account and another officer committed perjury. What that means is that these bank officers have indeed perverted the course of justice. In addition, Mr Don Sanders, the Managing Director of the Commonwealth Bank, wrote a letter incorporating palpable falsehoods. The letter was sent to me. It was incorporated in Hansard and quoted and relied upon by the Chief Justice of New South Wales when dismissing Mr Rigg's appeal. I call upon the Attorney-General for New South Wales to initiate investigations with a view to laying criminal charges.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators will recall that on the first occasion I raised the matter of a possible Senate bank inquiry that letter was not tabled or incorporated by me in this place but was incorporated by then Senator John Stone, I believe, at the request of Mr Don Sanders. I am convinced that that letter contained palpable falsehoods. By its being so tabled and incorporated in Hansard the Senate was misled, as was the Australian public because, by virtue of its being incorporated and tabled, it was made public property.

In the third case-that of Huon Valley Springs-the bank attempted to bankrupt the proprietress of the company. I seek leave once again to table a case history-affidavits of Miss Donna Batiste, sworn on 22 July 1988 and 15 September 1988, and exhibits thereto, and the judgment of Mr Justice Burchett handed down in the Federal Court on 27 April 1989.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The fact is that the bank breached a written undertaking not to proceed to bankrupt Miss Batiste. In his judgment dismissing the petition for bankruptcy, His Honour made a scathing attack on the officers of the bank. I call upon the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, Senator Tate, who is present in the chamber, to initiate an investigation with a view to laying criminal charges.

SPEECH.PARA: By tabling these case histories, which have been prepared for me by legal advisers, I am attempting to place before the Senate for its serious consideration-and indeed that of Senator Tate as the Minister for Justice, the media and the people of Australia-what I am convinced are provable cases of fraud, corruption and perjury in relation to three of the 80-odd case studies I have tabled in this place and only three of more than 300 cases that I now have before me.

The fact is that in each of these cases there was blatant corruption by bank officers. That corruption related to action taken by the bank. It is now open to Mr Don Sanders, the Managing Director of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, to make further denial of corruption. In the coming session of Parliament I will once again call for a Senate inquiry into banking.

For the last 18 months I have been deliberately pursuing a strategy by which I have been appealing to honourable senators to examine the circumstances of individuals. On the two occasions that I have appealed to the Senate to place these circumstances before a special Senate inquiry that request has been denied, which is obviously the privilege of the majority of the Senate.

I will be shifting strategies in the next few months and when we return to this place in the next session. I will, by and large, shift my focus away from case studies to what I believe are actions provable within boardrooms of banks. I will be tabling documents which emanate from the boardrooms of banks which I believe will reveal that in the context of deregulated banking there has been a significant and real shift away from the fundamental fiduciary relationship by which the interests of clients should be considered equal to the interests of the banker.

I believe that inherent in the current wave of foreclosures and record bankruptcies-that is all over the front pages of newspapers of this country today-one ingredient is malpractice and corrupt practice. From the first occasion on which I addressed the question in this place I have outlined variations on themes by which banks are able to deliberately manipulate-I believe I have tabled evidence here today that they have-strong, healthy, viable businesses to bankruptcy, for reasons which are not yet known to us or to the clients.

The three cases that I have cited today are all of businesses which at the time of these difficulties beginning were very healthy and viable and it was for those reasons that the banks advanced large sums of money to them. If banks do not make judgments when they advance large sums of money they are defective in one of their fundamental processes of counselling and deciding which businesses should be financed by their depositors' and shareholders' moneys. The fact that we have a record wave of bankruptcies cannot be blamed totally on the Government of this country but upon the attitude and ethos of banking which prevails.

The Senate can be assured that whilst ever I am convinced that malpractice and corrupt practice is present I will raise this issue again and again. I seek leave to table a press release that I put out today summarising my speech in the chamber.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I offer both the Senate and the public of Australia the assurance that I will return to this issue, as I have said, with a vengeance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.
