TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise the Government's extraordinary action yesterday afternoon in banning the merger that had been arranged, or was being arranged, between the Australian and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd (ANZ) and the National Mutual Life Association of Australasia Ltd. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) said that this merger was not in the national interest and, as a result, it cannot proceed. The need for some explanation of this decision is clear cut. The explanation so far appears that the Treasurer's gut reaction was that he did not like the proposed merger. There is no other coherent response from the Treasurer than that.

SPEECH.PARA: This issue raises the clear question of whether economic policy in Australia, during the run-up to the replacement of Mr Hawke as Prime Minister, is to be run on the basis of what sort of support Mr Keating can drum up within the factions of the Australian Labor Party for his personal ambitions. There is no other coherent reason for Mr Keating's denial of the very basis of his rationalising and restructuring of the financial system about which he has boasted over the last seven years. What he has done has reversed that process. It is not simply me saying that: we can look through today's press. The Sydney Morning Herald, on page 1, says, `The free market has had its day'. The Australian Financial Review's editorial is highly critical of Mr Keating's actions.

The facts are that what Mr Keating has done has not only reversed the process but also has created massive uncertainty within the business community about what the rules are. The onus was on Mr Keating to establish the need to change the rules. He had to establish a clear need for the banning of this merger. The onus was on him; it remains on him, and he has done absolutely nothing. He has failed totally to provide any coherent reason for this intervention-this gross, governmental, `big brother knows best' intervention-in this marketplace.

I have no particular brief for either the ANZ or the National Mutual. On the contrary, I could well claim-and some people have claimed-that at times National Mutual has chosen to lie down as a lamb with the lion, and at the moment it has been severely bitten. I have no special brief for National Mutual. I have no views about whether a merger would be in the best interests of National Mutual policyholders or ANZ shareholders. In fact, the market seemed to indicate that ANZ shareholders did not like it very much. But it was up to the people in the marketplace, the people affected, to determine whether or not it was an appropriate merger. Instead of that happening-instead of the free market dictating what happened-that great dictator Mr Keating came in, because Mr Keating's gut feeling was that perhaps it should not go ahead.

The question of what advice he was relying is interesting. Clearly, he was not relying on economic advice because, as we understand it, there were no objections on policy or principle grounds from the major sources of economic advice to the Government. Mr Keating has yet to explain why his gut has greater significance than the economic advisers that this Government pays a very large amount to maintain.

We do have, however, some comment from Professor Baxt, the Chairman of the Trade Practices Commission. Professor Baxt's response was perhaps even more curious than Mr Keating's. Maybe he is trying to help Mr Keating out of an intolerable position. Mr Baxt admits that the banned ANZ Bank-National Mutual merger would not have been in breach of the Trade Practices Act, but should still have been vetoed. On AM this morning he said:
Under the Trade Practices Act a merger of this kind to breach the Act would have to create a dominant player.
The intriguing part of Professor Baxt's extraordinary remarks is this:
The merger in our view-
this merger-
would not have created a dominant player as defined by the law.

In other words, there was nothing wrong-even from Professor Baxt, who is trying to justify Mr Keating's actions-with this merger in terms of creating a dominant player. It is self-evident that this merger would not have created a dominant player.

One can see from a list in this morning's Australian dealing with market share that the merger of ANZ and National Mutual would have meant that it would have had only 14.2 per cent of Australian banking business and only 12.6 per cent of its superannuation business. So Professor Baxt is obviously right: it would not have created a dominant player as defined by the law and, therefore, there can be no objection on anything other than political grounds to this merger. It is not illegal; it is not improper; and it does not create a dominant force in the market.

What then is Mr Keating's reason for making this decision? Mr Keating's reason is a simple one. He is fighting for the leadership of the Labor Party-it seems in the very near future-when Mr Hawke either steps aside or is pushed aside by a Treasurer, a Deputy Prime Minister, who is clearly, in all his actions, desperate for that position. While Mr Hawke has been ill we have seen the extraordinary way Mr Keating has dressed down Senator Button, thrown his weight around all over the place, and now is dictating to the free market in Australia what new rules should emerge as a result of his gut.
What intrigued me about Professor Baxt's comment `The merger in our view would not have created a dominant player as defined by the law' was that he went on to say:
But what might happen later down the road is the next merger or the one after that would have created that position of dominance.
Professor Baxt said:
What would you say to these people? Sorry, we've got to stop you, but we didn't stop the other two.

There is an old saying `if pigs could fly'. Professor Baxt is saying that something that is proper, reasonable, fits all the requirements of the law and does not create a dominant position must not be allowed to go ahead because maybe some other players in that free market might decide to get together and use that as some sort of precedent. That also is utter garbage.

Professor Baxt really should try a bit harder in his desperation to support Mr Keating in his intolerable position. If one looks at the next biggest players one sees that they would be the Westpac Banking Corporation and the AMP Society. If they merged, their total control of the banking business would be 17 per cent-only 17 per cent of the total market-and only 20 per cent of the superannuation business. Neither of those are dominant market positions by any criteria. If later on some of those bigger merged groups merge with each other, there is a case on the merits of the issue for Professor Baxt to take this incredible-in this context, supportive-role of supporting the Treasurer's impossible position. At the moment there is no justification, and nor can there be, either for Mr Keating's assertion or Professor Baxt's quaint support for him.

The key issue is that what the blocking of this merger does is diminish competition. That is the extraordinary situation. This Government has created an extraordinary environment in which it is encouraging saving through the process of superannuation while at the same time it is diminishing the benefit of saving through the banking system. In other words, banks may well be simply protecting their position by moving in this way into life insurance companies or organisations. The same may be true the other way around, because many of these life insurance bodies, such as the National Mutual, have such an enormous scope for expansion into superannuation, because of the changed tax laws and others, that they have stretched their capital base.

So it is in the best interests of those covered by superannuation and those who are customers of the banks. Yet there is no evidence whatsoever that the people who receive the benefit of bank loans, or loans from superannuation companies, would have their source of lending so cut that it would be an offensive concentration of power. The figures show quite clearly that there would be no dominant player. Professor Baxt admits that.

But to what extent will this decision, as I said, diminish competition? I can reveal that very simply. The National Mutual has been so busy pursuing this new business that the Government has thrust its way-and, I might say, it is one of the reasons I said that the National Mutual may well have been the lamb lying down with the lion-that it has stretched its capital limits. In other words, I cannot continue to compete as effectively with the market leader, which leads it by quite a way-the AMP Society-if it is not given the advantage of the capital backing that the merger with the ANZ would have given it. In other words, what this does is limit competition to prevent the market leader-the AMP-being more hotly pursued by the National Mutual.

I do not know whether the Government is even aware of that. I doubt it. I do not think that that was one of the elements that went into Mr Keating's gut for him to get that feeling. But we do not know what went into Mr Keating's gut. We do not know why he reversed the clear indication that the market had that he was in favour of the free market.

There must be rules, particularly in the banking and finance system, relating to the strength and security of the deposits there. That is why people in the Insurance and Superannuation Commission and the Reserve Bank closely guard the institutions in that area to make certain that people's money is not lost. Those are the only rules we need. We do not need and cannot afford an interventionist Treasurer with the arrogance of Mr Keating messing up this market. The signals that that gives to overseas investors in Australia is absolutely disastrous. We need a clear set of rules, not ad hoc gut feelings from the Treasurer. We need certainty in the marketplace. We want to know what the Government's policy is. We cannot have a situation in which massive damage may well be done both to the shareholders of the ANZ and the policyholders of the National Mutual by this Treasurer's unthinking, irrational intervention in this area. This Parliament must not sit idly by and allow this arrogant Treasurer to interfere in the free marketplace in this way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak about a public scandal of a most serious nature. According to the studies conducted by the Asbestos Diseases Society of Australia Inc., which has its headquarters in Perth, Western Australia, there has been a major and ongoing cover-up by Australian government departments and industry of a very serious public health risk-a health risk which has already claimed thousands of innocent lives; a health risk which will claim many thousands more; and a health risk which is entirely preventable.

SPEECH.PARA: The disease I speak of is indiscriminate in whom it strikes. However, our children are its favoured victims. The asbestos diseases epidemic now taking place in Australia is the result of past events. But the seeds of future asbestos diseases continue to be sown throughout Australia and they will cause even more deaths well into the twenty-first century, as has been well documented.

The causes are the many products and building materials made out of asbestos that have found their way into hundreds of government, commercial and residential buildings and schools. The widespread presence of asbestos fibres in the environment means that the asbestos disaster is not just about occupational health and the bad fortune of those who worked at the CSR Ltd asbestos mine at Wittenoom or for James Hardie Industries Ltd at Baryulgil, or the waterside workers who loaded and unloaded the asbestos fibres, or the building workers and tradesmen, et cetera. It can also be said that the asbestos tragedy was spread into the general community, claiming innocent lives by the thousands.

Already these painful and invariably fatal asbestos-caused diseases claim more lives each year now than AIDS, and yet no government or corporate funds are allocated to developing public awareness of the risk. Almost no funds are made available for associated medical research, and yet during this decade alone more than $3 billion will be spent on medical and social welfare costs for the afflicted.

The research which is currently being carried out in Western Australia by Drs Robinson and Musk and others at the Sir Charles Gairdner Hospital is funded, sparingly for the most part, by the Western Australian State Government. This really should be and is a Federal responsibility. We are unfortunate in Western Australia that, because of the Wittenoom situation, our State is the best laboratory in the world for research into asbestos-related diseases and indeed pressures are currently being put on Western Australia from other countries for more research to be done. There was a recent visit by a delegation from the United Kingdom in that regard.

The enormous dollar cost to the Australian community does not include the lost productivity of the sick, let alone compensate for the suffering or the agony of the families affected by the disease. These facts alone are damning-damning of the Federal and State governments which have in the main deliberately ignored this carnage.

However, the real scandal is that our governments and industry have created these problems and now provide misinformation to the public at large. The entire issue has been the subject of a massive cover-up and those responsible are guilty of heinous neglect. I talk of the millions of tonnes of lethal asbestos which have been widely distributed and are still being imported and used throughout Australia.

All asbestos is a serious health hazard. Every man, woman and child is at risk simply by living or working near the asbestos. The problem begins when microscopic fibres are released into the air and can be breathed into the lungs or ingested. In Australia there are 1 3/4 million houses and hundreds of thousands of schools and factories with asbestos roofs, insulation, walls and fences.

Unlike other more progressive countries, no uniform standards are adopted in Australia for handling asbestos. No education or awareness programs exist in Australia to safeguard the community at large. In fact, many government departments answer public inquiries with an answer that asbestos products represent no significant risk to the community. This is grossly untrue and mere wishful thinking as is evidenced by research teams around the world and the appalling death rate escalation caused by exposure to asbestos fibres.

All Australians are potentially at risk of developing a fatal asbestos-related disease. Those most susceptible to exposure are children. There is no safe threshold of inhalation of asbestos fibres. It needs only one single, small fibre which cannot be seen by the eye. The September 1984 edition of the Medical Journal of Australia stated:
Random autopsies in Melbourne routinely show 50,000 asbestos fibres in every gram of lung tissue of people who have never worked with the material. It is even found in the lungs of newborn babies.
I quote from the Health and Safety Commission of the United States of America:
The risk of mesothelioma is very much higher when exposure occurs early in life.

It is estimated that by the turn of the century at least 12,000 to 16,000 Australians will have died of asbestos-related diseases. The average citizen in the United States has substantially less exposure to asbestos fibres than Australian citizens, yet an estimated 250,000 Americans will die of asbestos-related diseases by the end of this century. West German research carried out in 1979 by Professor Spurny of the Fraunhafer Institute shows that fibres released into the atmosphere from asbestos cement products have shown from 200 to 1,200 fibres per cubic metre of air.

What is not generally known is that one-third of the asbestos-caused deaths represent persons without any occupational exposure to asbestos. The facts are well known and no action is taken. Why is this so? It is simply because acknowledgment of the asbestos hazards could result in massive damage claims and maintenance bills for government and industry. Far better to pretend the problem does not exist at all is the response from Federal government and the industry moguls.

This deliberate avoidance of responsibility is at the least a complete betrayal of public trust. We know all about that in Western Australia with the Wittenoom example. Now, as a result of years of neglect, the problem is compounding and becoming a major threat to the whole community in health and economic terms.

Recent research results from Kawachi General Hospital in Japan show that asbestos fibres cause not only fatal lung diseases through inhalation but also substantial death of heart muscle through ingestion. There are solutions available. We must recognise the problem and accept responsibility for dealing with it. We must have a uniform regulatory system for asbestos containment throughout Australia. We must have public education programs so that people can protect themselves and their families. We must ensure that those professions working with asbestos products do so to safe standards, at least to the Worksafe Australia standard, and failure to do so must meet with tough penalties.

One of Australia's largest asbestos removal companies, G. S. McMahon, was recently caught dumping dangerous asbestos on the roadside of a Sydney suburb. There is no excuse for further neglect in this matter. Unless we are successful in solving the asbestos problem, the regulations and the enforcement agencies are likely to be quite incapable of effectively controlling worker and community exposure to other less known but equally ubiquitous carcinogenic substances. Today asbestos, tomorrow what else?

The asbestos issue is clearly a test of our resolve to control the increasing number of insidious materials to which workers and the community are being unnecessarily exposed. The Australian Democrats are very concerned at the widespread presence of asbestos fibres in the environment and its consequences to the community. Therefore, I can promise the Senate and the Australian people that the Democrats will pursue all avenues open to them to rectify this sad situation by working through the community and Federal and State parliaments in conjunction with the Asbestos Diseases Society of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the remarks of my colleague Senator Michael Baume in raising what is clearly the most significant issue on the political agenda at the present time, and that is the extraordinary decision of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to reject the proposed merger between the Australian and New Zealand Banking Corporation Ltd and the National Mutual Life Association of Australia Ltd. I think that what is being said almost universally in the press today is that the real reasons have yet to be revealed. That is a matter of considerable concern to all thinking Australians because in many ways it heralds a fundamentally different approach to the regulation of excessive concentrations of economic power in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the day I think that the real explanation is more likely to lie in the fact that someone is in hospital having an operation and someone else has decided to flex his biceps. If that is the case, it seems to be part of a pattern that has been developing in recent days to move right away from the generally free market approach that had been espoused by this Government, and the Treasurer in particular, to somehow appease the left wing of the Australian Labor Party (ALP) and to appeal to those populist sentiments in the community so that Mr Keating's power base is able to be broadened accordingly. Tom Burton wrote in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald:
Suddenly Federal Cabinet has dumped its free-market rhetoric and wrapped itself in the flag of nationalism and interventionism.
According to other commentators, the Federal Cabinet was not even consulted on the issue, but otherwise I think the assessment is generally correct.

Tom Burton then went on to detail some other examples, including the equally extraordinary decision to limit the level of foreign ownership in broadcasting to 20 per cent, despite the fact that for the last nine years there has not been a problem in relation to holding companies. There has been essentially passive investment. The logic of this new approach, which no doubt will be characterised as a movement away from globalisation-in other words, going against the world trend, against the moves that are now in place to fragment the Glass-Steagall arrangements which have operated in the United States for the last 60 years-must be the rejection of the mega-com concept whereby significant sections of the ALP have been pushing for a gigantic monopolistic merger of Telecom Australia, Aussat Pty Ltd and the Overseas Telecommunications Corporation.

As Senator Michael Baume correctly pointed out, we are not talking about a monopoly here. At the conclusion of the merger arrangement, ANZ and National Mutual would have had market shares of no more than 14.2 per cent of deposit-taking intermediaries compared with Westpac's 16.4 per cent; 12.6 per cent of funds managed, compared with AMP's 15 per cent, and 13.5 per cent of the total, compared with Westpac's 11.4 per cent.

Clearly, the decision was not taken on anti-competitive grounds per se. There has to be some other reason. The community and, indeed, the participants in this merger, in which they have no doubt invested an enormous amount of time, money and effort, are entitled to a full and frank explanation.

The way in which the commentators have generally described the issue today highlights I think what may well be a reversion back to the 1940s and 1950s, as Dr John Hewson described it in his press release of yesterday. As I think Mr Will Bailey said in a very anguished press release yesterday, the analogy with the Australian automotive industry under McEwen is too close for comfort. What we have now is a situation in which the competitive and prudential rules are being changed with little notice. This provides neither a stable investment environment nor a reliable base for the planning of industry strategy. That is a damning indictment of the Treasurer's so-called rationalist approach to freeing up the commercial sector. If we are not concerned about excessive levels of concentration I would like to know what we are concerned about.

I found the Treasurer's press release quite mystifying because, on one view of it, he seemed to be saying that we are not opposed to the life insurance industry and the banking industry getting together-indeed we do not have a problem if we are talking about life offices taking over banks-but somehow in this instance we have a problem with banks taking over life offices. We all know that there can be reverse takeovers, so I do not know what his attitude would be if somehow a friendly arrangement came about, and it has already been foreshadowed, whereby the National Mutual happened to be the offeror. Would he somehow regard that as more acceptable?

If he is concerned to somehow artificially set in concrete the current arrangements in market shares, what view is he going to take of those smaller banks, such as the Challenge Bank and the Advance Bank, that presumably have been eyed by larger predators for quite some time? Does he take the view, for example, that Westpac ought to be allowed to acquire those two smaller banks and thereby end up with greater market share than the ANZ-greater market share than this merged entity would constitute, and thereby still be consistent in saying that this was against the national interest? It would be an extraordinary outcome to condemn something like a 14 per cent market share and at the same time condone something that is likely to exceed that by a number of percentage points.

It does seem, once again, that we are owed a real explanation. If the Treasurer thinks that somehow we are going to be able to construct oligopoly capitalism, as it has been described this morning, by simply indicating where the Government is going to intervene, what deals it likes and what deals it does not like and what view it takes of levels of market share, we are going to have the most interventionist government in history. The Treasurer owes the community an explanation. We are entitled to an explanation as to where the boundary lines ought to be drawn. Are they to be drawn at 14 per cent or 20 per cent?

What constitutes an excessive concentration of market power? After all, the Trade Practices Commission (TPC) had no objection to this deal in terms of the provisions of its own Act. The most that has happened today, as Senator Michael Baume pointed out, is that Professor Baxt, the Chairman of the TPC, has taken it upon himself to simply go further and say, `Well, although my Act would not preclude this deal, and I am not obliged to intervene, I nonetheless will pass a value judgment for whatever political purpose that might serve'.

That sort of gratuitous intervention does us all a great disservice because it does not give us any indication of where the proper boundaries ought to be and where the Treasurer expects the rationalisation that will inevitably occur to come to a proper level. I think it is a classic example of canutism. The Treasurer is quite clearly trying to hold the line in the short term in the hope that he will get brownie points from some of his colleagues.

As we have been reminded on more than one occasion by those on the other side, bad economics is bad politics. If that is the case, I am sure the chickens will come home to roost because the more that we attempt to somehow turn back the clock and keep those limits frozen, the more we are going to be out of sync with the rest of the world, the less competitive we are going to be, and the fewer market opportunities there are going to be for any such significant entities to operate efficiently in the market place.

It is quite clear that National Mutual does have a capital-raising problem, and it may well be that it will have no option other than to become a listed company. That may be one outcome. I think the Treasurer ought to explain whether that is what he regards as a desirable outcome. There is no doubt that--

TALK.START.PARA: —Stop being a mutual for the benefit of its policyholders and have to become a public company. Ridiculous.

—That is right, Senator. By what divine right does the Treasurer have the power to decide that somehow that is a more efficient outcome than a judgment made by two players in the market who, presumably, have assessed the economies of scale and the benefits that will derive no doubt from bringing together the mammoth asset base of each of them? It is described, I think, as a $130 billion merger. To that extent there must be significant economies that can flow from such a rationalisation.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the Treasurer owes the community an explanation. A laissez faire approach has been taken in the past to much greater mergers, particularly that of Coles-Myer, and News Ltd's takeover of the Herald and Weekly Times Ltd. Those are classic examples. If one stands back at that point when the levels of concentration are clearly much higher than they are in this instance, one has a very big consistency problem, as Will Bailey rightly points out.

TALK.START.PARA: —The only difference is that Mr Keating is trying to get the leadership.

—I think that Senator Baume and most of us on this side of the chamber are acutely aware of the real agenda in this exercise. The strategy of Mr Keating's drive for the top to replace his flaccid friend is becoming clear. I think that a grab for the traditional heartland of the Labor Party by jettisoning the long term requirements of structural change in favour of short time popularism is hardly the proper economic solution for the country.

SPEECH.PARA: The great tragedy of all this is that somehow we are going to have to put up with the Treasurer's agenda in the short term simply because it suits his present political purposes. The press release that he put out is contradictory. It does not explain what the appropriate balance is thought to be; it does not explain why there has been a fundamental move away from allowing the market to determine these issues; and it does not explain why all the major watchdogs, including the Insurance and Superannuation Commission and the Reserve Bank, have generally given it the green light. Of course they have expressed some concerns, and a number of those prudential requirements have already been addressed by the participants. But for the Treasurer to now hit the proposal on the head on the basis of a decision made in his office, presumably on his terms and his judgment of his own interests, is certainly not in the interests of the Australian community. I think we are entitled to more of an explanation than we have had to date.

There is a very real concern about where this current decision is likely to take us. It is quite clear that Mr Keating is trying to capitalise on some community discontent at the high profits that are being derived by banks. I suppose with the notable exception of the ANZ's negative 23 per cent yesterday over the last six months--

TALK.START.PARA: —And Westpac last week.

—Indeed, Westpac last week. No doubt the banks are a convenient scapegoat for the political opportunists, such as the Australian Democrats, who want to find reasons why we cannot reconcile high interest rates and high bank profits. But the fact of the matter is that Mr Keating seems to find it a convenient opportunity to turn around and bag the banks. It is only a decade or so ago when the banks were regarded as arch conservatives. Now they are regarded as profligate predators and proxy entrepreneurs. It would seem to me that what was contemplated in this merger was a return to conservatism; simply a recognition that there are enormous opportunities provided by the Government's tax incentives in the direction of superannuation and a legitimate and understandable desire to capitalise on those market opportunities.

SPEECH.PARA: What has happened here is that the Treasurer, by royal fiat, has simply said that he does not think that that ought to be the case, despite the fact that there are no trade practices or other statutory prohibitions on such a merger. He simply decided that it is not in the national interest. I am sure there will be some plaudits around the Caucus room but I doubt that there will be very many in the wider community. That is where this decision ought to be judged.

TALK.START.PARA: —Were there any in Cabinet? We don't know, do we?

—The reports suggest that this matter did not go to Cabinet and perhaps there is a very good reason for that-that someone was in such a great hurry to make sure that he was able to display his hairy chest before his mate got out of hospital that there was no time to convene a Cabinet meeting. But that is hardly in the best interests of the community and certainly it is not going to be in the best interests of the financial sector in this country. So for those who choose to come in late and then think they understand the whole of the debate, perhaps Senator Collins might like to insist on an ex post report to Cabinet as to the real national interest requirements in this decision. Certainly, I hope that in due course the community will get the same.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Olsen Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue I raise follows a question I posed in the Senate yesterday as to the confusion that has been caused as a result of the Government's proposed luxury car tax-a tax announced on the run during the election campaign. As I understand it, the decision to apply a tax on luxury motor vehicles was the result of a strategy meeting during the election campaign following a call by a Labor backbencher to apply a 2c a litre petrol tax for the purpose of road funding.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was of the view that road funding and its maintenance would become a major election issue. Therefore, to respond to that election issue, the Government decided, on the run, to apply the luxury car tax-indicating that it would generate some $100m in the first year of operation-with a starting date of 1 April.

However, because the result of the election was not known as early as had been anticipated, the date was deferred to 1 May. This indicates clearly that when a policy decision is made on the run it equals, and usually results in, bad law, bad legislation and confusion for those in the industry-in this instance the motor vehicle industry-who have to abide by that law. Yesterday I referred to the confusion in the motor vehicle industry regarding the advice it had been given by the Australian Taxation Office (ATO). Members of that industry are being encouraged to collect the extra tax when in fact there is no legislation entitling them to collect it. In fact, collection of the tax is illegal because no law has been passed entitling motor vehicle dealers to collect it. Their bind is that, if they do not collect the tax from people to whom they have sold motor vehicles and legislation is subsequently passed with an operative date, they will have to go back and collect the tax in arrears from their customers. One well understands the dilemma that would be created for motor vehicle dealers if they attempted to go through that procedure.

Yesterday I asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, whether the Government would clarify the position and what it intended to do, given that the Senate had now clearly rejected the Government's proposal that the operative date for the luxury car tax be 1 May. That proposal was rejected as a result of the combined vote of the Opposition and the Australian Democrats, obviously supporting the principle of the tax but not the principle that a tax should be collected prior to legislation having been passed by the Parliament.

That being the case, the operative date of 1 May is no longer an option for the Government because the Senate has rejected it, full-stop. The 1st of May is off. Therefore, why is the Australian Taxation Office, as of today, still advising motor vehicle dealers that they have a number of choices. They have been told that they can collect the tax and hold it in abeyance in case the legislation is passed-in which case they would apply that tax as of the appropriate operative date or refund it if the tax was not liable on the date of purchase of that motor vehicle. Or they can seek from their customers an undertaking that they will pay the additional tax, should the operative date for the legislation be such that they have bought the car in a period that would make them liable to pay.

Further, I understand and have received information that one branch of the Taxation Office, as recently as yesterday, advised the Nissan Finance Corporation that it ought to collect the tax because when royal assent is given to the Bill, whenever that might be, it will be retrospective to 1 May 1990. If the Tax Office is currently giving that advice to organisations such as the Nissan Finance Corporation and, through it, to the dealer network, it indicates that confusion is reigning not only among motor vehicle dealers but also within the Tax Office itself. For that reason it was not good enough for the Government to respond yesterday by saying that there are technical problems and it does not know quite how it is going to handle them, and that a decision will be made in due course.

The Government should ensure, as a matter of urgency, that the advice being given by the ATO to those who inquire as to the course of action they ought to take-people who in good faith want to work within the spirit of the policy that the Government has clearly enunciated-is clear. There ought to be some clear guidelines given to the ATO, so that the advice it gives to motor vehicle dealers throughout this nation is consistent.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: HOME AND COMMUNITY CARE SCHEME: COMMONWEALTH FUNDING

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. Since the establishment of Commonwealth funding for the home and community care scheme, what programs have been funded by the Commonwealth under the scheme in the Australian Capital Territory? What amount of funding has been made available for each scheme in each year since its introduction?

—It will not surprise Senator Reid to know that I do not have those detailed year by year statistics in the brief that I have brought into Question Time. I undertake to seek from the Minister for Community Services and Health a detailed answer to the honourable senator's question.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NATIONAL ABORIGINAL AND ISLANDER LEGAL SERVICE

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs give consideration to an examination and reassessment of the proper role of the National Aboriginal and Islander Legal Service to determine whether its primary purpose should be the protection of the rights of individual Australians of Aboriginal descent or the promotion of public inquiries? Would the Minister be prepared to seek the advice of Senator Walsh as to the wastefulness and futility of politically motivated inquiries as Senator Walsh outlined in his article in Tuesday's Australian Financial Review?

—The National Aboriginal and Islander Legal Service, referred to by the honourable senator, performs an extremely valuable service for Aboriginal Australians, who, prior to its institution, were routinely expected to come along to court in large numbers, plead guilty and have the process not interfered with by any proper defence. Unfortunately, that was the reality of what happened before this Service was instituted. The question of how it is applied or potential policy changes that might be made in respect of its operations is clearly a matter for the Minister responsible, not for me. I will refer the honourable senator's question to Mr Tickner for a response.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training to an article in the Courier-Mail of 18 May in which the Queensland manager of the Department of Employment, Education and Training claims that Austudy fraud is costing Queensland taxpayers millions of dollars a year. Is Austudy subject to widespread fraud in all States of Australia? If so, what are the principal reasons for such a high level of fraud? What action is being taken to rectify the problem?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The complaint as to the level of fraud has been brought to my attention. The short answer to Senator Colston's question is no. Out of a total expenditure of $820m in 1989-90, it is expected that Austudy fraud will amount to about $12m. This sum is spread proportionately across all States according to the level of expenditure. In addition to this $12m, it is also estimated that another $40m is overpaid, not as a result of premeditated fraud but due to failure of students to advise the Department of Employment, Education and Training of changed circumstances. Recovery is initiated when an overpayment is detected. The majority of fraud and overpayment cases are caused by, firstly, failure of students to notify the Department of withdrawal or change of course or, secondly, failure to advise of an increase in personal income over the estimate given in the application for Austudy.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is aware of this particular problem and is responding to it in a very effective way. In the economic statement preceding the election Mr Keating announced enhanced control measures which will include increased level of review activity and frontline recovery capabilities. These measures are expected to yield savings of approximately $50m annually by 1991-92.

There is a five-pronged response to the problem. Initially, and importantly, there will be a review of high-risk clients. Secondly, there will be verification of client data with external agencies, including checking of claimed personal income with employers and enrolment status with educational institutions. A third response will be to encourage students to inform the Department of changes likely to affect their rate of allowance. An effective way of informing students of that requirement is the fourth response: to publicise the role of the benefits control mechanism to deter students from attempting to defraud the Department. The fifth response is to refer cases of alleged fraud to the Australian Federal Police (AFP) or the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) for further investigation or prosecution. As I said, the Government is responding in a quick and effective way. For instance, in 1989-90 a total of 80 cases have been referred to the AFP or the DPP and 40 students have been prosecuted.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to yesterday's decision by the Government to reject the proposed merger of the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd and National Mutual Life Association of Australasia Ltd. Could the Minister explain how the merger proposal will significantly restrict competition when the merged financial institution would account for no more than 14.2 per cent of deposit taking intermediaries and no more than 12.6 per cent of total superannuation funds managed? What issues did the Treasurer take into account in making his decision in the national interest given that he was reported in the Sydney Morning Herald today as saying that:

QUESTION.PARA: One has to rely on one's own instincts substantially.
Was the decision taken by the Treasurer, that is, the Acting Prime Minister, alone or was Cabinet consulted?

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the last part of the question, I am sure that some Cabinet Ministers were consulted, but I cannot take it any further than that.
—Were you?
—Did Cabinet meet?

—That is quite clear. Honourable senators opposite had only to read the newspapers to understand that, so they should not try to provoke me into confirming what has already been in the newspapers. In so far as the decision is concerned, I find the question surprising from an Opposition which did nothing about deregulation of the financial sector in spite of numerous reports suggesting that it should be done. This Government has a strong record in deregulation of the financial sector. The Treasurer made a very full statement about this matter yesterday. I was not personally aware of the figures that Senator Hill cited and I do not know whether those matters were taken into account by the Treasurer before he made that statement; but I think they were, because it was matter which was considered at some length. It has been under consideration for some time and I am sure all those matters were taken into account. The decision does not indicate a wish to keep life insurance and banking separate as was implied in the question. Rather, as the Treasurer expressed, it was a preference to see institutions growing in their own operations as, for example, Westpac Banking Corporation did, rather than through mergers of our largest institutions.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy whether the wool levy paid by woolgrowers is tax deductable. If so, can the Minister indicate how much tax revenue would be forgone if the levy remained at its present level of 8 per cent, or was increased to 20 per cent as proposed by the Government or to 25 per cent as requested by the Wool Council of Australia?
—Why don't you leave the woolgrowers alone? You have killed them now. You have talked the market down.

—I know that the honourable senator is a redneck, but he should not show that he has a red face. I draw the Minister's attention to an article in the Australian Financial Review on Tuesday, 22 May 1990 which estimates that if all woolgrowers were taxed at the 20 per cent rate, the tax revenue forgone on the levy at the 20 per cent rate would be $200m. If these estimates are correct, does the Minister agree that they indicate that the Australian taxpayer will be making a significant contribution to the preservation of the present reserve price for wool at 870c per kilo?

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The question which has been asked by Senator Schacht requires the Minister to give a whole series of hypothetical calculations on the basis of `what would be the revenue if' and `what would be the revenue if something else'. The question is clearly hypothetical. It invites the Minister to respond to those particular matters and I do not believe that it, or the anticipation of debate on the Wool Tax Levy Amendment Bill, is in conformity with the Standing Orders.

—In reply to the point of order, these types of questions have been allowed in the past. I understood the last part of the question to be: What would be the effect on Government revenue? Therefore, I will allow the question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr President. Quite clearly you have made the ruling and, therefore, it is the correct ruling.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the correct ruling by the President. I wish to indicate my wholehearted support for the ruling. It is the appropriate ruling. It is a fact that Question Time is prolonged by nonsensical points of order like the last one.

ANSWER.PARA: The question from Senator Schacht asked: Is the percentage levy tax deductable? The answer to that is that the figure is tax deductable for woolgrowers. As honourable senators would now know, the levy is set at eight per cent of woolgrowers' income. That levy goes to support the reserve price scheme, marketing and research and development. If the maximum wool tax was increased to 20 per cent, as in the legislation that has been passed in the House of Representatives but which has to come here, or to 25 per cent as the wool industry as asked for and, as recently as yesterday in Roma, expressed its support for, there will be, of course, given the tax deductability nature of it, substantial amounts of revenue forgone. The report that Senator Schacht has referred to in the Australian Financial Review yesterday indicated that this could be around $200m, with a 20 per cent wool tax rate.

It is hard to be very accurate when giving these figures because it requires a calculation based on the number of growers and so on. The Department of Primary Industries and Energy estimates that the present 8 per cent rate provides a total woolgrower tax deduction of around $100m. An increased wool tax rate to 20 per cent would mean about $230m of tax revenue forgone, and a 25 per cent wool tax would mean around $300m forgone.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the income forgone?

—Senator Chapman asks about the income forgone. That is entirely in the hands of the woolgrowers. They are now buying their own product. If they wanted to lower the reserve price they might sell more and actually have income in that form, and that is an option for them.
—How would you know?
—I have told the Senate; that is how I know.
—Order!
—`How would you know?' is a ridiculous interjection from Senator Chapman. The question is entirely reversible.

ANSWER.PARA: The last part of the question by Senator Schacht was: Is this a significant cost? I would have thought, by any measure, that $230m or $300m is a significant cost in revenue forgone, and it is a basis for any Commonwealth government-in particular, this Government-to take an interest in the issue of wool pricing.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I refer to a report released this week by Professor Stephen Kaneff of the Australian National University which shows the Federal funding for renewable energy research has fallen by 88 per cent in real terms since 1978. I ask the Minister, given that military research was allocated $219m in the 1989-90 Budget-170 times the amount spent on renewables-does the Government consider that its research priorities are appropriate? Will the Government act to reverse this alarming decline in investment in Australia's sustainable energy future?
—I call Senator Cook, the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr President. I was waiting for the obligatory point of order from Senator Puplick, but I see he is not in his place.
—Order!

—I should say in answer to this question that it is not logical to draw the comparison that has been drawn by Senator Macklin between military expenditure and expenditure on research in other areas because, quite clearly, the particular needs in a particular area drive the agenda for research in those areas.

ANSWER.PARA: In the area of renewable energy there has been a dwindling of interest in the number of research projects that have come forward and, in recent years, from a commercial point of view, commercially renewable energy sources have been competing against a very low price for conventional energy sources such as oil.

Oil prices, having been low now for some considerable time, have displaced, if you like, to a large extent the research impetus that was generated during the Arab oil price shocks of 1972 and 1977. The reduction of interest in the commercial sector is why the market has reacted in the way that it has and why there has been a reduction in outlays by the Commonwealth for renewable energy research.

Having said that, it is not to say that this is an issue which the Government is not concerned about; we are. In my previous incarnation as Minister for Resources with responsibility for the national energy research development and demonstration grants, I was concerned about the amount of research moneys being allocated to alternatives. I commissioned a study by a consortium, comprising the Centre for Technology and Social Change at the University of Wollongong, Energy Policy and Analysis Pty Ltd in Canberra and the Science Policy Research Centre at Griffith University, into how the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council funds are allocated so as to give a focus in this area so that when prices and commercial interest are low we maintain our research commitment. Inevitably prices will rise and, consequently, so will the interest in alternative energy sources. I understand that that report will be in the hands of the new Minister for Resources any day now. He may even have it. It will be the basis of his and, perhaps later on, the Cabinet's consideration of the possibilities.

One of the other reasons that interest in alternative energy research has dwindled a bit is that some of the more exotic alternative energy sources have become mainstream energy sources. In Western Australia, for example, about 26.4 per cent of all households have solar energy accumulators on their rooftops. In the Northern Territory, 37.8 per cent have them. The interesting statistic here is for Queensland. Queensland, at 5.8 per cent, is below the national average of 6 per cent. That illustrates that some energy sources which were thought of as alternative energy are now, in fact, mainstream energy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Social Security to his response to a question that I asked in Estimates Committee C, regarding whether the Department of Social Security had costed the offer by the Tasmanian Development Authority (TDA) concerning the location of a DSS mainframe computer centre in Hobart. Has the DSS now costed that offer, and has the DSS assessment been subject to review by an independent consideration, given the DSS's predetermined view of this matter? Is the Minister now in a position to tell the Senate what decisions have been made in respect of the location of that mainframe computer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had a meeting yesterday with representatives of the Tasmanian Development Authority, trade union representatives, some senators and Duncan Kerr from the House of Representatives and representatives of my Department who had costed the difference between closing the Melbourne centre and putting it in Hobart, and closing the Hobart centre and putting it in Melbourne-at $9.1m. Obviously, that was a cause of great concern to me. However, during the meeting it became obvious that those costings were not comparing apples with apples. As an example, the Melbourne centre uses 2,200 square metres of space, whereas what was being costed for a building in Hobart was to be 4,500 square metres. That was a source of some concern to the Tasmanians assembled. I sent the Department away to have another go at those costings, so we at least knew what a reasonable comparison was of both proposals. There will be a meeting at 5.30 tonight to go over that costing. Hopefully, I will know a little more about it by the end of the day.

ANSWER.PARA: Today I had a further meeting with the Public Sector Union (PSU) nationally. It put a different view from the one the Tasmanian union has been putting. The PSU view is that we should trial the closure of only one centre to see what effect it has on services to clients. That proposal was put to me today and I intend to consider it. In the case of Hobart, we will have to wait until tonight. I was not satisfied with the Department's costings last night, so it has gone back to try again. Hopefully, I will be able to inform the honourable senator tomorrow of the outcome of those deliberations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware that the regulatory authorities have not opposed the ANZ-National Mutual merger in principle? Given that it was not opposed in principle, what advice did the Government receive from the regulatory authorities-the Department of the Treasury, the Reserve Bank of Australia, and the Insurance and Superannuation Commission? Was this advice influential in determining the Government's position? Does the Minister agree that the Treasurer's decision yesterday has injected a new dimension of uncertainty into business decision making in Australia?

—I do not agree with the conclusion which Senator Watson has drawn from the information he gives us in the first part of his question. Ultimately, irrespective of advice received from various organisations-and there was advice received from various bodies of the kind to which the honourable senator refers-it is a decision which has to be made by government, and it was. I do not wish to canvass the advice which was given from various sources.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade been drawn to a report by Amnesty International that hundreds of people have been secretly executed in China following the Beijing protests last June? Will the Australian Government support a worldwide campaign to protect human rights in China? I further ask: has the Minister any up-to-date information on the fate of political prisoners in China? Is the Minister aware of any change of attitude in the Chinese Government towards persons involved in the Beijing uprising?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the latest report issued on 16 May by Amnesty International concerning continuing human rights violations in China. We have no independent confirmation of the material contained in that report, particularly about executions, but it does reinforce the importance of maintaining efforts to persuade the Chinese Government to bring about an improvement in the human rights situation there. Certainly the human rights situation in China does continue to cause concern to Australia and to the Australian community. We have been very active in stating our concerns to the Chinese Government through bilateral representations and at international forums such as the United Nations Commission on Human Rights, to which, incidentally, Australia was re-elected yesterday for the first time since 1987. We will continue to maintain this level of activity so long as the human rights situation in China remains a matter for concern.

ANSWER.PARA: As to recent developments in the country, it is the case that recently the Chinese Government announced the release of another 211 people who were arrested for their role in the pro-democracy movement. Amongst those released are some prominent leaders of the movement, including one of the four hunger strike leaders. According to Chinese officials, a further 431 people involved in last year's demonstrations, including 42 students, are still, however, in prison under investigation. This development has followed a number of other announcements relating to human rights, including the lifting of martial law in Beijing and, more recently, in Lhasa; the easing of restrictions on travel by foreigners to Tibet; the release in January of 573 detainees; and an official admission that some detainees have been tortured, injured or died in custody. However, we have no further information than this at this time about the fate of political prisoners in China.

As I made clear in my discussion on 9 May with the visiting Chinese Minister for Metallurgical Industry, Mr Qi Yuanjing, although Australia does welcome these measures that have been announced recently, we very strongly believe that China can do a great deal more to improve the human rights situation, including allowing greater freedom of speech and association. Only if genuine improvements occur will it be possible for Australia and other countries to consider the full normalisation of relations with China.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support and Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications aware of the Qantas Airways Ltd-Captain Cook Cruises Pty Ltd partnership that is building a cruise liner in Fiji that will operate in the already oversupplied north Queensland market? Further, in view of reports that Qantas is receiving some type of Fijian Government subsidy for the construction of this ship-which is to cost some $5.5m in Fiji, as opposed to about $10m if built in Australia-does the Minister support the capital starved and protected Qantas using scarce public funds to enter the reef cruise market at the expense of local shipbuilders and local cruise operators? Finally, will he inform the Senate why the Fijian Government is subsidising an Australian Government enterprise, especially when the Australian Government has just resumed foreign aid to the Fijian Government?

—I regret, particularly in the presence of some distinguished visitors that I have noticed in the gallery, that I do not have the details to respond adequately to Senator Boswell's question. I will take the question on notice and provide him with the details later this week.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. In the last Budget some $6 3/4m was allocated for birthing centres and home birth programs. Can the Minister say how much of that money has been spent and where? Further, does he regard progress to this point as being satisfactory?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Crowley has indicated, in the 1989-90 Budget the Commonwealth announced funding of $6.4m as an incentive package, over four years, to assist State and Territory governments to establish alternative birthing services. The incentive package is in recognition of the demand for alternative birthing services, which was brought to the attention of the Commonwealth during the development of the national women's health policy. The Commonwealth's offer consisted of $50,000 in capital or establishment costs for the birthing centres; the salary of one midwife per centre; and a Commonwealth contribution per delivery for outreach midwife assisted home births.

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth is currently negotiating with the States and Territories on the manner in which this program can best be introduced to meet its objectives. The program will be introduced incrementally, as many States and Territories are not in a position to implement the program immediately. However, I understand that four States have indicated that they are in a position to participate now. It is understood that all of this year's allocation of $600,000 will be taken up.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In light of recent reports of excessive medical interference in the childbirth process, at considerable cost and with no improved health outcomes, can the Minister say whether he sees any need for urgency in finalising the arrangements in this area?

—As I said, I understand that in relation to four States the process has reached a stage where the birthing centre program can be put into place. I am sure that Senator Crowley-despite her, I think, correct reading of recent reports-would agree that, for example, the accreditation of midwives is a matter of some importance in relation to such a project. Further, matters like that would have to be satisfactorily concluded before the arrangements could be put in place. As I understand it, if $600,000 is to be taken up this year, then the program must be well advanced.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Defence. First, when will the Government make its final decision on the refits of the Oberon submarines? Secondly, will the Government give full consideration to the fact that a two ocean navy policy requires a refit capacity at Cockburn Sound in Western Australia?

—A Government decision, as I answered Senator Durack during the Estimates Committee late on Tuesday night, I think, is very imminent-within the next two or three weeks. All factors to do with the refit of the Oberons will be taken into account. As I have said on many occasions-and I repeat once again-the contract will go to those who can do a quality job for the best price-that is the way government works-and not on the basis of representation from particular States or vested interests.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Has the Australian Bureau of Statistics reported the latest wool production statistics for Australia? What are the main features of the report? What will be the impact of continued overproduction of wool for Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Bureau of Statistics published, on 22 May, catalogue No. 7144.0, headed `Sheep and Wool, Australia-1989-90 Preliminary'. The main features of that report are that the preliminary results for 1989-90 show a record total of shorn wool production of 1,015 thousand tonnes, an increase of 12.9 per cent on 1988-89. The number of sheep shorn to produce this result rose by 5.7 per cent to 207.6 million. The national sheep flock has increased by 7.1 per cent to 176.6 million. Although there is a massive wool surplus-these are the words of the Bureau of Statistics-mating intentions for the 1990-91 season have risen in New South Wales, Victoria, Queensland and South Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: We have a conjunction of oversupply of wool at the present time with reduced demand because overseas buyers in China, Japan and the Soviet Union have not been participating in wool auctions in the same way as they have in the past. This has meant that a stockpile is held by the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) of around 2.5 million bales. In about four or five weeks, by the end of June, that will be three million bales. The largest stockpile ever held up until this time was 1.6 million bales in 1974-75.

According to the Australian Wool Corporation figures, the stockpile will be between four million and 4.7 million bales in a year's time. The cost to the AWC of storing a single bale for a year is $220, and of this $180 per annum in interest costs is paid on the Corporation's borrowings. A decrease in the interest rates would have only a marginal impact on the AWC's borrowing requirements.

It is for these reasons that Mr Kerin, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, and the Government are concerned that the implications of all the options are properly considered for growers and are in their own interests and in the interests of the economy in general.

The level of the reserve price, which has attracted a lot of public comment, is only one issue, as Mr Kerin keeps saying, that needs to be carefully thought through. Other issues to be taken into account are the effect on woolgrowers of their debt to equity ratio, the effect on woolgrowers' incomes, since they are in effect selling their clip to themselves, and the marketing and promotion strategies adopted by the International Wool Secretariat in the present situation.

In Roma yesterday Mr Kerin pointed out to woolgrowers that, even if there are record sales from now on, it will not be until 1994-95 that the stockpile can be expected to be depleted. For those reasons, and reasons adverted to in the earlier question from Senator Schacht, there is of course widespread public interest in this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to his explanation on Monday concerning the Government's continuing support for sanctions against South Africa. Can the Minister explain why his Government apparently has a quite different approach to Australian businesses such as Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd doing business with a regime in Myanmar which has locked up its opposition under house arrest in the lead-up to the coming election, has shot its citizens in the streets, maintains an appalling record on human rights, and yet receives significant Australian aid?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I accept the honourable senator's description of the human rights situation in Myanmar, which is nothing short of disgraceful and has not lived up to any hopes or expectations that might have reasonably been held for its improvement in the last couple of years. I have already answered a question to that effect. It is not the case that Australia has any kind of significant aid program to Myanmar. That aid program was severed in 1988 in the aftermath of the revolution that occurred.

ANSWER.PARA: The circumstances of the one very small residual component of that aid program which still exists in relation to the Mandalay dairy project were explained to the Senate a few days ago and on a number of previous occasions. It was simply in order to avoid the squandering of a multimillion dollar investment in circumstances that would have been profoundly unhappy for about 8,000 dairy farmers in the area in question.
It is a matter of judgment as to whether one can go that far in the pursuit of what is unquestionably a legitimate moral judgment about Myanmar.

It is always a nice question as to the way in which an aid program ought to respond to human rights violations, bearing in mind that human rights is about economic and social rights as much as it is about political and civil rights. There is no one to one nexus between an aid policy response and a concern about human rights violations. It is a matter of weighing and balancing the circumstances of each particular case. That is something that we have made clear before in talking about the application of aid policy.

Australian commercial activity in Myanmar is not great but it does exist, and Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd is one such company, as Senator Newman pointed out. We have not sought to impose constraints upon companies in any country of the world so far as private commercial activity is concerned, except South Africa. Although there are many countries around the world that have been guilty of human rights deprivations of one kind or another, including Romania, at a time when Senator Newman's party was vigorously applauding the entrepreneurial vigour of Lang Hancock and others in getting barter trade and so on going, it is not a position that we adopt, except in the most exceptional circumstances, to apply government sponsored or government supported sanctions in the private sector.

However, South Africa is and always has been a special case. South Africa still has a constitutional system which is unique in the world, in comprehensively discriminating against people, not just providing for an electoral system as in Fiji which discriminates on the basis of race, but not even acknowledging a right to vote at all on the basis of race and treating people not merely as second class citizens but as non-citizens. We all know of the circumstances in South Africa. The fact that those circumstances have never been understood or appreciated with any sensitivity by anyone in the Opposition is no ground for Senator Newman to make any allegations of double standards so far as the Australian Government is concerned. South Africa remains a special case for that reason. It remains crucially important that that pressure, economic and psychological, be maintained until such time, as I said the other day, that real, genuine and irreversible progress is made in the human rights situation there.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence and concerns the Defence Department's wish list. I ask the Minister whether the Royal Australian Navy is still pressing for two extra submarines at a cost of another $800m and by when he intends to make a decision on this matter. I further ask: Is the Navy considering the acquisition of a helicopter carrier and, if so, what sort of vessel is envisaged, what would it cost and would we buy it from an overseas shipyard or would it be built in Australia? Does the Minister accept the rationale for the Navy to acquire a helicopter carrier on the grounds that it could be used to carry troops or to rescue stranded tourists or does he accept the line that such a support ship is interventionist, as other vessels could carry troops and Qantas Airways Ltd is perfectly capable of rescuing stranded tourists as it did from Beijing last year? Finally, is it possible to reconcile the Department of Defence equipment wish list plus improved conditions for personnel with the recommendation of the recent United Nations special session on international economic cooperation which called on all governments to reduce their military expenditure to a maximum of 2 per cent of gross domestic products?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to Senator Vallentine's 10 questions, it is true to say that from time to time any department, let alone the Department of Defence, does have a whole series of wish lists. It just starts off that way and gradually gets pruned down by the bureaucracy. It is then pruned down by the relevant Minister, assassinated by the Minister for Finance and finally amended by Cabinet. That is just the process of government.

ANSWER.PARA: With regard to the thrust of the honourable senator's overall question about an overall reduction in defence expenditure, which I think I have answered both at Estimates committee hearings and here in respect of previous questions, it really depends on what level one is coming off. The Soviet Union has cut some of its defence; it now appears that it is coming off at least 25 per cent of gross domestic product on defence. We have never been in that ball park. It was once regarded as 15 per cent because people totally overestimated the Soviet economy but it now appears to be 25 per cent. As Senator Vallentine knows, expenditure in Australia has been well below 3 per cent.

In relation to that general point, I do not think that what happens in the rest of the world is particularly applicable to Australia. Even less so. It has been a long while since Australian defence strategies and posture have been based on what the superpowers have been doing. Our defence strategy is specifically directed to respond to events and possibilities in our own region.

As to the two specific questions that Senator Vallentine raised in terms of equipment, I will be reviewing whether there is a sufficient case for an extra two submarines. I must admit to the honourable senator that I have a very open mind on the question. I will be looking at it and making a decision in due course, especially after consulting other colleagues in government. The same applies to any proposed mode of evacuation via a helicopter carrier. All those things should, I think, at least be considered by government and assessed, prioritised and then a final decision made on those particular points. I would not agree, however, that Qantas Airways Ltd can, on all occasions, intervene to save Australian citizens in certain circumstances. I am not saying that a military response is the only other way. But I do not think I can conceive, in some circumstances, that Qantas and its crews could necessarily have the effect that Senator Vallentine thinks they can.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND TRADE

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade aware of a report in Monday's Australian newspaper alleging that taxpayers have been paying the boarding fees at top Australian private schools for the children of several diplomats who are separated from their wives but whose wives live in close proximity to the schools being attended by their children? Is it a fact that the document referred to in the article alleges that Mr Stephen Whitlam, son of former Labor Prime Minister, Gough Whitlam, is a recipient of about $30,000 worth of this largess at taxpayers' expense? Is it a fact that this same document alleges that several years ago, this Government's United Nations mission in Geneva was allocated $80,000 for furniture and fittings to be shared by all staff members but that the then Ambassador, Richard Butler, a former Private Secretary to Gough Whitlam, spent all this money on his house in clear contravention of departmental directions on that specific matter; that additional funds then allocated to Geneva, trimmed from other posts, were similarly spent; and that a third allocation had to be made for other staff? Has the Minister investigated the truth or otherwise of these allegations? If they are true, what action will he take against the approvers and recipients of this largess? If they are false, what action will he take against the perpetrators of the allegations?
—Including you?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Ray's interjection is highly appropriate under the circumstances. The reference was to Senator Chapman as one of the perpetrators of this allegation. Senator Chapman has become a perpetrator by virtue of putting his name in support of it in this place. He has joined the scavengers of the rubbish bins of the Department in putting on the record matters of private family concern in the guise of purporting to advocate the interests of the taxpayer and the public purse. Senator Chapman is as great a disgrace to the public weal as the particular individual officer who--
—Order! Senator Evans, I ask you to withdraw. There were two imputations.
—In deference to your ruling, I withdraw, Mr President.
—Order! You cannot call a senator a disgrace.
—There are a lot of other words I could employ, Mr President, but, in deference to the principles of this place, I will not.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I request that the Minister unreservedly withdraw.
—I thought the Minister had. The Minister will withdraw.

—I withdraw. I make the point that the document in question from which the honourable senator is quoting, as reported in one newspaper, I think, is one that was circulated by an individual calling himself the Officers Revolutionary Council, with no other known supporters or colleagues within the Department.
—He has two now.

—He has a second member now, yes-Senator Chapman. He has scoured personal files and put on the public record matters of intimate private concern as well as matters which may properly be the subject of legitimate concern in so far as they concern suggestions of malexpenditure. To the extent that there is any conceivable substance in any allegation that is made by this particular officer-and there have been a large number of them in recent weeks-the Department is in the process of and has indeed set in train full and thorough investigations, as was discussed at the Estimates Committee. To the extent that any conceivable question of illegality is involved, these matters have been invited by the Department to be referred by the individual in question to the Australian Federal Police.

ANSWER.PARA: I am not saying that these particular allegations are in that category, but what I am making clear for the record is that the Department has been absolutely prepared to lay bare to proper processes of scrutiny, auditing, administration and investigation any conceivable aspect of departmental financial administration that affects the public interest. We are not in the slightest bit defensive about the situation, but we regard it as scumbag behaviour to put on the public record private material of that particular kind, and any repetition of that by anyone purporting to act in the public interest equally justifies that description.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. When will the Minister respond to the detail of the question I have asked and provide the specific answers I have requested.
—I will respond when an appropriate investigation has been conducted and results are known.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What is the Government doing by way of opposition to the economically and ecologically destructive practice of driftnet fishing, particularly in the south-west Pacific?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My ministerial colleague from New Zealand has gone now so I am not sure that the question is quite as necessary as it was half an hour ago, but never mind. It is nonetheless appropriate to put the answer on the public record. The Prime Minister signed the Convention for the Prohibition of Driftnet Fishing in the South Pacific on 2 February during his visit to New Zealand. The Convention bans driftnet fishing by parties to the Convention in their terri- torial seas and exclusive economic and fishing zones and requires parties not to assist the use of driftnets in the South Pacific region and to restrict port access and port servicing facilities for driftnet fishing vessels. The Government is now preparing legislation to enable ratification of the Driftnet Convention and it is cooperating with New Zealand, in particular, to improve driftnet surveillance.

ANSWER.PARA: Protocols or letters supplementing the Convention through which distant-water fishing fleets, including those of Japan and Taiwan, would accept obligations to ban driftnet fishing in the region have been drafted now for further negotiation with the driftnetters. We remain disappointed that Japan and Taiwan still refuse to consider an immediate ban on driftnet fishing in the South Pacific and will continue to urge them to sign the relevant protocol to the Convention.
