Nonetheless, we welcome the Japanese agreement to cease driftnet fishing in the region by 1991.

I should say finally that Australia was also actively involved in the formulation of a consensus resolution at the United Nations General Assembly which was adopted in December last year. That resolution contains a commitment to a cessation of driftnet fishing in the South Pacific by mid-1991 and to moratoriums in other oceans by mid-1992. Australia was instrumental in ensuring that the region's strongly expressed desire to see driftnet fishing banned in the South Pacific was not compromised. It has been Australia's particular concern to coordinate action taken in different oceans to avoid the displacement of driftnet vessels from one ocean to another. It is for this reason that the Government is also pushing for a global ban on driftnet fishing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Prime Minister to comments made by the honourable member for Hinkler, Brian Courtice, in the Parliament recently that the executive members of the Royal Automobile Club of Queensland had lied, cheated and misused members' funds during the 1990 Federal election. Would the Minister please expand on the Government's attitude to this vicious attack?
—Any member of parliament is entitled to say what he or she likes in the Parliament subject to the Standing Orders.
—Do you agree with it?

—I do not even know what the honourable member for Hinkler said. I must say that reading the proceedings of the Senate Question Time in the Hansard is sufficiently boring to not also lead me to indulge in reading the House of Representatives Hansard. I do not read the House of Representatives Hansard as a matter of course and I am not able to say whether I agree or disagree with the honourable member. But if the honourable member for Hinkler wants to make comments in the Parliament which are within the Standing Orders, he is entitled to do so.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CONFERENCE OF MINISTERS: ASIA-PACIFIC ECONOMIC COOPERATION

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade inform the Senate as to the progress in advancing the successful Australian initiative last year in convening a conference of Ministers on Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC).
—This is the last gasp.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate Senator Archer's utter lack of interest in what has perhaps been the most significant enterprise of initiative in which Australia has been involved in recent years and which, more than anything else, has led to our recognition as a key player in the Asia-Pacific region.
—Are you going to hold a ministerial meeting?

—It is more than the Opposition was able to manage in 23 years of government. Following the APEC ministerial level meeting which was held in Canberra last November, we have been seeking to ensure that the momentum to carry forward the process of economic cooperation in the region is maintained. While that meeting in Canberra focused, essentially, on getting the whole exercise off the ground, since then the emphasis has been on developing a work program to give emphasis to APEC.

ANSWER.PARA: Senior officials met in March and agreed on six projects covering human resource development, energy, investment and technology transfer, marine resources conservation, trade and investment data and trade promotion. We were designated as the coordinator, or shepherd, so-called, of the energy project and we are organising a meeting of relevant regional officials to advance that project. The next of these meetings will be held in Singapore at ministerial level on 30 and 31 July. Officials will be meeting in Singapore in late May to review progress and prepare for that meeting and a further meeting is to be held in the Republic of Korea in 1991. In other words, the momentum will be sustained because the institution framework is now well and truly in place.

I finally mention that a meeting of trade Ministers associated with this APEC process is to consider progress on the Uruguay Round in Vancouver on 11 and 12 September. That meeting is to take place in accordance with the agreement, reached at the Canberra meeting, for enhanced regional consultations on that Round at the official ministerial level. One of the key features of the Canberra meeting, it will be recalled by all except those ignoramuses opposite, was the reaffirmation of strong regional support for multilateral trade liberalisation and a determination to secure a successful outcome of that Round.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Is the Minister aware that yesterday, students from the University of Tasmania held the biggest protest rally seen on that campus since the days of the Vietnam war to protest over savage funding cuts to the university by the Federal Government? Is the Minister also aware that because of these Federal cutbacks the University of Tasmania will no longer be able to offer courses in women's studies, Asian studies and religious studies and the future of the entire arts faculty is in the balance? Given the Prime Minister's statement in his policy speech that Australia could no longer be content with being the lucky country and had to become the clever country, how does the Minister explain the decision by the Federal Department of Employment, Education and Training to impose quotas on first-year arts intakes to the University of Tasmania, a decision which will mean an end to the hopes of a tertiary education for hundreds of young Tasmanians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two specific angles to this question. One is the general question of opportunities and funding for higher education, and the other, of course, is the specific part of Senator Brownhill's question that goes to my knowledge of demonstrations in Hobart yesterday.
—Brownhill?

—I am sorry-Senator Calvert. He does not ask too many questions, so I forgot who he was. In respect to the part of the question related to whether I knew there was a demonstration in Hobart yesterday-no, I did not. And I did not know there were quotas. I could obviously seek information on that. In respect to the part of the question that goes to the levels of funding and opportunities in higher education, I think probably three points should be made, and made so that they can be understood by honourable senators opposite.

ANSWER.PARA: We have reached a situation where we are now looking at 150,000 extra places in higher education institutions between 1982 and 1992. Between 1989 and 1992, an extra 63,000 additional places will be created in higher education institutions as well. Senator Calvert is basically talking about this figure-63,000-being the equivalent of re-creating the universities of Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide and Western Australia. So I think to be fair, in his attack he should recognise that the Government has been concerned about ensuring more opportunities for people to study in higher education institutions, and has been successful in doing so.

In terms of the level of funding that he is talking about, it should be recognised that this Government will be spending, by 1992, $3.6 billion in higher education, which is $1.6 million more than we were spending in 1988. It is a massive increase.

The other aspect of it is the level of research funding. By 1992 we are looking at an extra $144m for research in higher education with another $1 billion to be allocated through the Australian Research Council over the next five years. Funding for cooperative research centres of $100m a year will also be allocated within the next five years. So the basis of Senator Calvert's question in terms of the Government's commitment to creating opportunities in higher education and also to increased funding, I think, is totally wrong.

In respect of the reason for the demonstration in Hobart yesterday and all the matters related to that, I will attempt to find out more information for him and make it available to the Senate, hopefully tomorrow.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I take it from the Minister's answer that the fact of Tasmania's only university losing its arts faculty in the overall scene is not that important. In other words, the Minister is saying-and I hope he corrects this-that the rest of Australia can become the clever country but Tasmania will have to be the lucky State.
—It does start behind the eight-ball.

—I do not think I will pick up Senator Collins's interjection on that one, but I think that no-one in this place honestly believes that Tasmania has to start behind the eight-ball, as has been indicated. The point I make is that the Government has an overall commitment towards higher education throughout Australia, irrespective of where one comes from. That commitment has been met by the provision of a massive number of extra places in higher education institutions, as I indicated. That should be recognised. In respect of the Tasmanian situation, I do not think Senator Calvert should take any inference from my answer until he gets a full answer in response to those specific parts of the question.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. This question relates to the sports selected for the Commonwealth Games program every four years. Firstly, is the Minister aware that, though one of the factors to be taken into consideration when selecting the eight optional sports from the list of 17 is the need for sports to provide maximum opportunity for men and women to compete, male orientated or male only sports frequently take up to 50 per cent of the program? Secondly, is it correct that the various sports represented in the previous Games have a vote to decide the venue-and so the sports-for the next games? Is this the main factor that helps to ensure male only or male orientated sports are entrenched? Thirdly, while I am aware that the Commonwealth does not have any control over the Commonwealth Games Federation, influence and encouragement are always possible, particularly as Mr Hawke is the patron of the Australian Commonwealth Games Association. As we move into the 1990s, how can the Government encourage the Commonwealth Games Federation to ensure that sports selected cater for men and women, for example, by including canoeing and table tennis rather than boxing and wrestling?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the great difficulty in looking at the selection of sports does not come so much from a sexist attitude from the sports that are currently involved in the Commonwealth Games but rather from looking at the profile of sports that developing countries prefer. Those countries are the ones which in the real world have the votes and they are the ones who so often push for traditional sports such as boxing, wrestling and weight-lifting. Many of the developing countries that take part in the Commonwealth Games feel that those are the sports in which they have the best chance of doing well; therefore, they tend to support them.

ANSWER.PARA: The other factor about the Commonwealth Games that should be borne in mind when looking at the sports which are likely to be played is that each bidding city actually proposes the list of sports which could best be played in that city. Quite often we will find that the city that bids for the Games gets its way in terms of the sports that if feels it can best handle and for which it has the best venues and training facilities. It is not so much a question of looking at just finding opportunities for women; rather it is a question of making sure that developing countries have, what they consider to be, a fair say in the make-up of the sports that will be played in the Commonwealth Games on each occasion.

As Senator Lees would be aware, the participation of women has dramatically increased in the last decade, and developing countries are showing more of an inclination now to send women, particularly in athletics teams, when perhaps they would not have done so in the past. So I think there has been an improvement. In the context of the meeting that will be held-I am not sure whether it is this year or next year-that has been organised by the Commonwealth Secretariat to look at the structure of the Commonwealth Games, Australia will take up the question of better participation for women. In the past it has not really been some deliberate sexist policy on the part of any country competing in the Commonwealth Games nor has it simply been sports protecting themselves; rather it has been the attitude of developing nations and the kinds of sports played in those countries.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SECRETARY TO THE DEPARTMENT OF IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND TRADE

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the question asked of me earlier by Senator Chapman about allegations of corruption and maladministration in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, I now have available a little further information which I think is appropriate to put on the public record. The most recent allegations to which Senator Chapman referred followed a long course of such allegations of corruption and maladministration which began to be made by this officer calling himself the Officers Revolutionary Council in the latter part of last year. On 18 December a senior officer of my Department formally wrote to the officer concerned asking him to provide information for investigation by the Department of allegations he had made. This was followed up in several discussions with relevant officers of the Department. When nothing was provided and when he continued to make these allegations, he was formally directed on 7 May this year to provide all information including any departmental documents or copies of such to the Australian Federal Police (AFP) for investigation.

ANSWER.PARA: As a further step, on 21 May my Department appointed a senior and experienced officer to investigate any matters that come into the hands of the Department alleging corruption or maladministration. The material that Senator Chapman, in his wisdom, put before us today was distributed by the officer in question on 18 May-last week-to the Department, to other departments and to the press. The material refers to the personal situation of a number of officers and, therefore, gravely and seriously breaches their privacy.

For that reason and also because that matter is now being investigated by the AFP it is inappropriate to go into detail about the allegations. But at this stage I can say that I am advised that the allegations in important respects were factually incorrect. The appropriate and correct means of addressing such allegations is for them to be referred to the AFP. Again, on 18 May, my Department directed the officer concerned to confirm that he had provided all relevant material-in other words that he was not holding anything back-to the AFP. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN DEFENCE FORCES: SURVEILLANCE AND INTERDICTION

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have further information on a question asked by Senator MacGibbon yesterday. As he is not here I seek leave to incorporate my answer in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

Yesterday during question time Senator MacGibbon asked me a question regarding the aggregate cost to the Australian Defence Force of surveillance and interdiction operations mounted by the Australian Defence Forces against foreign fishing vessel incursions within the Australian fishing zone.

I am advised that the Australian Defence Force is committed to providing 1800 patrol boat days per year and 700 P3C (maritime patrol aircraft) hours per year dedicated to surveillance operations in the AFZ and apprehension of illegal foreign fishing vessels where required. These operations are conducted in close co-operation with coastwatch surveillance operations. Generally coastwatch provide the detection capability and RAN patrol boats provide the response capability.

An aggregate cost for 1800 patrol boat days and 700 P3C hours is $23.6m. This figure includes fuel and maintenance, unit amortisation and crew wages-it must be borne in mind, however, that this does not reflect a fully valid assessment of costs. The ships and aircraft have other roles and continuation training is conducted concurrently with surveillance operations to ensure the required military skills are maintained.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have further information in relation to a question asked of me by Senator Brownhill which related specifically to his concerns about reduction in Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) staff in Tamworth. The information has been provided to me by the ABC.

ANSWER.PARA: As part of a program to develop and improve its service to listeners, ABC regional radio in Tamworth and other areas of New South Wales is undergoing some changes. The Tamworth office is currently being refurbished and a new staffing structure is being implemented at 2NU. Although there has been a change in individual staff in the Tamworth office there have been no cuts in staffing numbers in Tamworth or the New England area. The ABC has also advised that it is strongly committed to improving its regional service nationally and has, in recent years, provided more than 50 additional staff in regional areas and opened offices in 15 new locations. It is hopeful that it will soon be able to improve services in the New England and North West region with the location of two additional positions in Armidale. This will allow current staff to concentrate their attention even more on the north-west part of the region.

The ABC has advised that there are no plans to reduce the number of ABC Radio's regional journalist positions. Every effort is to be made to expand the network of regional journalists. For example, in New South Wales the revised staffing plans call for new journalist positions to be located in Nowra, Wagga Wagga, Dubbo, Armidale and Coffs Harbour and an additional journalist to be employed in Bega.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Hill, proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The need for the Government to reconsider its rejection of the call by the New South Wales Government and Opposition for a Royal Commission to investigate the activities of the Mafia with terms of reference focusing upon-

the involvement of the Australian Federal Police and the New South Wales Police with the Mafia in the illegal growing of marijuana crops in the Southern Tablelands of New South Wales and in the Brindabella Ranges in the Australian Capital Territory;
corruption involving the cultivation and distribution of marijuana in the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area and, in particular, the Griffith area; and

the relationship of all the above with the death of Assistant Federal Police Commissioner Winchester, and related allegations of police corruption and any commonality of personal interests involved therein.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussions to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The terms of the matter of public importance are in the terms of the resolution passed last week in the New South Wales State Parliament-carried by all political parties-and have the intention of setting up a royal commission into the Mafia and associated criminal activities. All honourable senators would be aware of the difficulties faced in a geographically limited royal commission. For that reason the New South Wales Parliament approached the Federal Government seeking its support that this royal commission become a joint inquiry. It is to our regret that to date the Federal Government has rejected that request.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a particularly important matter. The Mafia-organised crime network is firmly entrenched in this country. It is nationwide. It has enormous resources. It corrupts police, politicians and other public officials. It has no compunction in killing its opponents. It operates within a code of silence. Crime is its business. It does what is necessary to make a profit and to protect its interests. Whether it is growing an illegal marijuana crop or executing an informant, it acts in a professional way. It is well organised and ruthlessly determined. It has an Italian heritage. This is irrelevant except that, as in the case of other organised crime networks, for example, the Chinese triads or the Japanese yakuza, it provides a particular ethnic bond which can be useful.

The Mafia is not limited to those of Italian background. In fact, it is as much a curse in Italy itself, and the Italian authorities are now putting in enormous resources to combat its criminal activities. In Australia, the law enforcement agencies now know a lot about Mafia operations. The Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence (ABCI) has been gathering material under Operation Alpha since 1981. The National Crime Authority (NCA) under Operation Vigilante has been gathering material since 1986. I understand that since the death of Commissioner Winchester, nearly 18 months ago, the Australian Federal Police has put together a major file on the Australian Mafia. Yet the Australian public knows so little of its structure, its links, its coverage or methods of operation. On this side of the chamber we believe that the Australian public has a right to know that, just as John Hatton had a right to know that there were threats on his life. It is only an aware public which will put sufficient pressure on governments to commit the resources necessary to counter this criminal network.

Ironically, if the Government gets away with avoiding this royal commission, it will be because of public ignorance. Regrettably, traditional law enforcement bodies and the NCA have been largely ineffective in combating the Mafia in Australia. In my contribution to this debate I will seek to sketch the overall picture of the problem that we face. I will explain why traditional law enforcement methods in Australia have been largely ineffective. Most importantly, I will seek to explain why the NCA is not proving to be any more successful. That is particularly important because given as one of the two reasons why the Government will not become a party to this royal commission is that it claims to have the NCA doing the job. My colleague Senator Durack will look at what other royal commissions-some unfairly judged-have been able to achieve in the ongoing fight against organised crime. He will demonstrate why the ACT Coroners Court is inappropriate for this task. That is the other justification given by the Hawke Government for refusing the request of the New South Wales Government and Opposition.

In the case of traditional law enforcement bodies the difficulties faced have been a lack of resources, a lack of power and geographical barriers faced by our individual police forces. These are the same sorts of obstacles referred to by Mr Dowd, the Attorney-General of New South Wales, in his contribution to the Hatton motion last week. In the case of the NCA, there has been a lack of resources, but furthermore it was not designed or structured to combat a nationwide criminal network of the size, complexity or power of the Mafia. The NCA is not an effective body to take an overview; it is more appropriate for a royal commission to do this.

For example, in my home State of South Australia, there are, unfortunately, pockets of official corruption which the NCA, well run and using its special coercive powers, should be able to root out. They have, unfortunately, been able to defeat the traditional law enforcement methods-the police. That is why the NCA was set up. If there was evidence of institutionalised corruption in South Australia, for example, as was seen in Queensland, the NCA would not be the best body to deal with that particular problem. A more appropriate body would be a royal commission-a body of the type we saw in Queensland.

The work of the NCA is more akin to that of the orthodox police methods, except that it has special powers that can be brought into play when traditional law enforcement proves unsuccessful or comes upon a particular barrier of silence. Thus, when we look at Opposition Vigilante, the one mentioned by Senator Tate in answer to questions concerning reference 7 of the NCA, we find useful work in combating particular cells of the Mafia.

As a result of Operation Vigilante, there is no greater public understanding of the Mafia network. There is no real suggestion that the NCA has significantly affected the overall operation of the Mafia in Australia. There is no suggestion that it has been able to take out those who head the Mafia network in Australia. I ask Senator Tate, who will respond in this debate: How many Mafia bosses have been put away under Operation Vigilante? I think he will give the answer of none. The method of the NCA in Operation Vigilante is to follow the crops: that is, the public manifestation of the Mafia network. Through that mechanism you get the small players; occasionally you get lucky and might incidentally get a corrupt police official or police officer who might be protecting a crop.

That was the case of drug chief Moyse. The NCA was observing a crop in South Australia and Moyse happened upon the crop. The Moyse matter was well-handled, in my opinion, and taking him out was a public service. But it did not strike at the heart and soul of the Mafia. He was just another public official, albeit senior, who was corrupted by the Mafia and associated interests. The crop was a Mafia operation. The gardener was one Sergi who was brought into Australia as a specialist in this particular area and who, I understand, is about to be declared a Mafia operative under Italian legislation. I understand that he was responsible also for growing other crops in Australia. A group sought to get him permanent residence in Australia with a false claim that he was a specialist chef. The same group is believed responsible for providing false passports and funds for moving other operatives in and out of Australia. I remind the Senate that this is an international crime network. All of this information was suppressed for two years. The Opposition believes that the public has a right to know. They also have a right to know the linkages between the drugs business and migration rackets.

Apart from the fact that the NCA is not structured to combat an organisation of the size and complexity of the Mafia, it is suffering from internal ruptures brought upon it by itself and by poor Government leadership. I regret to say that at the moment it is in its self-justification mode, concentrating upon itself rather than its task, with the consequent loss of public confidence. It has no head. The last Chairman resigned in unusual circumstances. The last two chairmen have been publicly brawling. The past South Australian head of the Authority was driven out by internal bickering. The Authority has allowed itself to become political-which is a matter I will deal with on another occasion. In other words, it is in no condition to effectively take on the Mafia. For Senator Tate to say that Operations Vigilante is the Government's response to the Mafia is to accept a knockout in the first round.

Let me refer to Bungendore. Bungendore 1 and Bungendore 2 were part of a series of marijuana crops grown by the Mafia and Mafia associates, with the knowledge of the New South Wales and Federal Police, with a potential street value, some believe, in excess of $100m. The police side of the operation was Operation Seville 1 and Seville 2. It is unclear which police officers acted for so-called `legitimate purposes' and which officers were in league with the Mafia. There were some 10 crops. Two crops were ripped off on five separate occasions while under police surveillance. Millions of dollars of the crops reached the market. If ever a set of circumstances called for a public inquiry, it was these.

Bungendore was just another cell in the network. Experienced gardeners were brought in. Public officials were corrupted. The principles have all escaped successful prosecution. Some of the principals have been known for a long time; some are still unknown. Why was there not a public inquiry? We do not know, but there has been speculation. The links between Griffith and Bungendore are clear. I remind the Senate of the leaked Operation Alpha report from the ABCI which indicated that South Australia was just as important in the Mafia network as Griffith. That is the key point. This is not a pocket of corruption that we are looking at. This is a nationwide criminal network that can be effectively combated only by a national response. In the New South Wales Parliament Mr Hatton said:
The Wran Government's record on the Mackay murder is appalling-the prevarication, the delay, the inefficiency, the lies, the half truths, the unwillingness.

Time after time Mr Hatton and those who wanted to get to the bottom of the Mackay murder and the Griffith crops were fobbed off. I regret that we have had the same experience in relation to Bungendore.

The NCA says that no member of the AFP acted illegally. That is incredible because the whole operation was illegal. The AFP blames the New South Wales Police, and vice versa. In Estimates committees and in questions in this Senate, Senator Tate accepts the incredible. The Senate will remember his answer to the police casting the 18 kilograms of marijuana on stoney ground but failing to remember where. Senator Tate accepted the explanation.

The informant Verducci played everyone for fools-or were they fools? As Mr Hatton said, the role of Verducci, his relationships with the police and the reliance placed on him by the NCA scream out for investigation. Of course, after Operation Seville, Verducci was alleged to be growing marijuana in the Guyra area. The prosecutions all collapsed. Senator Tate shrugged his shoulders: they were New South Wales prosecutions.

Where is the truth? At the committal we heard that the usual cut for informants was 10 per cent of the crop. That would come to many thousands of dollars-perhaps $100,000-yet the police claimed to have received only a few thousand dollars. Why did the AFP refuse the applications of Max Chapman to join the force? Who gave the advice that he was too hot to handle? Why did the Federal Government tolerate the situation?

Last week the New South Wales Police Minister said that the AFP Commissioner Colin Woods sanctioned Bungendore. In 1987 Woods went on television and said he knew nothing of Bungendore. Yesterday Senator Tate said Woods knew and agreed to the use of the informant. Where is the truth? When were the Federal Ministers first told of the illegal Operation Seville, and what has been the extent of their briefing since?

The Woodward Royal Commission into Drug Trafficking, reporting in 1979, was the last real attempt to expose the Mafia, to break through the code of silence. Woodward exposed those involved with the Mafia and marijuana growing in Griffith. The same names turned up at Bungendore a decade later. By accident, Bungendore resolved the mystery of the murder of Mackay-murdered by the Mafia. Winchester's murder had all the hallmarks of a Mafia execution. The Federal Government knew of the connection between Winchester and Bungendore-and I do not imply by that any wrongdoing on the part of Winchester. It knew that Winchester was due to give evidence in the Bungendore trials. It knew Bungendore was primarily a Mafia operation. But did that lead the Federal Government to a clearly required, long overdue inquiry into Bungendore? No. Certainly, ultimately there was a coronial inquiry into the death of Winchester, but no-one thought that that would lead to an investigation of Bungendore.

Now Magistrate Cahill, I would say with great courage, is doing what the Government should have caused to be done a long time ago through a more appropriate body. There will be a royal commission. It will be a New South Wales royal commission and Mr Carr, with some courage, I suggest, has made it bipartisan and called upon the Federal Government to put the matter above party politics.

Between a magistrate hampered by inadequate powers and a New South Wales commission hampered by limited jurisdiction, enough of the truth will come out. It will demonstrate that all the Hawke Government has done by its refusal to cooperate is to hinder effective law enforcement, benefit those who are prepared to undermine a basic pillar of our society, and further enrich this evil criminal network which gains from the misery and suffering of fellow Australians. It will be seen as another sad chapter in the sequence of government inaction.

For Senator Tate, of course, who has principal responsibility for protecting the public from organised crime-and who proudly said yesterday that he had advised the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) against a royal commission-ultimately it will be another blot on his record. Senator Tate becomes yet another Minister who, instead of seizing what Mr Hatton calls an historic opportunity, as has been seized by Mr Greiner and Mr Carr, puts another obstacle in the path.

I have no doubt that ultimately the Federal Government will be embarrassed into joining this royal commission. Senator Tate, as the one who advised against cooperation, should reflect upon where that will leave him. It is not too late. This motion has been deliberately couched in moderate terms because what we want is for the Commonwealth to cooperate with New South Wales and, hopefully, other States, in a nationwide effort to combat this criminal network. I repeat what Mr Carr said: this is something which should be put above party politics, and Senator Tate, ahead of all others in this chamber, should be providing the lead the community deserves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hill says that his matter of public importance is couched in moderate terms. Certainly it is couched in different terms from those which were faxed to my office earlier in the day, which spoke of a motion, and moving a matter of public importance. That had to be withdrawn by Senator Hill because, quite clearly, he knows that in this chamber there would not be support for a motion of the type of the matter of public importance that he has put forward if it were in identical terms to the motion moved in the New South Wales Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition is trying to start this matter of public importance on an entirely flawed premise, an entirely erroneous premise. The first sentence states:
The need for the Government to reconsider its rejection of the call . . .

That would give the listener, as I have no doubt it is intended to do, the impression that there has been a straightforward, blunt, utter, forever and a day rejection of the call for a royal commission. I have made it absolutely, abundantly clear time and time again in answers to questions in this place that if at the end of the coronial inquiry there are matters which require further investigation, and if a royal commission is the best way to investigate those matters then this Government will have no hesitation in adopting that particular procedure.

I have said time and time again that there is no question of the seriousness of the matters which have been raised by Mr Hatton. What I have said is that we need to have a process which can further elucidate the matters to which he points. The fact is that I have made it abundantly clear that the question of the convening of a royal commission from the Australian Government's side and the assistance we might give is one that will be properly looked at at the end of a process that is already under way in relation not only to the coronial inquiry but also to inquiries being undertaken by the Australian Federal Police (AFP) and the National Crime Authority (NCA).
It is in relation to the National Crime Authority that I would like to spend some moments. Senator Hill's matter of public importance states:
to investigate the activities of the Mafia
focusing upon-

the involvement of the Australian Federal Police and the New South Wales Police with the Mafia in the illegal growing of marijuana crops in the Southern Tablelands of New South Wales and in the Brindabella Ranges in the Australian Capital Territory;
corruption involving the cultivation and distribution of marijuana in the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area and, in particular, the Griffith area;

Of all honourable senators, Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority member, Senator Robert Hill, would be very well aware of the reference given to the National Crime Authority under the title `Vigilante' by the Commonwealth and by all mainland jurisdictions. Indeed, that reference deals with most of the matters which are of concern to Mr Hatton and others. In the annual reports of the NCA which are tabled in this place there is a full description of the matters which are covered by that reference. As one knows from certain public hearings that have been held by, I think, Mr Justice Stewart he made it clear what the scope of that reference was. In particular, he called for assistance from the general public in relation to those matters dealing with the involvement of persons associated with the Italian community. I take Senator Hill's point that that is not to say that that community is to be tainted by the illegal and criminal activities of some in its midst.

The Vigilante reference has been supported by the Federal Government and by all governments on the mainland of Australia in a bid precisely to tackle Mafia organised crime in Australia. I find it quite extraordinary that Senator Hill would say of the National Crime Authority that it is not constructed in a way which would allow it to tackle organised crime on a national scale across Australia.

That was precisely why the National Crime Authority was established. No doubt, it is because it was established on that basis and was operating to achieve the objectives set out in its statutory charter that Senator Hill found himself able, as a member of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, to give his support to the Committee's report entitled The National Crime Authority-An Initial Evaluation. He indicated that it was working sufficiently well in this new task to have his confidence, that it should have the sunset clause repealed and be allowed to continue. Indeed, this is what the Committee had to say at that time:

Certain of the fears expressed at the time of the establishment of the Authority, both as to the obstacles which might lie in the way of its effective performance of its functions and the potential threat to civil liberties which it posed, appear to date to have proven groundless. So far from being a `9th police force', as some have claimed, the Authority is a unique and novel investigative agency, combining elements of traditional law enforcement agencies with the powers of a Royal Commission and able to use the one to complement the other.

It was that combination of the elements of traditional law enforcement agencies with the powers of a Royal Commission which, apparently, appealed to Senator Hill and the other members of the Committee in ensuring that this Parliament guaranteed the continued existence of the National Crime Authority in its fight against organised crime nation wide.

TALK.START.PARA: —It hasn't the necessary teeth and you know it.

—Senator Walters appears to know better than the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority about the extent of the powers available to the National Crime Authority. In fact, as I recall, there has been no request from that Committee for extra powers to be vested in the National Crime Authority. If there were, I am quite sure that the Government would respond in a very speedy and ready fashion. In relation to the National Crime Authority, my particular concern is with the involvement of the Australian Federal Police, as I have explained to this chamber before, in relation in particular to the dreadful killing of Colin Winchester, the Assistant Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police, in the Australian Capital Territory the aftermath of his assassination, the day after his killing, I went to the National Crime Authority headquarters in Sydney and asked Mr Peter Clarke about the National Crime Authority's investigations into the Bungendore plantations, Operation Seville and, in particular, the role of Mr Winchester. I was told by Mr Peter Clarke that no criminality was involved. The National Crime Authority had carried out an examination of the role of the Australian Federal Police in relation to Operation Seville and had come to that conclusion.
—You accept that?
—Of course I accept the conclusion of the National Crime Authority.
—The police running an illegal operation, and it is not illegal.
—Order! Senator Hill was heard in silence; the Minister should be heard in silence.

—I accept the conclusion of the National Crime Authority as a result of its investigations, that there was no evidence of criminality on the part of the Australian Federal Police in relation to Operation Seville. The National Crime Authority pointed to what it regarded as shortcomings in relation to the administration of Operation Seville by the Australian Federal Police and suggested certain disciplinary actions. Certain action, including counselling, was undertaken by, I think, the then Commissioner, Major-General Grey, in relation to the officers concerned. That was the conclusion of the National Crime Authority in relation to the involvement of the Australian Federal Police. Whatever Senator Hill might want to say about it, it was not tainted by illegality or criminality. I think that that is an extremely important matter once again to put on the record.

SPEECH.PARA: When one takes, perhaps not that particular response by the National Crime Authority in relation to those sorts of allegations but, as Senator Hill did, concentrates more on the overall role of the National Crime Authority. I believe that this Parliament is still entitled to rely on the expertise and the powers available to the Authority to continue to conduct its investigation, particularly with the assistance that it is able to draw on in relation to other law enforcement agencies around Australia, precisely to overcome the jurisdiction barriers, the protection of turf and the jealousy between law enforcement agencies which had so bedevilled and fragmented the fight against organised crime in this country up to the time of the creation and operation of the National Crime Authority.

Senator Hill says that some of the consequences of Operation Seville in law enforcement terms were somewhat accidental, but I think it needs to be emphasised that, as a consequence of following marijuana resulting from the crops at Bungendore down into Victoria, eventually the police were led, by way of admissions made by a person arrested, to the successful conviction of those responsible for the conspiracy to murder Donald Mackay. They are languishing in prison now. Further, there were convictions relating to the conspiracy to murder the Wilsons, who were involved in the terrible Mr Asia syndicate. I think this needs to be emphasised; I do not think it has been mentioned much by the press. The fact is that arising out of Operation Seville, if you wish to put it that way, those responsible for the conspiracy to kill Donald McKay are now in prison. One particular person was sentenced to eight years gaol for his part in the conspiracy to murder Donald McKay. Another person was sentenced to nine years gaol for conspiracy to murder Donald McKay. I think he was also sentenced to life imprisonment in relation to other conspiracies to murder.

TALK.START.PARA: —Probably be out in another 12 months.

—These are very important convictions, and I think Senator Hill ought to acknowledge them. Senator Hill asked whether any of the top people had been successfully prosecuted. No one was more disappointed than I in the collapse of the Queanbeyan prosecutions. It was quite clear that those committal proceedings were going ahead on the basis that, in particular the New South Wales Director of Public Prosecutions, and, indeed, the New South Wales Attorney-General in offering an indemnity hoped that the witness Verducci would live up to the undertakings he had given in order to secure that indemnity. As everybody knows, the committal proceedings collapsed in relation to most of those who were on committal. In relation to four who were eventually committed to trial, they were not proceeded with because Verducci did not live up to the undertaking he had given.

SPEECH.PARA: I felt strongly about this and other instances where prosecutions had collapsed. Indeed, it is interesting that Mr Faris indicated that he believed that in relation to informants one should not use them as witnesses in these sorts of criminal trials unless a lot of corroboration is available. Indeed, he said that he preferred that the informant, if involved in criminal activity, should be charged and convicted, and representations be made to the judge as to sentence in order to deal with the cooperation aspects of the informant turned witness rather than dealing with it by way of indemnities. In any case, Mr Dowd has had to withdraw that indemnity in light of what the magistrate said in relation to Verducci's lack of cooperation.

For those reasons, those committal proceedings and prosecutions did not succeed as one would have hoped. That is greatly to be regretted. But I hope that certain lessons have been learnt about the way in which informants can be turned into witnesses and about what ought to be done in relation to corroboration or some other way of dealing with the evidence they might give. In relation to the coronial inquiry, I do not know what Senator Durack or Senator Hill has to say further about this, but I think that if one reads Mr Hatton's speech-I take it that Senator Hill and Senator Durack, naturally, have perused his speeches as I have-I think they would agree that Mr Hatton did not grasp the full powers available to a coroner in the ACT, particularly his ability to offer an immunity to a person giving evidence so that a self-incriminating answer cannot be used against that person in subsequent criminal proceedings.

Mr Hatton claimed that certain people were not going to come forward at the coroner's inquest because they were not aware that they could be offered that particular section 57 immunity, as it is called. I believe that the coronial inquiry nevertheless is directed to ascertaining the manner and cause of the death of Colin Winchester but, as I also pointed out, if at any stage the coroner thinks a prima facie case has been made out he can charge a person with an indictable offence-and it does not have to be an indictable offence in relation to the actual killing or death-and can, after a certain procedure, commit that person to trial.

It is for that reason primarily that I have indicated my concern that it would be improper to have a royal commission running alongside a coroner's inquest possessed of those particular powers with that sort of evidence coming forward because we know that Mr Cahill, the Chief Magistrate acting as coroner, intends to take evidence in relation to Operation Seville in the next few weeks. I just do not believe that it is at all proper that that coronial inquiry should be conducted in tandem with a royal commission.

For all those reasons, I believe that the Government's position is a sound one. It is that the establishment of a specially constituted joint royal commission is not justified in the current circumstances. I believe that at the end of the coronial inquest we will be in a far better position to make a judgment as a government as to whether indeed the most productive process would be to join with the New South Wales Government in a royal commission procedure. Given the fact that the coronial inquiry is so well advanced, I believe that it would be improper to take any other course at this stage. It is true that I have offered that advice to the Government in relation to the decision which has to be made by the Acting Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in his response to Mr Greiner.

I am informed that Mr Hatton has agreed to cooperate with the coroner and has, in fact, forwarded some material. I think that is an indication that Mr Hatton, having spoken with the Australian Capital Territory coroner, has concluded that he should respond to the invitation of the coroner to put any information he has before him. I believe that is a sensible course for Mr Hatton to take. I think Mr Hatton has probably taken some further advice as to the exact scope of the powers available to the coroner and is prepared to cooperate with the coroner in forwarding that material. I believe that the coroner ought to be allowed to complete this inquiry. I undertake very sincerely that at the end of that coronial inquiry the Government will reconsider the question of the royal commission, and I believe that we will all be in a far better position to make a considered and deliberate judgment in relation to these matters at that time.

In the meantime, whilst Mr Hatton has, in good faith, put forward this particular proposal for a joint royal commission to be commenced immediately, the Senate ought-not that we are called upon to vote at this stage, given the form of the matter of public importance-to permit the current course of inquiries to continue; and at the end of the coronial inquest no doubt there will be further debate in this chamber as to the appropriateness of a royal commission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter we are debating today concerns a call that was started by Mr Hatton in the New South Wales Parliament for a royal commission to deal with a number of matters set out in the resolution of the New South Wales Parliament, some of which actually refer to matters within the Australian Capital Territory. Our view is very much that all parties in this place have an interest in combating crime. There may be a disagreement as to how that should be done. I believe that the suggestions made to date are based, first of all, on a fallacy and, secondly, on an earnest wish and desire that something be done quickly.

SPEECH.PARA: The fallacy-it has been expressed to me by a large number of people I have spoken to on this issue-is, firstly, that the National Crime Authority (NCA) is not capable of undertaking these investigations, which is patently false both in terms of its legislation and its activities, and, secondly, that it has not done so, which is patently false in terms of its reports and the reports of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, a committee of this Parliament. If the NCA continues to be destabilised, it will be the largest gift to organised crime in this country. If the undermining of the NCA continues, as has started in the last few weeks, organised crime, including the Mafia and other criminal syndicates that operate in this country with international links, will be overjoyed because it is the only organisation in Australia capable of dealing with this matter.

I, too, wish there were a magic wand to wave around so that organised crime and the Mafia would go away. It so happens that there is no magic wand in the real world. In the real world the combating of family syndicates depends very largely on deliberative, painstaking, long-term investigatory work. There is no substitute, no matter how much we desire it, for that activity. To do that we have not only the National Crime Authority, but also seven State police forces, two Territory police forces, independent commissions such as the Independent Commission Against Corruption in New South Wales and the Bureau of Criminal Intelligence-a panoply of organisations directed at organised crime. The idea is that if we get a judge-and if one is to believe the overwhelming conspiracy theories in operation at the moment, where would we find a judge who is not corrupt?-and appoint a royal commission, somehow these things will go away. I ask every honourable senator who is interested in the fight against crime to read the history of royal commissions in this country and see what the results are in this area.

I agree that many names will be traduced and dragged through the mud. I am not interested in that; I am interested in whether or not we actually solve the problem of crime. We will get headlines, there will be lovely stories, and politicians might feel good. But the community will continue to be corrupted. There is no substitute for the long-term, painstaking investigatory activity that is necessary to blow apart family syndicates. I wish there were, as I think most people in Australia do.

Anybody who has ever bothered to look at the exercise in Italy would know that the exercise we have embarked on with the National Crime Authority will go on and the community will be paying not just for the next 10, 20, or 30 years but indefinitely, because there is no ultimate solution to crime within society, certainly not the criminal syndicates that are based on international links.
I turn to a number of the reports that honourable senators have referred to in this place. For example, in the National Crime Authority annual report for 1988-89 Mr Justice Stewart says:
As the first Chairman of Australia's only truly national law enforcement agency, I have experienced first hand the realities of law enforcement in a federation-
the realities, not the wish list-

With the establishment of self government in the Australian Capital Territory, we now have in Australia nine jurisdictions making and enforcing laws, each with its own imperatives, issues and pressures.

We have the States righters running around saying that we must not tread on anybody's toes. There are a lot of ways to help the fight against crime which I am sure most people in the Senate-and certainly some have argued this already in this debate-will find completely incompatible with their political objectives. But they are there, if people want to look at some of the more dramatic ways of dealing with the issue. Justice Stewart goes on:

Achieving and maintaining the required level of co-operation from all agencies, to ensure an effective Australian response to organised crime, is no easy task. The need goes well beyond co-operation between individual police forces and other agencies in particular investigations, though that is important. It means focusing on those areas where governments have never achieved effective co-operation . . . It includes the need, on a continuing basis, for the pooling and proper analysis of information, difficult to develop and maintain when corruption is an ever present threat . . .
At this stage of the Authority's life, I believe it is time to develop and widen the use of the power to convene task forces-
which are already under way-

drawn from a variety of investigatory and regulatory agencies such as police forces, the Taxation Office and Corporate Affairs Commissions. These temporary forces give the Authority and other participating agencies the flexibility to target particular syndicates or criminal enterprises, using a wide range of information, powers and resources . . .
That is the reality of fighting crime in Australia. Justice Stewart knows what the reality is. That is what he has put in his report. I wish that some people had read it.

I turn to the third report of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority which was presented to this Parliament last year and which Senator Hill signed. He has already spoken in this debate. I quote from page 3 of that report:

The Authority was thus under pressure to prove itself and to do so quickly even though the investigation of organised crime is a lengthy process and it takes even longer for the results of investigations to be processed by our criminal justice system.
It does-that is the rule of law. There are alternatives. We can have a lynch gang if we want; we can traduce people if we want, but they are not the ways we operate under the rule of law.

I find it passing strange that a couple of weeks ago there was a censure motion moved and carried in this chamber against Senator Tate with regard to a few comments that he made which in fact put a trial off for a time. Now we want people to be tried and convicted without proof and not in a court of law. Will that make people happy? We want to spend millions of dollars doing it, which will come from where? It will come out of money we currently spend combating crime. The money has to come from somewhere and that is where it will come from. When we are making the decision on where we will spend $23.5m-that is what the Costigan Royal Commission into the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union cost us in today's dollar terms-we must ask: Is is better spent here or is it better spent there?

I have said with regard to the call for a royal commission that I am not against it, and my Party is not against a royal commission into this matter. But give us reason as to why we will do it this way; give us some reasons as to why this would work. Give us some reasons as to why the Government would not want to follow through with the NCA and its painstaking operation of not naming people in public without them having the right to defend themselves, but rather taking people into our court system and convicting them-as the Authority has convicted people such as this: Saffron, 3 years; Kiss, 8; Ng, 7; Tung, 7; Ferguson, 16; Royal, 14; Oloyede, 7; Wong, 24; Ng, 20; Xhow, 11; Yau, 9; Tsoi, 9; Wong, 11; Sha, 14; Souksamrane, 14; Phanith, 13; Yuen, 9; Chen, 7; Luu, 10; Nguyen, 7; Nguyen, 8; Wong, 12; Lian, 24; Han, 18; Tan, 22; Tang, 12; Tiffany, 12; Scott, 15; Cornwell, 23; Bull, 18; Webster, 10; Drew, 8; French, 7; Rogers, 13; Rowell, 12; Angelini, 9; Manstead, 7; Huttley, 4; Domican, 14; Moyse, 21; Sergi, 5; Carbone, 7; Malvaso, 5; Barber, 5; Barber, 10; Ferguson, 6; Woods, 6; Amad, 18; Malkoun, 18; Skelton, 6; Shand-Smith, 11; Yeow, 10; Gobindram, 10; Loh, 6 3/4; Chan, 10; Cheah, 8; Grant, 6; Marinovich, 5; Lee, 15; Chan, 15; Maio, 18; Asciak, 10-the list goes on.

It is absolutely absurd to say that the National Crime Authority has done nothing. Senator Hill knows of all those major criminal figures. He knows of the destabilisation of organised crime that the National Crime Authority has engaged in and done so well in. Up to the last count by the National Crime Authority, 191 convictions had been attained-and I have had people ringing me saying that it has not done anything. The amount of confiscated money going into the coffers has totalled $51m.
Senator Walters: All little fish.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walters, from the back bench, knows absolutely nothing about this. She is bleating away she is not interested in how things are really done in the real world. That is how organised crime is battled. It cannot be done by waving a wand. It has to be done in the painstaking way, under the rule of law. That is what we are combating; that is what we are up against. If people believe the noise that is going around that we need only find a judge and appoint a royal commission and it will all be solved, they will create an impression in this country which will be of great joy to organised crime syndicates.

SPEECH.PARA: What we can do, and I hope we will do in a short time, is get a witness protection organisation up and running. If we want to roll organised groups, such as the mafia-as Senator Hill knows, the only way these are broken up is by getting inside people-we have to be able to protect them. They do not come cheap and they do not come easy. There is no easy way of doing it. Let us not kid ourselves and let us try not to kid the community. There is a most extraordinary amount of corruption out there. It is from the top to the bottom. It will always be in the police forces.

What about the waving of the wand around Scotland Yard? In fact, 22 or 24 members of its internal anti-corruption organisation are in gaol-and that is the type of organisation we were going to call on. When we are talking about international syndicates, Scotland Yard is no further removed than Queanbeyan. That is the type of problem that we are dealing with. It is all encompassing, it is dangerous, it is corrupting of our society and of our organisations.

It is not a light matter, it is not a funny matter. It is a matter that goes to the very guts of the organisation of our democracy. How we deal with that will be on the head of everybody in this place. To suggest to the community that there is a simple, easy, slick way of doing it is to feed them a pup, to feed them something which will lead them at the end of the day to come back to us and say, `You misled us, you are the people responsible'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition, through Senator Hill's motion, has raised a very serious problem and has proposed the consideration of a solution to it. It is no part of the Opposition's case to discredit the National Crime Authority (NCA)-Senator Macklin seems to have worked himself up into a great state of passion about that matter, nor is it the Opposition's case to discredit the coronial inquiry being conducted in the Australian Capital Territory by Mr Cahill.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition is concerned to propose and establish by this debate today that a royal commission in the particular circumstances would be a better and a more likely way of tackling and solving this very serious problem. Clearly, there are deficiencies in the NCA, as Senator Hill has said. Hopefully, they are temporary difficulties, but we are not here to discredit the NCA, and Senator Macklin's speech has mostly been way off the point.

The matter that we are really concerned about does raise, and has raised, very great public disquiet; so much so that the whole of the New South Wales Parliament, both the Government and the Opposition, has supported a motion moved by Mr Hatton, an independent and long term crime fighter, and it is in substance that motion that we have proposed should be considered by the Government and the Senate today.

The matter at the heart of this problem is police operations that go back to the early 1980s, known now as Operation Seville 1 and Operation Seville 2. They involve the authorisation or participation-whatever the right word to use is hard to say-in the growing of marijuana crops in Bungendore, which is just over the border from the Australian Capital Territory in New South Wales. The involvement of police in these particular activities is not, of course, unknown to police work. It is popularly known as entrapment, but in our own legal parlance it has got another name. But that is the popular name, and that is the way I propose to refer to it.

It is a very difficult, sensitive and dangerous form of police work, and clearly the involvement of the Australian Federal Police (AFP) and the New South Wales Police in this particular entrapment exercise has gone off the rails and raised these matters of great public disquiet. When I read the Queanbeyan proceedings, as they are now called, in the newspapers in February or March of last year I was immediately concerned about the evidence of the involvement of the police in the growing of marijuana. On what scale it was grown is also a matter of great concern. I do not think we have really ever established the scale of the growing of this marijuana. In fact, we do know that there was a rip-off-I think that was the word Mr Hatton used-in that people had converted to their own use marijuana valued at $2.75m and that it was as a result of this stripping of the crops that the operation was finally brought to an end.

Because of the concern I felt as a result of what I had read-and I did not know anything about the scale of the matter at all-I raised at the Estimates Committee dealing with the AFP on 13 April 1989, at which Senator Tate was present, the police operation in an abstract way with the Assistant Deputy Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police. I did not want to get into the particulars of that operation because I did not know exactly the stage that legal proceedings had reached. I raised with him as best I could a hypothetical case, although he was very concerned to talk about the particular case, and I think that that is where we ended up. Mr Johnson said some very enlightening things. First of all, he said that in deciding on an operation of this kind the issue would be so important that it would need to come to the attention of the Commissioner of Police. Of course, we now find, in the answers given in the New South Wales Parliament earlier this week, that it is said that the Commissioner of the AFP himself approved of the involvement of the AFP. Mr Johnson went on-and this is even more important-to say this:

If confronted with those circumstances today-this is as far as the AFP is concerned-he would not allow that plantation to have been grown. In our judgment, and again armed with 20:20 hindsight, we are saying that that was a wrong decision.
He said further:
The risk of it being stripped, as it was, and released out into the community, as it was, was a risk not worth taking, from our point of view.

This operation was embarked upon essentially by the New South Wales Police, but there was clearly very deep involvement by the AFP as well. It was embarked upon apparently as a result of a decision taken at the very highest level. Whether the decision was actually taken by Sir Colin Woods on behalf of the AFP, I do not know, and that is not important, but it certainly was approved at the highest level in both the New South Wales Police and the AFP. The operation was embarked upon without any legal advice having been taken in relation to the matter and, as Mr Johnson said further in his evidence last year, that is now regarded as very foolish indeed because, of course, the difficulties of the evidence that is obtained by these entrapment methods when it gets to court may in fact lead to the trial failing-which, of course, it did in Queanbeyan.

I mention those matters because these are very dangerous and difficult police methods and should be embarked upon only after very clear consideration and the taking of the best advice possible. But it has raised clearly in the minds of a lot of people a whole series of questions, and it raises the question to what extent some of the police may have been corrupt in these matters. That is what has been behind Mr Hatton's own research over so many years. His concern has been raised more and more by the failure to get answers. The answers given in the New South Wales Parliament earlier this week were the first time that any matters had been put on the public record.

TALK.START.PARA: —The rest have been on the Notice Paper for some years.

—For years and years Mr Hatton has been trying to get information about these questions. The information has only just been given, and has raised a huge head of steam, and it is in those circumstances that we say a royal commission is probably the only way in which this matter can be handled.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Tate, the Minister in charge of this matter, has said that he does not accept the proposition that he has in fact rejected the call for a royal commission, and I am very pleased to hear that. But the fact is that he has rejected it at the present time, and one of the purposes of this debate today is to put to him, the Government and, hopefully, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) himself and not just the Acting Prime Minister (Mr Keating), who seems to be the one now handling this question, for further consideration the very strong arguments there are for a royal commission.

Royal commissions in the last 10 years or so have been appointed into matters of this kind, and I mention in particular the Royal Commission into Drug Trafficking, in New South Wales, headed by Mr Justice Philip Woodward, which was a very thorough investigation for the first time into the growing of marijuana in Australia. That Royal Commission produced a great deal of valuable material. Subsequently, there was the joint Royal Commission between New South Wales and the Commonwealth known as the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking, set up to investigate the activities of the infamous Mr Asia syndicate, and the subsequent Royal Commission of Inquiry into the Activities of the Nugan Hand Group, which was an equally infamous group. Mr Justice Stewart's report was a valuable and voluminous document which led to a great deal of action by government. Indeed, it led to Mr Justice Stewart himself being appointed the foundation chairman of the National Crime Authority. So that was also a very valuable royal commission.

The royal commission that perhaps had the greatest value in the sense of developing new techniques and new methods was that conducted by Mr Frank Costigan. Again, that was a joint commission between the Commonwealth and Victoria and it led to a vast amount of information and recommendations which successive governments have been implementing over a number of years. Some of the better legislation in the criminal field by this government in recent years has had its origins in the report of Mr Costigan.

A royal commission is a very clear way to go because it gives the commissioner wide powers to deal with these vast areas and can obtain information on a wide scale. It can sit in public or in private, depending upon the circumstances, and that is particularly important as far as witnesses are concerned. It can require evidence to be given even though it may be self-incriminatory. It cannot be used in other proceedings, of course, but it can require the evidence to be given. It does not have to rely on a certificate, as does the coroner deciding to give a certificate in a particular case, which presents a coroner with very great difficulties indeed.

The importance of a royal commission is that it has these wider terms of reference as against a coroner's inquiry, which is a specific inquiry. Although it has the powers that Senator Tate has mentioned, they are limited. This matter we are now discussing calls for a wide-ranging power of inquiry. Royal commissions are also much better resourced than coroners' inquiries can be. I mentioned the pioneering methods and techniques of Mr Costigan, and those well established means are now available to a royal commissioner.

A royal commission also has a great deal more general public authority. A royal commission can be given to a distinguished person. He does not have to be a judge, as Senator Macklin seems to think. Indeed, the two most outstanding royal commissions in recent years have been those conducted by Mr Costigan and Mr Fitzgerald. It is a question of the resources that are available to them and the investigators available. As Mr Hatton has pointed out, the investigator available to the coroner, Mr Cahill, is really the police force, which is under suspicion and should be inquired into. I know that there are police who are perfectly capable of assisting him, but the fact is that there is a question of public concern and public disquiet and it is a matter of allaying those concerns as much as getting the information.
We know that royal commissions can have access to taxation records, another very important power in relation to inquiries of this kind.

TALK.START.PARA: —The money trail.
—It is the money trail, looking at the various forms of laundering money and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me conclude this debate by saying that it is of some satisfaction to us that Senator Tate has gone as far as he has. I think it is unnecessary to wait until this coronial inquiry is finished because a royal commission could be set up and could be getting itself ready. As Senator Hill said, it is inevitable that a royal commission will be set up.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a letter from the Acting Prime Minister, Mr Paul Keating, to the Premier of New South Wales, the Hon. Nick Greiner, MLA, on this matter. I have mentioned it to the Leader of the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Acting Prime Minister
Canberra
The Hon N F Greiner MLA
Premier of New South Wales
Parliament House
SYDNEY NSW 2000
My dear Premier

I refer to your letter dated 18 May 1990 expressing your Government's support for a proposal that a joint Royal Commission be established to investigate alleged activities of the Mafia, including police involvement with the Mafia in illegal growing of marijuana crops and alleged corruption, and the death of Assistant Commissioner Winchester of the Australian Federal Police.
The Commonwealth has given careful consideration to your proposal. The matters covered in Mr Hatton's statement in the New South Wales Parliament are clearly of a serious nature.

It is the view of the Government, on reviewing the material raised, that establishment of a specially constituted Royal Commission would not be the most productive way of proceeding in the current circumstances. This view was elaborated on by my colleague the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, Senator Tate, in the Senate on 21 May. Senator Tate said: ``The real issue, I believe, is not whether the matters raised by Mr Hatton have needed or do need investigating but, rather, the most productive way to proceed from this point onwards''.

Senator Tate did, nonetheless, give the following undertaking: ``I do, however, give this Government's commitment that if at the end of the Mr Cahill's inquiry there are remaining issues or if new issues come to light they will be investigated. If, in our view, that requires a Royal Commission, that is what we shall have, but at this stage that requirement is not clear''.

In relation to those matters associated with Assistant Commissioner Winchester's death, there would be difficulties in conducting such an inquiry while the police are still energetically pursing lines of investigation and a Coronial inquiry into the same matter is well-advanced in its own comprehensive investigations. I might add that the Coronial inquiry is armed with considerable statutory powers, including not being bound by rules of evidence or procedure, the power to summon witnesses, the power to require the production of documents and the capacity to compel answers to questions on oath.

While the outcome of both investigations is uncertain at the present time, it does not seem that the circumstances of Assistant Commissioner Winchester's death would be effectively dealt with by the broad ranging inquiry you have outlined. In the event that either investigation brings to light matters that could affect that view the issue would, as I have said, be reconsidered.

In relation to other allegations and events raised in Mr Hatton's statement, I am advised that the more specific and serious of these have already been thoroughly investigated, principally by the National Crime Authority. Moreover, the National Crime Authority has had a national reference since 30 May 1986 into the Mafia and its activities in Australia, as a result of which some 103 persons have had charges preferred against them. I also understand that the ACT Coroner has spoken to Mr Hatton and invited him to put before him any information he has. Mr Hatton has agreed to co-operate with the Coroner and has in fact forwarded some material.

I am also concerned at the possible impact a Royal Commission may have on the findings of the Coronial inquiry. Should the Coroner commit a person or persons for trial, the attendant publicity surrounding a Royal Commission may well prejudice a future trial. In my view, the more appropriate course of action would be to allow the Coroner to complete his inquiry and consider the question of a Royal Commission in the light of his findings.

Both our Governments have been co-operating closely for some time now to counter the problems created by organised crime and I would want to see this continue. While it is the Commonwealth's considered view that a Royal Commission is not the best way of proceeding at this time, I would certainly not wish to close off dialogue on this matter and I would be happy if relevant Commonwealth and NSW Ministers meet to discuss it, if that seems desirable.
Yours sincerely
(Paul Keating)

That business of the day be called on.
