DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION AND TRAINING

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, I present the Committee's report on annual reports.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON THE ENVIRONMENT, RECREATION AND THE ARTS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Black Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts, I present the second report on drugs in sport, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

Sport is about performance in competition. Its huge popularity is due to a range of factors. It is self-fulfilling to compete, can endow fame and material rewards, and is usually most entertaining as a spectacle. For all of these reasons, competitors in sport often consider employing banned practices. Regrettably, many succumb to the temptation to use banned drugs in the pursuit of the success.

This problem is particularly widespread because sport enjoys such a high participation rate in this country. And it is not only competitors at the elite levels who will resort to drugs to succeed. The drugs in sport inquiry has found that there is a performance drug problem even among adolescent athletes.

Regrettably, the problem is wider still. Some performance drugs, in particular anabolic steroids, are used by some people for what can only be described as cosmetic purposes. These people extend from professional bodybuilders to teenagers who want to improve their appearance on the beach.

Accordingly the inquiry on drugs in sport pursued by my Committee was not an inquiry concerning the exposure of a very narrow band of the Australian population to a small market in highly esoteric drugs. it was an inquiry into banned sporting drugs whose use could be considered by many people, from lower grade sports competitors and teenagers who frequent beaches all the way up to Australia's most elite athletes.

The potential market for sports drugs, then, is very considerable. In the course of its investigations, the Committee heard from gymnasium proprietors and health professionals who advised the extent and value of this lucrative market. In fact, the potential scope and value of the sports drug black market raises the spectre of criminal activity concerning these drugs parallel, if not coincident, with that for other proscribed drugs, including narcotics. Of course, some drugs such as amphetamines are drugs of abuse in the wider community and are also proscribed sport drugs.

Importantly, the problem examined by the Committee is not only potentially widespread and involves significant criminal elements, but its possible consequences are tragic. In the course of the inquiry the Committee's resolve to contain the non-therapeutic use of sports drugs was even further strengthened following the death of a young Sydney bodybuilder from the abuse of diuretics and other drugs. The coroner found that at the age of 23 this university student has been rendered sterile from anabolic steroid consumption and had died from a sports drug induced heart attack on the eve of a bodybuilding competition in which he was to compete. The Committee's inquiry, then, is of particular relevance across Australian society and is not simply confined to questions about athletes cheating in sporting events.

Further, the Committee found that the problem of sports drug abuse could not persist as it has without the complicity or incompetent of corrupt medical practitioners, veterinarians and pharmacists. However, just as the inquiry did not expose more than a segment of the black market in banned sports drugs, so it had opportunity to do no more than expose a small number of doctors and pharmacists who have facilitated sports drug abuse. The second report analyses the particular circumstances made known to it about the black market and compliant doctors and pharmacists in the knowledge that the problem is much more widespread. Nevertheless, the Committee examined closely each of the cases before it to determine the methods by which sports drugs have been disseminated.

To demonstrate the nature of the problem uncovered by the Committee in this regard, I refer to the case of a doctor who practices at Woodridge in Queensland. In a seven-month period, one Brisbane pharmacy alone filled 1,107 steroid items on prescriptions from that doctor. Not only were veterinary anabolic steroids supplied for the majority of these prescriptions, but the doctor encouraged steroid use in a Brisbane gymnasium, touted for consultations there and prescribed anabolic steroids solely for bodybuilding purposes-against Australian Medical Association (AMA) policy. This case and several others assisted the Committee to conclude:
that the concept of self-regulation for medical practitioners on this issue is invalid;
that the AMA policy deploring the prescribing of anabolic steroids to improve athletic performance requires regulatory support and enforcement;
that doctors must be prevented from prescribing veterinary anabolic steroids and pharmacists from supplying them.

That is, while the black market in sports drugs and the activities of corrupt doctors and pharmacists across Australia is more extensive than that revealed by the inquiry, the Committee's analysis of particular individuals has been sufficient for devising public policy proposals adequately to control the supply and abuse of sports drugs.

Similarly, the Committee was unable to examine all `professional' sporting codes. In choosing four for examination, however, it was able to satisfy itself about action being taken in `professional' sport to curtail sports drug abuse. And, on the basis of that examination, the Committee devised recommendations for all `professional' sports that centre on the encouragement and administration of adequate drug testing regimes and ensuring that penalties imposed in any one sport-whether amateur or `professional'-will be respected by all sports.

With regard to non-`professional' sports, the way in which the Committee proceeded was somewhat different. While all sports are vulnerable to performance drug use, some are certainly more vulnerable than others. And what is loosely known as the `power sports' are perhaps the most vulnerable. Accordingly, the Committee devoted considerable attention to the problem of drug abuse in weightlifting and powerlifting. It was also logical in this context to consider sports drug use in bodybuilding.

The Committee uncovered a most disturbing picture in Australian weightlifting. In recent years, the Australian Weightlifting Federation has corrupted drug tests by providing adequate clearance time warning, failed to investigate circumstances surrounding the failure of weightlifters to be drug-tested and, in one important case, failed to apply the internationally recognised penalty when a weightlifter was found positive for anabolic steroids in 1987. Further, as was noted in the interim report, the then head weightlifting coach at the Australian Institute of Sport admitted to the Committee that he had knowledge of rumours concerning the purchase overseas of large quantities of performance drugs by AIS weightlifters in 1982. He also admitted that he did nothing about an incident of anabolic steroid use at the AIS in 1984. The interim report had recommended a tribunal, which, had it been in operation in the early 1980s, would have been available to consider these sorts of matters and prevent the subsequent difficulties that were experienced by the AIS and several of its weightlifters.

In order to introduce appropriate reforms in Australian weightlifting, the second report makes eight recommendations. Many more of the Committee's 53 recommendations, however, will contribute to the establishment of a climate in Australia that will significantly constrain the black market in sports drugs and encourage a culture of drug avoidance among athletes. This will make it much less likely that performance drug abuse will continue in weightlifting and all other sports.

The recommendations concerning weightlifting are aimed at ensuring that the administration of the sport is improved while allowing it to reform itself. Because of the problems experienced by the Australian Weightlifting Federation, however, the Committee considered that the reform process should involve the International Weightlifting Federation. Further, the implementation unit recommended to be established in the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories would facilitate the reviews and the necessary reforms.

Of course, much has already been achieved in the cause of preventing sports drug abuse since the Committee received this reference just two years ago in May 1988. One of the most significant steps following the tabling of the Committee's interim report in June 1989 was when the Commonwealth Government established the Australian Sports Drug Agency (ASDA) to conduct sports drug testing in Australia. ASDA has discharged that responsibility with distinction over the past year and the Committee anticipates that ASDA will soon enjoy appropriate legislative support. Its role has now been supplemented by the accreditation in April 1990 of the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories (AGAL) by the International Olympic Committee. AGAL's accreditation means that ASDA no longer has to send samples abroad for testing.

While the achievements have already been significant, the fact that the Committee has made a further 53 recommendations for the second report indicates that very much more must be done to control sports drug abuse. Internationally, for instance, Australia must ensure that its drug-free athletes are competing in environments where those athletes can be confident that no competitors have resorted to performance drugs in the hope of securing an advantage. More must be done to present Australia's position on these matters in forums presently under way abroad. For example, the Dubin inquiry in Canada is inquiring into a similar range of matters examined already by this Committee; and I have been invited to present evidence to the sports drug inquiry into British weightlifting and powerlifting in the United Kingdom.

In Australia, the Committee's recommendations centre on the establishment of an investigatory authority, the Australian Sports Drug Tribunal, which would have authority to review all sports drug matters. That is, the Tribunal would ensure the rights of individual athletes who wished to appeal against penalties imposed following positive drug tests. And, importantly, the Tribunal would also ensure that all drug testing proceeded effectively and that sport authorities conducted their drug testing activities properly and enforced them. The Committee considers that the Australian Sports Drug Tribunal should be established as a matter of some urgency.

The Tribunal would complement the role of the Australian Sports Drug Agency. The Tribunal would receive advice from ASDA about drug test positives and any instances where samples had failed to be provided or where sports administrators had not applied the required penalties. The Tribunal would utilise powers approximating those of a Senate committee in conducting its investigations. It would report to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories the substance of all its investigations and findings. It would subsequently report to the Parliament through the ASDA annual report. Clearly, the operation of this authority would ensure the competent and fair administration of sports drug testing in Australia. Importantly, its establishment would comply with section 7 of the International Olympic Committee's model for a national anti-doping program where the IOC advocates due process review and appeal mechanisms for doping control.

Finally, I should note that the Committee has determined that it will continue with the drugs in sport reference until the Australian Sports Drug Tribunal is established. This will permit the Committee to continue its public monitoring role of sports drug abuse until that is no longer necessary. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the limited time I have I want to go through some of the recommendations of the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts report on drugs in sport. Many of them have been covered adequately and competently by Senator Black, the Chairman of the Committee. I refer first to some recommendations which were made by the first Committee and which have not, in the view of this Committee, been dealt with adequately. We again pursue those recommendations with a sense of the integrity that is required of this Committee and of those who administer public funds.

SPEECH.PARA: Two matters, regrettably, appear to me to reflect the arrogant disregard the Australian Sports Commission (ASC) has for the findings of this Committee and the view of anybody outside the Committee. In the interim report we made some recommendations, for instance, in respect to Miss Jane Flemming. I feel it is a great pity that this matter has to be raised again in this report and has to be raised by me in this chamber because it rather gets to the point where we could be seen as being persecutors because of the attitude of the ASC, and no doubt it will cause Miss Flemming some unnecessary pain and discomfort. Having said that, I do not believe that Miss Flemming ought to suffer a penalty which would bar her from future participation. However, the severity of the penalty ought not, in my view, in any circumstances be equated to the skill, the ability or the profile of the athlete.

In the case of Miss Flemming, as the interim report noted, Miss Flemming confessed in camera to us, although she had come along for a quite different reason, that a Mr Plant had come up to her at the Ulster Games in Belfast on 30 June of 1986. She said:

[Mr Plant] came up to me [at the javelin throwing area] and asked me if I would urinate in a bottle for Sue Howland because she had been picked for testing . . . He gave me a drink bottle . . . I went and weed in a bottle and apparently it got passed off as Sue's urine sample.
This attempt to corrupt a drug test was closely examined in the interim report and a number of conclusions were drawn. Without reading them all, let me mention one:

The Committee finds it unacceptable that although Ms Flemming held an AIS scholarship and discussed the incident with Messrs Kemp, Hilliard and Rice, all AIS coaches, no formal report was made to the AIS, in the first instance by Kemp, although he wrote to the AAU, and in the second instance by the other two. The Committee rejects Mr Bowman's suggestion-
Mr Bowman, I might tell honourable senators, is now the acting head of the Australian Institute of Sport (AIS)-

that because Ms Flemming was representing Australia and not the AIS, the substitution incident was a matter for the Australian Athletic Union and not the AIS. Under the Code of Ethics which AIS scholarship holders are required to sign, the athletes agree, inter alia, to `abide by both the rules and the spirit of my sport'. In the Committee's view, Ms Flemming is liable for disciplinary action by both the Australian Institute of Sport and the Australian Athletic Union.
Since the publication of that report Mr Rice, a very senior member of the Australian Institute of Sport, has written to the Committee. He said:

I am surprised that Jane Flemming, Merv Kemp and Craig Hilliard have admitted that Jane produced a urine specimen at Belfast. When I interviewed Jane at A.I.S. she informed me that she had not done so. For this reason I took no action against her, allowing A.A.U. to continue its enquiry.

That begs the question of whether Mr Rice is likely to have lied to us or Miss Jane Flemming is likely to have lied to us under oath. That, I trust, is a matter that will be pursued by the Australian Sports Commission. The report states:
For present consideration, perhaps the most relevant part of the Interim Report conclusions with regard to Jane Flemming is the last sentence of paragraph 7.102:
In the Committee's view, Ms Flemming is liable for disciplinary action by both the Australian Institute of Sport and the Australian Athletic Union.

During the Estimates Committee hearings last year I managed to extract from Mr Perry Crosswhite, then acting Chief Executive of the AIS and now the acting head of the Australian Sports Commission-he appeared before Senate Estimates Committee D on 28 September 1989-advice that a report had been provided to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, the Minister responsible for the Australian Sports Commission, concerning the conclusions of the interim report. He confirmed that a letter had been sent to Miss Jane Flemming advising her that the Australian Sports Commission thought that she had done wrong and that it disapproved of her participation in the urine substitution. As events transpired, Mr Crosswhite then went on to say that a letter had been written to this effect to Miss Flemming. He subsequently contacted the Committee to advise us that, contrary to his previous advice, no such letter had been sent to Miss Flemming at all but that it was subsequently written and that disapproval was contained in that correspondence. I remind the Senate and the Australian Sports Commission that the International Olympic Committee (IOC) list of doping classes and methods states:

The IOC Medical Commission bans the use of substances and of methods which alter the integrity and validity of urine samples used in doping controls. Examples of banned methods are . . . urine substitution . . .
Then there is some considerable comment in respect to the IOC's attitude to the corrupting of drug tests.

As I say, the Australian Sports Commission, headed by Mr Ted Harris, has judged that nothing worse than a letter of disapproval ought to be written to Miss Jane Flemming, notwithstanding the fact that under normal circumstances she would have been expelled from the Institute and she would have been banned, I think for life, for her conduct. That is what has put us in the dilemma we are presently in.

The Australian Athletics Union thus far has done absolutely nothing, although Mr Plant, who solicited the urine sample from Miss Flemming, has written to the AAU and, in a moment of remorse, he has acknowledged a potential error of judgment-not that he was wrong, not that he was downright corrupt, not that there had been an error, but that there had been a potential error. He acknowledged a potential error of judgment.
The other recommendation which has been ignominiously ignored is the recommendation that disciplinary action be taken against Mr Peter Bowman. The interim report recommended:
that the AIS investigate the approval of medical supply purchases without medical officer authorisation, contrary to AIS policy, with a view to disciplinary action.
Our report goes on to say:

The Committee finds it difficult to believe that the actions of Mr Jones and Mr Wardle could have taken place without some degree of acquiescence or co-operation by senior administrators, and in particular, Mr Bowman.

The relevance of that is that the Committee found that Mr Jones and Mr Wardle were purchasing drugs, anabolic steroids, for weightlifters at the Institute, presumably using taxpayers' money, and it would have been very difficult for that to have taken place without the conduct of Mr Bowman. Mr Bowman's discipline for that was to be promoted to acting head of the AIS. I suspect that that again is the attitude of the Australian Sports Commission to the report and to the conduct of the various officers.

In respect of Mr Jones and Mr Wardle themselves, of course, absolutely nothing has been done. Mr Jones has left the Institute but Mr Wardle happily lives on over there without, to my knowledge, any disciplinary action having taken place whatsoever. In respect to Mr Jones, it was the Committee's conviction that action ought to have taken place on two levels. The report states:
First, the Australian Weightlifting Federation (AWF) ought to have conducted its own investigation of the matter.
It continues:
The Committee has established that the approach taken by the AWF to Mr Lyn Jones and the conclusions of the Interim Report is reprehensible. This judgment has been drawn on the following grounds.

2.35 First, Mr Lyn Jones did not appear before the Committee to provide evidence until Wednesday, 14 December 1988. Yet, at the Annual General Meeting of the AWF held on Saturday 10 December 1988, the AWF passed a resolution pre-emptive of hearings to be held about the AIS, weightlifting in Australia, and drug-taking. The minutes of the AWF Annual General Meeting of 10 December 1988 record that a motion was passed unanimously declaring `total confidence in the integrity and the record of Federation officials, the weightlifting coaches of the AIS and the weightlifting coaches of NSW and Victoria'. The AWF, then, before any officials appeared at the inquiry, showed that it had prejudged the matters to be reviewed. It did not present itself as an authority capable of objective investigation of whatever conclusions were reached by the Committee about Australian weightlifting. This matter is further mentioned at Chapter Six of this Report.

This matter is referred to later in the report. I think it is a reflection of the standing of weightlifting and its administration in Australia and, in part, makes the recommendations that the Committee ultimately made on weightlifting compelling in their conclusions.

I turn to further findings of the second report. One matter which we raised again is that concerning the Australian Sports Drug Tribunal. It is the Committee's view that there ought to be a mechanism in place which provides an opportunity for athletes who feel aggrieved to appeal against findings of whatever nature. It is my view that had such a tribunal been in place now, we would not have had the problems with the Vinnicombe-Neiwand allegations and we would not have had the Chairman of Australian Airlines, Mr Ted Harris, investigating an employee of his company. The Tribunal is designed to protect and preserve the rights of athletes.

I will jump ahead to the evidence we received in respect of professional sport in Australia. I will touch for a moment on the matter of the Australian Football League. It is symptomatic, I suspect, of almost every sport in Australia that those asked about the likelihood of drugs being used in their sport give what they believe to be compelling reasons why drugs are inappropriate and then reflect favourably-and quite properly-upon their athletes. They say there is no prospect of their athletes being inclined to use performance enhancing drugs. Those sorts of comments in respect of the Australian Football League show an abysmal lack of understanding of steroids and perhaps highlight the need for further and better education in that area.

We received evidence from the Australian Football League's doctor and from the players' representative, Mr Madden, who concluded that anabolic steroids would be of no benefit to the sport and that they were not being used. Much was said in a similar vein by Mr Ross Oakley. Mr Oakley stated:

One of the most important things in our game is durability; being able to last a full game and being able to run around a large football field for 120 minutes of football. On that basis, I do not believe there is a risk group, as such, as there is in rugby.
That contrasts rather acutely with a recent positive finding from a Soviet Union marathon runner who presumably runs for a period of 120 minutes.

TALK.START.PARA: —That would be the quickest marathon in history.

—Yes, I would have thought so. Perhaps, more than anything else, what epitomises the lack of understanding of what is going on in their own sport was this evidence that was given to the Committee in camera:

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, with regard to anabolic steroids, the Committee's conviction that they can be directly relevant to AFL players was confirmed during in camera evidence. The Committee accepts, as credible, advice that VFL players in at least one Melbourne club have been administered anabolic steroids over a period of years by the Club doctor.

Presumably the doctor, the coach and players imagined that there was some perceived benefit from steroid use. While the Committee has proposed some improvements, it considers that, in general, the administrators of the professional sports examined for this report have taken a responsible attitude to the threat posed by performance enhancing drugs.

Senator Black made reference to the problems that we have with doctors prescribing steroids and with chemists dispensing them. The Committee has made some recommendations which I trust will overcome that problem. For instance, there is the Queensland case concerning Dr Mark Mitchelson who prescribed 1,107 steroid items which were dispensed at Mr Azar's pharmacy over a seven-month period. Of those 1,107 items, 366 were Deca 50, which is an animal steroid. Mr Azar dispensed 756 veterinary steroids between the end of July 1988 and 20 February 1989. One must assume that there are either a lot of very sick dogs in Queensland or that the use of anabolic steroids is endemic and that veterinary steroids are being obtained legally through doctors' prescriptions and are being dispensed by chemists. The two issues are: firstly, the use of anabolic steroids and, secondly, and more particularly, the use of veterinary steroids.

Mr Azar is not the only person involved. There are a number doing exactly the same thing. Mr Azar explained to the Committee in evidence that, upon checking with the poisons regulations and other information, there was nothing to say that he was doing anything improper or illegal and that that, in his view, applied also to the doctors who had been filling in the prescriptions. Mr Azar made it clear to us that he knew something about the side effects of steroid use but that he knew absolutely nothing about dosages. As the report points out, it makes it impossible to discuss side effects of steroids if one does not know anything about dosages. The Committee has made recommendations in respect of those matters.

In respect of the question of a black market for steroids, there clearly is a black market in Australia. The depth of such a market is not easy to identify but the Committee received sufficient evidence to satisfy it that it is alive and well. A company in Western Australia, SAA Research, which has been referred to previously and which is run by Mr Were and Mr George Farquhar, used to advertise very freely that it was providing steroids. Hopefully, the Committee's recommendations might solve that problem in some respects.

If my memory serves me correctly, at the present time, with the exception of Queensland, it is not an offence in any State to prescribe veterinary steroids for use by humans. Of course, one of the other problems concerns the apprehension of anabolic steroids at the Customs barrier. In one recent case steroids were returned to the gentleman who had been apprehended on the basis of his claim that they were for his personal use. He had sufficient steroids for normal dosages for forty years of personal use.

One other matter we looked at, although not in as much depth as I would have wished, as time overtook us, was the question of bouncer violence. While it is not an issue which directly reflects upon sport, it is a by-product of athletes using steroids for body building purposes.

The Committee has taken considerable evidence from a number of body builders who found employment as bouncers in the security industry. There is clearly a disturbing increase in the level of violence in nightclubs. We took very disturbing evidence. In fact, Sergeant Jones from the Australian Federal Police told us in evidence:

We know of at least one firm in the Australian Capital Territory, MIL Security, which hires a lot of powerlifters, cum bodybuilders. Several of the ex-AIS lifters (weightlifters) and the owner of the firm, Michael Ian Lawrence, have records as long as your arm, for want of the better word. My understanding is that he has a number of convictions for assaulting police.

Mr Lawrence, the principal of MIL Security, responded to a letter from the Committee by confirming that he had a criminal record, including four counts of assaulting police over the past four years. The reason that is a matter of concern to me is that, almost without exception, the bouncers in these nightclubs are body builders and many of them use anabolic steroids. They see their duties and responsibilities as giving them a quasi-legitimate right to use physical violence against customers, and in many circumstances those customers are not in a state either to resist or to recall in detail later the events that had taken place.

One of the other matters which is of concern to us is that of police officers moonlighting after hours as bouncers and also those that take anabolic steroids. I understand that both Victoria and Queensland are now taking steps to regulate the security industry.

Senator Black has spoken at some length on the question of weight-lifting in Australia and its administration which I would have thought is either corrupt or incompetent. My best guess is that it is both. It is clearly not able to administer itself in a professional way. There is much evidence given of the use of anabolic steroids by weight-lifters. There is evidence of prior notice of the intention to test, including a circular distributed by Dr David Kennedy, Chairman of the Australian Weightlifting Association and the Oceania Medical Committee, and a member of the International Weightlifting Federation Committee. There are two excellent examples in the report of positives taken and no action taken. One is in respect of a Mr Satry Ma. Another one is Mr Nick Voukelatos. There are circumstances surrounding a Darren Walker. All of these deserve very considerable investigation.

I conclude my remarks by saying that I hope that the recommendations in this report are pursued by the Government with some vigour and by the Australian Sports Commission (ASC). It is the latter one that I have particular concern about. I will be raising the matter of primary concern at the Estimates Committee, but thus far I have seen no determination by the ASC to pursue the recommendations that have been made by this Committee and which impinge upon the Commission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise very briefly. The first point I put on record concerns the work done by the Chairman and the secretariat on this inquiry. I believe that when this term of reference was first mooted it was received with quite a lukewarm reception by the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts. It was mainly activated by the wish of the Chairman, Senator Crichton-Browne and me. It turned out to be a far-reaching inquiry. History will treat it as a far-reaching inquiry for what it has brought out today. I know that Senator Black departs on 30 June from this place but that may be temporary. If he does not ever return to this place, I think he will be remembered for the work that he has done on this Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: If I have any criticism of the inquiry, it is that although it lasted long enough it was not quite widespread enough, and there have been some reasons for that. My biggest concern is that the inquiry did not come to my State of Western Australia where we have a lot of expertise in sports medicine and other facilities allied to sports medicine. But not only that, we have a problem. Probably the greatest single problem in Western Australia pertaining to drugs in sport is that the veterinary chemicals that are being used and abused by humans are supplied from over there. I was sorry that the inquiry did not go to Western Australia, but I know that there were problems. I believe there were two dates set down and both were interfered with by the airline strike.

However, I will not go into the recommendations in depth, but I would just like to look at No. 1 which has already been mentioned, and that is that the Government establish an implementation unit within the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to deal in an integrated fashion with the recommendations from the interim and second reports. The fears or concerns I expressed earlier were that the inquiry did not cover all of Australia or other codes of sport, because I believe that the inquiry was concentrated mostly on power sports. Obviously, that is where steroids have mostly been abused. There are certainly other codes of football and other sports that could have been looked at. I do not fear for that.

If this first recommendation is put into place, those aspects can be picked up in due course. I certainly hope that the Government does take up that particular recommendation and most of the other recommendations that are in this report. I know there are members of the Committee who have not had a chance to read the report fully who may want to speak further-and I certainly have not digested the whole report-but I would seek leave at this stage, if there are no other willing speakers, to continue my remarks later.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before us this afternoon we have four reports from the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. I wish to speak to two of these. The first is the report of the inquiry into the death of Nita Blankett. Nita Blankett died on 14 January 1982. She was then in the custody of the Department of Corrections and died at approximately 10.30 p.m. en route to St Andrews Medical Centre, Midland, which is on the outskirts of Perth, where it was intended that she would receive medical treatment for an acute attack of asthma from which she was suffering.

SPEECH.PARA: Nita Blankett was a chronic asthmatic with a history of severe attacks requiring hospitalisation. Her asthma was not well controlled. Before her imprisonment she was an invalid pensioner unable to work because of asthma. On the day of her death she was cleaning windows with an ammonia-based cleaner. It is possible that this precipitated the attack. While junior custodial staff and other prisoners were sympathetic and concerned, Senior Officer Crowfoot did not both at any time to check up on their concerns, although she did ask Sister Rice to see the prisoner. Sister Rice, we learn in the report, despite her professional training, had very poor knowledge of the condition of asthma.

The fact is that Sister Rice did not accept the request of Nita Blankett to be examined by a doctor, nor did she pass on the request to Senior Officer Crowfoot because she did not think it would be possible. It appears that there was some thought that Nita Blankett was putting it on and that her symptoms were not real. Eventually, in spite of Nita's hysterical pleas for an ambulance, she was taken to the medical centre, but taken in a prison van. She was left alone in the back of the van with non-one to comfort here. When they arrived at the medical centre she was dead. In spite of the fact that the surgery was well equipped with all the necessary equipment, the doctor on duty did not bother to attempt resuscitation. He certified life extinct.

We learn that the police investigation was inadequate. One day was allocated for completion of the task and the young woman given the job had no experience with sudden death, let alone a death in custody. She did not bother to check on the standing orders relating to such matters. In his report the Commissioner states:

It seems an unusual way to conduct an investigation of a death in custody, to rely upon the Superintendent to select the prisoners who would, or would not, speak to the investigating officer from the police.
Later on he states:

During the course of the inquest the Coroner discovered that a number of other prisoners could give evidence on the events of that night, and the inquest was adjourned accordingly to enable these prisoners to give evidence.

The tragedy of this sorry tale is that a fully equipped ambulance was only minutes away. Indeed, knowing the history of Nita Blankett and her asthma, the suspicion has to be there that she need not have died. The Commissioner in his conclusions says:

I commend changes in procedure which have already been implemented and I recommend that custodial and medical staff receive the necessary information and training to enable them to follow general procedures for dealing with medical emergencies and specifically to recognise and deal with an asthma attack in a prisoner.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 May, on motion by Senator Jenkins:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish also to speak to this report, which again relates to a death in custody in Western Australia. This is the report of the inquiry into the death of Albert Dougal. Albert Dougal was born in Broome on 26 February 1956. On the evening of Wednesday, 4 December 1980, he was lodged in the lockup of the Broome police station by police officers, who assumed that he was drunk when they found him at about 8.45 p.m. on the roadway outside the Roebuck Bay Hotel. He was in an unconscious condition from which he could not be roused and he smelled strongly of alcohol. He died on 9 December. A post-mortem was performed on his body and it was found that the cause of death was respiratory failure due to brain damage. In fact his skull was fractured.

SPEECH.PARA: What is particularly tragic here again is that the police acted in good faith. At the time their ruling was that if a person was found presumably drunk but unconscious outside the Roebuck Bay Hotel in Broome, then that person would be imprisoned. The rules have now been changed and for very good reason. Indeed, the death of Albert Dougal has had a lot to do with the changing of those rules.

What happened to Albert Dougal? He did not regain consciousness. In fact, he was checked only once during the night. During the period Dougal was in the police lockup, only one cell check was noted and that was at 2.55 a.m., five minutes before the constable and the police aide went off duty for the night. The Commissioner is very critical of the fact that police lockups in Western Australia, and presumably in other States too, are not necessarily manned all night. Indeed, in this report the Commissioner makes the following recommendation:

I would urge the Commissioner of Police to ensure that country police stations such as Broome are manned twenty-four hours a day. If resources are not available, it is incumbent on government to provide them. The police cannot fulfil their duty of care to those in their custody otherwise.

That is a very obvious statement. If people are in custody, by definition they are under care. The next morning when Albert Dougal could not be roused he was removed to the Broome District Hospital. Finally, emergency exploratory surgery was undertaken to treat brain damage but he did not regain consciousness and died four days later on the morning of 9 December. Other recommendations which have been made with regard to other deaths in custody also relate to the condition of Albert Dougal. That is, if a person in custody cannot be roused, then medical attention should be sought immediately. This is one of the standing orders of the East Perth lockup. I presume that this is now carried out in all the lockups in Western Australia.

Very shortly the Royal Commission will cease its investigations. Certainly the recommendations made by the various Commissioners are very serious. It is to be hoped that all States will take note of those recommendations and immediately implement them. Some of the recommendations made in Commissioner Muirhead's interim report have not yet been implemented by a number of States. This is a very urgent and serious matter, which should be addressed immediately.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Jane Mugford has taken a particular interest in domestic violence, dealt with in the seventeenth annual report of the Australian Institute of Criminology. She very clearly points out that, although several surveys have been taken, we have no statistics on domestic violence at all. One survey that comes to mind states that one in five men think it is all right to rough up their wives every now and again. Some women think that that is still acceptable. It is horrifying, but it is just a survey; it is not a statistic that is at all reliable. Ms Mugford says that there are no accurate statistics on the extent of the problem that could be used to guide the present Government on any decision making.

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government has committed only $2m over three years for its national education campaign compared with $16m for the current year alone on public education on drug abuse. As honourable senators can see, the $2m over three years is totally inadequate. We believe that there is a problem in the community.

The second report, put out by the Criminology Research Council, relates to rural domestic violence. Again, there are no statistics. Miss Mugford says that the use of the statistic of domestic violence being committed in one in three homes can only come home to haunt us because we have no accurate information and therefore that statistic could be entirely wrong; yet we keep perpetrating the use of it.

Miss Mugford has prepared a methodology for working out statistics. That is mentioned in this annual report. The Minister might be able to inform me whether this suggestion is being taken up by the Government. Miss Mugford has a method of collecting statistics on domestic violence which, if implemented, would provide for the first time in Australia a firm basis for estimating prevalence of domestic violence and it would collect and coordinate information on cases reported to criminal justice as well as health and welfare agencies.

It is essential that this information, this data, is collected and collected as soon as possible. As I say, it is of great concern to me that so little money has been put forward by the Government in this area. I ask the Minister to inform the Senate whether Miss Mugford will be permitted to carry out this research. Mr Acting Deputy President, if no other honourable senator wishes to speak on this matter I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 May, on motion by Senator Reid:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Fishing Industry Research and Development Council first met in October 1988. The prime function of the Council was to fund appropriate research and development with the aim of benefiting the industry. When one considers the fishing industry, it is also necessary to understand that it includes a wide range of areas involving such aspects as catching, culturing, transporting, processing and marketing of fish products. I am pleased to see that the Council's objective is to fund research and development which will improve the economic position of the fishing industry because I believe that this has a very positive impact upon the Australian economy and also upon the community.

SPEECH.PARA: We are now in a time when people are placing ever-increasing emphasis on correct diet and healthy lifestyle. Seafoods fit well within that category. It is clear that, as we approach the twenty-first century, seafoods will become a more important part of our diet. In considering programs suitable for funding, the Council looks at applications which can conserve our fisheries resource and at the same time enhance productivity. One of the key areas which falls within these categories is the opportunities for new fisheries in providing access to fish stocks. We have seen the development of aquaculture as part of this process whereby what previously would have been considered as native species are being harvested in a similar manner to normal farm production.

These developments lead to increasing returns to producers and the lowering of costs generally for the consumer. During the election campaign Senator Fred Chaney, as he then was, and I inspected a fish farm at Dover in Tasmania where we were shown a trial growing area of native fish called stripey trumpeter. The potential for that species further down the track, particularly on the Japanese market, is quite considerable. In looking at this Council's report, I was particularly interested in a number of programs that have received funding and were based in my own State of Tasmania. I will, therefore, briefly elaborate on several of those projects.

Firstly, I would like to mention the jack mackerel resource assessment in south-eastern Australian waters which is being undertaken by the Division of Sea Fisheries within the Tasmanian Department of Primary Industries. Jack mackerel is Australia's largest single species fishery. In 1988-89, 42,000 tonnes valued at $4m were landed. Over the last two years catches of jack mackerel have been monitored with a view to collecting important information regarding stock size, breeding and early life history.

It is very important for the future that jack mackerel stocks be assessed in relation to environmental factors to enable appropriate annual total catches to be set. Over this season it has been disappointing to see that those numbers have dropped significantly. As yet, we do not know the reason. But because of this important research we will be able to find out the reason. I also place on record my personal appreciation and the appreciation of the whole community for the work which the Division of Sea Fisheries is undertaking.

I also refer to the scholarships for training fishermen which the Council is providing at the Australian Maritime College in Launceston. The Australian Maritime College has filled a vital role in providing training for local fishermen to ensure the proper utilisation of our fisheries resources within the 200-mile Australian fishing zone. Obviously, if our fishing industry is to prosper and grow, it is vital that we encourage young people to make use of the comprehensive training facilities at the College. Without such financial support the young people concerned would not be able to take time for such courses.

I also briefly refer to the very important work being undertaken by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) into toxic dinoflagellate spores in ships' ballast water, which has been of some concern to the mollusc growing industry-for example, oysters and mussels-in the D'Entrecasteaux Channel area. This problem has come forward in recent times and it is very encouraging to see that this Research Council is investigating that matter. It is understood that the algae was introduced to Tasmanian waters, possibly from Japan, through the discharge of ballast water. It is thanks to the research of the CSIRO that we are developing a better understanding of this process and the way in which such micro-organisms can cause risks to human health.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I wish to comment on a couple of matters in this report of the Australian Agricultural Council (AAC) meeting, held in Hobart on 8 February 1990. Page 19 of the report refers to the Australian code of practice for the care and use of animals for scientific purposes. I place on the record that that particular Australian Agricultural Council meeting made recommendations as a result of recommendations that were made by the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare in its report on Animal Experimentation. In sections 13, 15 and 16 of that report, the Senate Select Committee recommended that all States and Territories upgrade animal welfare legislation and establish animal welfare advisory councils and departmental animal welfare units, as has been done in New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia. The Committee went on to recommend that the system of controlling animal experimentation in New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia be extended to other States and Territories. That system was to be based on upgraded legislation, incorporation of a code of practice into regulations, the accreditation and licensing of institutions in which animal experimentation was to be conducted, and the appointment of inspectors to monitor the work of ethics committees, animal house facilities, and practices in the conduct of animal experimentation.

That particular report caused quite a bit of comment among those learning facilities throughout Australia that use animals in experimentation. I am very pleased to see that the Australian Agricultural Council has recommended that those particular recommendations be taken up. The Australian Agricultural Council noted that its writing group, set up to revise the code of practice, had consulted with all State and Territory government departments responsible for the welfare of animals, and that nominees of the relevant Ministers in New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia had joined in with the writing group to assist with the revision.

It is very pleasing to see that the recommendations we made last year in our report have been taken up and that the relevant staff or Ministers from those particular States that we highlighted as being the three States that had shown the lead in this particular code of practice were imploring the other States to pick up the code of practice that we had recommended in our report. It is also interesting to note that the revised code had been considered by the sub-committee on animal welfare of the AAC's Animal Health Committee and was endorsed by the Standing Committee on Agriculture, the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. The result of that will be the publication of the code by the NHMRC. It was agreed that the code will be taken back to the Australian Agricultural Council for further consideration.
The Council raised another matter in its report. It referred to the Select Committee's report on Sheep Husbandry and stated:
The Select Committee's recommendations are generally moderate and most relate to research inputs which the Committee wishes to encourage.

It went on to note the recommendations of our Committee report on Sheep Husbandry and agreed that the progress by the Commonwealth, State and Territory governments towards implementation of the recommendations should be reported back to the next Council meeting.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is considering Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1989-90 and the motion moved by Senator Robert Ray that the report of Estimates Committee D be adopted. The Committee is considering the issues raised in relation to the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and, in particular, the questions that were taken on notice. When the debate was interrupted Senator Chapman was about to speak.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Chapman-Can I ask whether the Minister is coming? Mr Chairman, perhaps I should wait until the Minister arrives before I proceed, because I want to respond to some of the remarks that he made before the sitting was suspended.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Chairman. Before we adjourned the discussion on the immigration estimates prior to lunch the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) had responded to some of the questions and issues which I had raised following answers from the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs to my questions on notice.

SPEECH.PARA: He made the point that the long processing times to which I had referred with regard to Athens and Damascus were due to delays in the lodgment of further information requested by those stations. That, in turn, was also attributed to problems in the Gulf area. However, I remind the Minister that the applications which we are discussing relate to applications lodged by accredited agents. All of those applications ought to be complete-certainly, I would assume that most would be complete unless the accredited agents acting for intending migrants from those areas are very amateurish in fulfilling their responsibilities.

Therefore, I ask the Minister: In what respect are those applications incomplete? What percentage of applications at those two stations are being lodged incomplete? What is the average processing time to finalisation of those applications which are lodged in complete format?

The Minister mentioned that there was going to be an increase in personnel provided in Hong Kong to process applications. I think he mentioned that those increased resources would be in place by August or September. How many extra people will be devoted to processing business migration program applications in Hong Kong?

The Minister also attributed the increase in outstanding applications in Hong Kong now, compared with six months ago, to the fact that a number of them were what he described as stage 3 situations; that is, the applications had been approved but the visas had not yet been collected. Surely that situation would also have applied six months ago. Is the proportion of applications 37 per cent, or smaller or greater? Surely that, of itself, is not the reason for the increase in the number of outstanding applications now as against six months ago. I ask the Minister what percentage of the applications were at this stage 3 process six months ago, so we can get a real comparison of the actual increase in outstanding applications.

More generally, with regard to the continuation of long processing times, is the Minister aware that accredited agents have expressed their concern to me, certainly, that they believe that some posts are ignoring the role of accredited agents, as intended by this Government with regard to the processing of business migration program applications, and certainly appear to be processing these applications themselves in the way that they used to be processed under the pre-accredited agents. In effect, they are ignoring the role of accredited agents in dealing with applications. These agents believe this is a significant factor in continuing delays in the processing of applications.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Chapman were to look at the record from earlier today he would find, for instance, in respect of the first question he asked about Athens and the processing of forms there, that I indicated generally that one of the reasons was the fact that we are talking about applications from Gulf states being processed in Athens. There are difficulties because of that particular area and also because of the travel involved.

SPEECH.PARA: Without being able to give specific details to his specific questions, I ask Senator Chapman to take into account that the processing of forms and applications from the Gulf states is done by someone who goes down periodically to those states. Obviously, that would not be a daily or weekly event. It happens infrequently, I believe-at three monthly periods. Then there is the associated question of medical and security checks which also have to be done. When all those things are added together the scenario shows there are good reasons for longer time periods out of Athens.

In terms of Hong Kong and the number of extra staff there, I will go to the second part of the question first. In terms of stage 3 problems with applications I am informed that there has been a slight increase over the six month period. There were 495 outstanding applications six months ago and 647 outstanding now. That is just a slight increase in number. I also indicated earlier this afternoon that it was one of the factors and that the Department had reviewed the situation. I am informed, if I can read the writing, that there will be one A-based officer extra in Hong Kong and appropriate local staff will be employed as well.

Senator Chapman went on to ask about accredited agents being ignored. I think we should take into account the fact that even though agents are accredited, at some of the posts people can still make applications as individuals, and do so. That might be something which Senator Chapman is not taking into account. Probably the best way to approach the problem that Senator Chapman has with accredited agents claiming they are ignored is to bring those cases specifically to our notice and we will pursue them that way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have three matters remaining which relate to questions not answered at the time of the report. They are numbers 9, 22 and 7, and I will talk to them in that order.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, there is the question of Cambodian citizens in Thailand. For more than a decade there have been persons who have left the turmoil of Cambodia to go across the swamps in the border region at considerable danger to their lives from mines, one army or another, the swamps, civilian ambushes and thieves. Thousands of those persons are in camps which have become well known in this country, such as Khao I Dang and others along the border. Many honourable senators and members have visited one or other of the camps. I have made such a visit.

In recent weeks there has been a series of letters sent by the Australian Embassy in Bangkok to about 2,000 families in Australia who came from Cambodia, almost entirely, through the refugee program. They wish to sponsor persons in those camps to come to Australia. I raised questions about this quite large program that is now under way with regard to those 2,000 families. The letters came soon after the last general election during the month of April from Bangkok to very many Australian families that had formerly been living in Cambodia.

I thank the Minister and the Department for the careful supplementary answer that has been given to us. I note and endorse the distinction that is being made in the consideration for immigration purposes between a refugee application as one thing, and an application for immigration on ordinary grounds as another.

It would appear that there is a minority of persons in the camps who are last remaining relatives, spouses or dependent children and who would, on an ordinary application, wherever they lived in the world, be successful in being able to immigrate to Australia. It is commendable that there is now a concentration in the Department's program on the priority of those person actually joining their families in Australia in a way that does not offend the Thai Government. In particular, I want to ask about the happy conclusion that was set out in the further answer given to me yesterday, which is as follows:

The Thai authorities have indicated that in very strong compassionate circumstances they would permit, on a case by case basis, immediate family of Australian residents, such as spouses and dependent children, to be processed for settlement in Australia if the Australian Government were prepared to accept them under our normal migrant entry criteria.

My remaining few questions are: Have all of the letters that are to be sent under this new approach been sent to former applicants; are the 2,000 letters that have been sent all that will be sent; how many applicants have taken up the letter's suggestion that if there is a close family relationship they reapply; and is there any difficulty in the way these new applications are being processed?

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Teague would probably accept the sort of response I give. He seeks a lot of information which is not available to us. SPEECH.PARA: The difficulty I have is that the Government, just prior to an election, during February, gave an extra half a million dollars to a multi-million dollar program of grants-in-aid. Whilst the Minister sent letters to the recipients noting that they had been successful in receiving the grants in aid, this statement is in the paper I received yesterday:
All Government MPs with successful grants in their electorates were advised of the award of those grants.

Not one Opposition member was advised of these grants-in-aid going to their electorates. Yet, as one goes down the list of where the grants-in-aid were given, one notices quite a large number of electorates that were then represented by the Opposition. Happily, a lot more are now represented by Opposition members. Yet it is the policy of this Government to give selective information only to members of parliament who are from the Government side of the House. Of course, in the six weeks preceding an election those members can go around the community involved, `glad hand' them and put a great deal of emphasis on the way they have received this grant from the Government and on the fact that an extra half a million dollars has been given to the program.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The article read as follows-
ETHNIC LOBBY INFLUENCE STEERS MIGRATION POLICY
by Joanne Gray

Several ethnic leaders, together with senior officials in the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet, are exercising extraordinary power over the Government's Immigration policy, blurring the push for a stricter economic focus and forcing senior public servants to be dumped.

The influence of ethnic lobbyists derives from the perceptions held by the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and other senior members of the Australian Labor Party that the established ethnic communities in marginal Sydney and Melbourne electorates can make the difference between winning and losing an election.

Because of the perceived power of Lebanese community leaders in Sydney and the Jewish, Greek and Italian community leaders in Melbourne, they have had almost direct access to Mr Hawke and have been instrumental in wresting from the Government fundamental changes to immigration policy.

Through the Office of Multicultural Affairs and its head, Mr Peter Shergold, ethnic lobbying has been successful in persuading Mr Hawke to soften migration rules and dump the Immigration Department's secretary, Mr Ron Brown, and deputy secretary, Mr Tony Harris.

Mr Brown was replaced by Mr Chris Conybeare from the Prime Minister's department, and Mr Shergold has been mooted as the new deputy secretary. Mr Conybeare has been asked to ensure that the immigration department no longer pushes for the tough options.

The OMA has enormous power within the bureaucracy. It vets every Cabinet submission and has become a major voice in migration policy formulation. Just weeks away from the announcement of the 1990-91 immigration intake, there is persistent speculation that the push for a lower migrant intake will force a cut to the skilled category.

The Department of Immigration is understood to be in disarray after the removal of its two most senior officials. Two key elements of immigration policy-that the people selected are useful to Australia and that the department is in control of the programme-are at the brink of failure.
Department officials feel that the economic rigour that the department tried to introduce to policy following the FitzGerald report's recommendations is being progressively undermined.
There is also speculation that the next phase of changes to migration rules will restore some elements of ministerial discretion to interfere in immigration cases, removed last year.

While Mr Hawke has a long association with ethnic leaders and sympathy with multiculturalism, several senior public servants believe he and Mr Hand are hypersensitive to concerns raised by the ethnic communities and have jeopardised the careers of public servants.

The most influential ethnic leaders include Mr Eddie Obeid, of the Lebanese community, Mr Nino Randazzo, editor of the Italian weekly Il Globo, and Mr Walter Lippmann, deputy president of the Jewish Board of Deputies. Mr Lippmann is treasurer of the Victorian Federation of Ethnic Communities Council and an old friend of Mr Hawke.

Although former Immigration Department secretary, Mr Ron Brown, was handpicked three years ago by the Prime Minister, it is understood that Mr Brown and former deputy secretary Mr Tony Harris were forced to leave the department at the behest of ethnic leaders.
The ethnic lobby has apparently succeeded in halting the push for a sharper economic focus to migrant policy advocated in the FitzGerald report.

It has ensured that the family migration programme remains the keystone of policy and that family reunion applicants no longer receive points for English skills, despite official reports which estimate that English language difficulties cost the economy $3.2 billion a year.

It has argued for even higher family migration, more liberal rules and rights of review for illegals, and restoration of grants to the more established ethnic communities rather than to those who have most recently arrived in Australia.

The first move of the new Minister for Immigration, Mr Gerry Hand, on taking over the portfolio was to signal a relaxation of immigration rules in response to solid lobbying by ethnic representatives.
The regulations were intended to make administration easier and more transparent and were originally expected to receive ethnic support.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Committee. I note the answer to the first question, which relates to why Mr Ron Brown is no longer Secretary to the Department. The words refer to his decision to leave the position in order to make a career change away from the Public Service.

I note that I asked a similar question with regard to Mr Tony Harris, the Deputy Secretary. I asked:

The answer is very brief and does not give an answer to my question. In a line and half it stated:

Department officials feel that the economic rigour that the department tried to introduce to policy following the FitzGerald report's recommendations is being progressively undermined.

While the Prime Minister has a long association with ethnic leaders and sympathy with multiculturalism, several senior public servants believe he and Mr Hand are hypersensitive to concerns raised by the ethnic communities and have jeopardised the careers of public servants.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that during the Estimates Committee hearing Senator Hill asked a question of the Trade Practices Commission about the fees paid on a per diem basis to counsel in the Arnotts matter. I know that the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) is aware of this matter, but perhaps for people who may suffer from insomnia and occasionally read Hansard I should put it into perspective. There was some reluctance at the Estimates Committee for Senator Hill to be provided with an answer. Originally, he was referred to the Attorney-General's annual report and advised that that report has for some years clearly indicated the fees paid in total to various counsel.

SPEECH.PARA: He was also, quite properly, advised by the Minister that those fees might cover a number of matters in which that particular counsel may have appeared for or on behalf of the Commonwealth or a statutory authority. Consequently, it was not possible, if one knew the length of time that particular matters had run for, to necessarily work out who got paid what for which days. When this matter was pursued there was some reluctance on the part of the Minister and the officers present to indicate exactly how much counsel was paid on a daily rate.

The Committee moved off that matter with undertakings being given by the Minister to investigate it, but came back to the matter as a consequence of a resolution of the Senate to be found in the Standing Orders. At the end of the Standing Orders there is a list of resolutions and orders of the Senate that have continuing effect, and on page 123 under `Statutory Bodies-Accountability' the third resolution of the Senate is there referred to. It states:
That the committee . . .
recommends . . .

(i) that the principle, espoused by the Senate in 1971 and 1974, that there are no areas of expenditure of public funds where Statutory Authorities have a discretion to withhold details or explanations from Parliament or its Committees unless the Parliament has expressly provided otherwise, be re-affirmed;

(ii) the affirmation, in accordance with this principle that the right to privacy of individual counsel accepting a brief on behalf of the Commonwealth for which money is appropriated by Parliament is supervened by such acceptance-
and adds-
subject to the reasons for the information being clearly defined and to the proviso that injudicious or unwarranted invasion of privacy is not the intention of the Parliament or its Committees.

What that boils down to is a statement of two things: firstly, that it is reaffirmed by the Senate that there are no areas into which the Senate cannot inquire in relation to expenditure. It is taxpayers' money that is being spent and the taxpayer is entitled to know how it is spent. It goes on in the second part to say that yes, counsel do have some sort of right to privacy, as for that matter, I suppose, any other commercial contractor does, and points out that counsel, by accepting a brief from the Commonwealth knowing that the taxpayer is paying his or her bill, waives that right to privacy. That is really what that second paragraph says.

It adds that the reasons for the information will be clearly defined and that there will be no injudicious or unwarranted invasion of anybody's privacy. That need not have been added because Estimates committees are not there for the purpose of members carrying on some invasive inquest into the privacy of individuals; they are there for senators to inquire into expenditure allocated by the Commonwealth-for example, whether departments can tell us how many consultants have been used, who those consultants were and how much they have been paid. The reason someone asks that is in order to ascertain whether a department is judiciously expending its wealth in the form of taxpayers' money on consultants. Someone may ask, `How much are you spending on outside counsel?', and that would be a reason for seeking the information.

This information was provided with some reluctance, and I have some questions on the general matter of providing information in respect of counsel's fees and some specific questions. I deal with the specific questions first. I understand from the answer-and the Minister's answer has been tabled by the Chairman of the Estimates Committee, Senator Colston-that, in the particular matter referred to, counsel was paid a total of $457,723.80 over a reasonably extended period. Is that simply counsel's fees? I ask that because the question was asked originally, `How much is counsel paid per day as a fee?'. Are there additional costs-for example, additional preparation and reading costs-or any other costs on top of a per diem rate for appearing?

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)
