In providing this information to the Committee I would stress the commercial and confidential nature of the information.

I understand the commercial nature of the information. Quite clearly it is a case of, `You do this job for me, I give you this much money'. It is exactly the same as what a bricklayer says when he does a job for someone. It is exactly the same as what consultants say when they offer to do a job for the Commonwealth. It is a commercial enterprise entered into with the Commonwealth. I am at a loss to understand the confidential nature of that information.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —If honourable senators look through the Hansard they will find that Senator Vanstone actually agreed that there was a parallel, an analogous case, with those who contract with the Commonwealth. It is a question of competition and tendering between persons seeking to undertake business, in this case the provision of legal advice or counsel services, or whatever it might be. In that situation what the Parliament has hitherto taken to be a sufficient indication of the expenditure by the Commonwealth is the listing in the back of the annual report of many hundreds of solicitors and barristers and the aggregate of the monies that they have received.

SPEECH.PARA: I have indicated that I am prepared to make available, if a senator thinks it necessary, the per diem rate. It is, I suspect, going to create some problems if those who are approached by the Commonwealth, say, the Trade Practices Commission, to appear in a matter, say, in Sydney, know exactly what the daily rate was that was agreed to by another counsel. It will make the task of the Trade Practices Commission in seeking to get the best value for the dollar out of counsel in Sydney that much harder. They will know roughly what the per day rate is. I do not put a lot of emphasis on this because anyone who gets the aggregate sums in the back of the annual report and knows how many days a counsel appeared in court would be able to work it out pretty roughly anyway.

I emphasise that I have been happy to respond to the request for specific information. I have accepted in a sense that the mere fact that Senator Vanstone indicated that she wanted the information, even in terms of the resolution of 1980, is itself sufficient reason. She did not actually go much further than saying that she thought it was important in order for the principle to be vindicated. What Senator Vanstone has been about-I do not say improperly-is vindicating the principle rather than wanting to know in this particular instance precisely how much was paid in relation to the appearance by senior counsel in the Arnotts case. That principle has been vindicated. I believe that honour is satisfied.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to intervene for one moment to say something in relation to the whole of Group E and to make a point to the Minister. I thank Senator Vanstone for allowing me to interrupt. In this group we have the Attorney-General's Department, which is currently being proceeded with. We also have the Department of Transport and Communications.
—And Aboriginal Affairs.

—Yes. In relation to the Department of Transport and Communications, I want to make a point to the Minister so he can take it up with his colleagues. A list of unanswered questions has been circulated. It is our understanding that these had to be cleared by both Mr Beazley and Senator Collins. The answers to a lot of these questions are currently with Senator Collins or in Senator Collins's office. Senator Collins has to clear them. He is apparently on his way to Perth, or somewhere. As a result, the questions have apparently not been cleared.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make it clear to the Minister that if the questions which are currently with Senator Collins have not been cleared and made available by the time we resume later this evening we will not be prepared to proceed with the Department of Transport and Communications. That will result in a deferral. Therefore, if there is any way in which matters which are currently in Senator Collins's office can be expedited that will be helpful to the Committee. I wanted to let the Minister know before the dinner break that that is the problem likely to be faced later this evening.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will turn back to the Attorney-General's Department. We are still on the daily rate charged by legal counsel.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for his answer. I am sure that the taxpayers will sleep more comfortably tonight knowing that the Attorney-General's Department is not of the view that it is in a position to be able to negotiate with counsel and keep those matters confidential to itself. I am pleased with that. I understood the commercial nature of the deal and that there are parallels with lots of other people doing these deals. I understand the need for confidentiality until a deal is struck. That is the same with the tendering process for bricklaying, or whatever. But once the deal is struck the nature of the confidentiality is lost on me. As I understood the Minister's answer it basically comes down to the fact that if the matter is revealed it is difficult for the Trade Practices Commission to get the best deal because everyone knows what everyone else accepts. Is that basically the thrust of it?
—Yes, more or less.

—I express some surprise that every other department manages to do deals and get the best arrangements under that system. I would not have thought that the Attorney-General's Department should find it any more difficult.

SPEECH.PARA: I have an additional question. In the Estimates, as I understood it, some of the Minister's remarks indicated that while the view that I was putting might be the case for the future, and I am pleased we have accepted that it is, for the past that may not be the case because a number of agreements have been entered into `on the basis of an expectation of confidentiality'.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —What I have incorporated indicates that I am prepared to reveal the per diem rate in relation to past events. I have already answered that by incorporating a document.

—Do I understand that if one were to-I am not saying I am-ask for a per diem rate per counsel per matter back until the beginning of this financial year there would be no contracts for which the Minister would have to come back and say, `I am sorry, we entered into a contract with a confidentiality clause in it'? Is that the case? Is that what the Minister is saying? If I were to ask that question would the Minister be happy to provide the answer, because I am happy to put it to the test? It ought not need to be but I am happy to put it to the test if the Minister cannot give me that undertaking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have indicated that in relation to past arrangements with counsel or solicitors I am prepared to reveal the per diem rate. I do not understand there to be any confidentiality clause. That was my only hesitation. I think it is just an understanding that has developed over the years. I do not take into account any particular clause in relation to a contractual arrangement or anything like that. I have indicated that the Committee is entitled to the information in accordance with the resolution of 1980.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Committee is considering Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and the motion moved by Senator Bolkus that the report of Estimates Committee E be adopted. The Committee is considering the issues raised in relation to the Attorney-General's Department. Is there any further discussion on the question of the daily rate charged by legal counsel?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to Senator Vanstone, the Trade Practices Commission has advised that senior counsel are paid only normal disbursements in addition to the daily fee rate.
—Senator Durack, do you wish to speak on the daily rate charged by legal counsel?

—I first read of this matter in the Hansard report of Estimates Committee E and I was listening to this lengthy debate just before dinner. I did not intend to speak on this but I thought it might be of some interest for the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) to know that I have been in exactly the same position as he is in and the person who tormented me on this subject was his esteemed colleague Senator Evans.
—Yes, he is haunting us all the time.

—He certainly is. Although I had made the same offer to him as the Minister has made, he insisted on having these details provided which we then proceeded to do for the rest of the time that I was Attorney-General. In fact, I think the motion was passed in 1980 just to put it on the record. So I must say that I was a little surprised that the Department had reverted to the bad habits that it had back in the 1970s.

—If there is no further discussion on the daily rate charged by legal counsel, the third matter to which the Committee drew the attention of the Committee of the Whole was the cost of aborting the Yooyen trial. The next question is the Auditor-General's report No. 31, to which there is a reservation by Senator Michael Baume. There are no unanswered questions relating to the Attorney-General's Department, so that completes consideration of that department. We will turn now to the Department of Transport and Communications. The first matter is the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. Senator Walters has a reservation about questions taken on notice.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I am just seeking advice. I understood from a short conversation with one of the Clerks assisting you that some answers had been provided and were now being duplicated. I know that this does create a problem.
—I understand that they are being photocopied now. Nevertheless, the matters are listed for discussion and they are eligible for discussion. If Senator Walters wishes to speak to them, well and good.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Chairman. I have received the answers, or a list, from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation to the questions that I had asked. I will put the matter into context. I had a discussion with Mr David Hill on 10 April. On that date I asked him whether I would see him at the Estimates Committee. He said to me, `Yes, Senator, that is right'. Because he was well aware that I wanted to ask him questions, I did not ask the secretary of the Committee to see that he was present. Mr Hill was not present. As a result, the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Colston, and the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, Senator Collins, both gave permission for me to ask a question of the ABC. We were told that the ABC did not have an appropriation and that that was why Mr Hill was not present. This was although, as I have said, he was aware that I had asked him to be there. I am waiting on the photostat; I do not know whether the Minister has got the answer.
—The Parliamentary Secretary is now open to questions.
—So the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) has the answer to that question. I will go on and come to that later. Under `Answers' the ABC has written:

SPEECH.PARA: The raising of this ABC programming matter in the context of the Senate Estimates Committee Hearing is of some concern, as the questions do not relate in any way to Estimate matters.

I believe that, if the Minister in charge of the Estimates, Senator Collins, the Chairman of the Estimates Committee, Senator Colston and the Estimates Committee as a whole decided that it was proper for me to raise these questions, the Chairman of the ABC, the Managing Director or whoever it was-because these answers are not signed-has no right at all to express concern that these questions were raised. The Minister, Senator Collins, at that Estimates Committee said:
These questions are not strictly relevant to the appropriations. I am anxious to accommodate Senator Walters.

And he allowed me to put these questions on notice. What right indeed has Mr Hill to say that the ABC expresses concern. I believe it is a direct insult to the Minister who is in charge of the Estimates, to the Chairman of the Estimates Committee and to the Estimates Committee itself. I would like to express my deepest concern that Mr David Hill chose to express his concern that I should be allowed to ask these questions. I asked for the number of complaints there had been to the showing of the Riddle of the Dead Sea Scrolls on Palm Sunday. On 10 April I had asked Mr Hill for that figure, and he knew I was going to ask that question at the Estimates Committee. He has said to me in answer:
Below is information readily available given the time-frame the ABC has had to respond, and our resources.
He had that request on 10 April and today is 24 May. However, he said:
Detail of written complaints-
That was not the question I asked; I said complaints generally-
addressed to the Managing Director is as follows . . .
There is no answer to my question at all. He said:
Total number of complaints concerning the showing (content) of the program-112-
written to him-
Total number of complaints concerning the screening of the program on Palm Sunday-71-
written to him. There is an asterisk which points out that there were multiple signatories to some of those. He did not say how many signatories.

TALK.START.PARA: —For written complaints you multiply it by one thousand.
—That is the estimate, I know, of the editor of the Mercury in Hobart. I do not know whether the ABC takes that approach. He then went on:

SPEECH.PARA: Details of capital city switchboard complaints will be made available when this information is collated on an Australia-wide basis.

Mr Hill has told me-and the answer is here-that the capital city switchboard complaints will be made available to me when they are collated. I think this is a complete disregard for the Estimates system, a complete disregard by Mr Hill of this Parliament. The Estimates asked for the number, and he would be able to give me the number of capital city complaints to the switchboard by a phone call to each of the capital cities. Mr Hill chose not to do that, knowing the questions I had asked on 10 April. He continued:
The number of calls to various regional ABC offices are not known.

He has not told me that he will seek out those numbers. He has merely said that they are not known. When I was speaking to Mr Hill and I asked him for the numbers, he said that there were 72 regional ABC stations in Australia and that it would be a waste of taxpayers' money for him to ring around and get the numbers from each of those centres.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are supposed to collate those as a matter of course.

—I will come to that matter in a minute. But when I spoke to Mr Hill he said that it would be a waste of taxpayers' money for him to ring around the 72 regions in order to assess what the numbers were. He said that he had no idea as to the number of complaints or requests the ABC had received that the program not been shown on Palm Sunday. I told Mr Hill that I had no idea that the Managing Director of the ABC had to do that to assess the number of complaints that it received and it surprised me that the ABC ran its business that way.

SPEECH.PARA: The question I asked in the Estimates Committee hearing was: How did the ABC assess and give those figures? Mr Hill said that there is a regular reporting system to the Managing Director in the form of correspondence and switchboard reports. That is not what he told me on the telephone. He said that he would have to ring around personally in order to assess those numbers. I ask the Parliamentary Secretary, who is at the table, whether he could tell me how regular the reporting system to the Managing Director is, and whether the Managing Director had been informed of any requests and complaints on the occasion of the screening of The Riddle of the Dead Sea Scrolls program on Palm Sunday.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make two general comments and then respond to the specific points raised by Senator Walters. In the formal sense, the answer to which Senator Walters is referring is not an answer from Mr Hill; it is an answer from the Minister. So the expression of concern that Senator Walters refers to is not an expression of concern by Mr Hill but an expression of concern by the Minister. I also make the general comment in discussing this matter that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation--
—The Minister said it was perfectly all right.
—I am simply saying that this is the formal situation.
—Okay. I will wait until you have finished.

—Those are exactly the words that I used before and I use them again. I also reiterate the Government's support for the independence of the ABC's programming. I do not know-and nobody who is available here knows-how regular the reporting system to the Managing Director is. I am happy to find out but I do not know and cannot find out that information immediately. Therefore, I also do not know whether such a report regarding this matter had flowed to the Managing Director as a matter of course. I am also happy to try to find that out, notwithstanding that there are no estimates concerning this matter, but I cannot do it here and now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find this situation extraordinary. I made a particular reservation in regard to these questions, yet the Department of Transport and Communications has not seen fit to send anyone along tonight who could answer these questions. I find it quite extraordinary. I asked the very simple question as to how the Australian Broadcasting Corporation gets across to the Managing Director the feelings of the public whose money is being used to run the ABC. I have requested the information and I have not been given the courtesy of having someone here who can answer the questions I am putting.

SPEECH.PARA: As you know, Mr Chairman, I have very strong feelings about this new system. It seemed to me that under this new system if I made a reservation, then to speed things up the Government would take note of that reservation and have the appropriate people here so that I could ask questions and have answers. If the Government wants this new system to work, then I suggest that it overcome the problems that we have been facing ever since this new system began this time.

For the Parliamentary Secretary (Senator McMullan) to say that to the Treasurer the Minister is expressing concern is quite ridiculous, since I read from Hansard that the Minister has no concern at all. Let me quote it again for the Parliamentary Secretary so that there is no misunderstanding:
These questions are not strictly relevant to the appropriations, but I am anxious to accommodate Senator Walters.

The Parliamentary Secretary tells me that the Minister now is expressing concern. If the Minister were here-and we are well aware that he has unavoidably had to leave the Parliament-then I am quite sure he would not be saying that he had concern.

TALK.START.PARA: —I bet the Minister does not defend the Australia Council and take responsibility for its comments in quite the same way when we come to that.

—I take on board Senator Puplick's comments. I ask the Parliamentary Secretary: Because of the comments of Senator Tate that there are some additional answers being typed up, has either of them now received the answer that was to come to me on the details of the capital city switchboard complaints? I find that I am certainly of the feeling that Mr Hill is deliberately frustrating the questions I asked. I said earlier that he could have got his staff, if the information had not come directly to him, to make a simple call to the six capital cities and be given the information.

SPEECH.PARA: When I spoke to Senator Collins and said, `I feel I am being slighted by the Managing Director in this regard', Senator Collins assured me that he had asked for the answers to be available before this sitting of Estimates Committee E. I ask the Parliamentary Secretary: Have those figures now been forwarded to us as directed by the Minister?

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call anyone else, I should make it clear on this question of relevance that whether or not-and I express no opinion on this-Senator Walters's questions were relevant to the Estimates Committee, having been made the subject of a reservation, they are relevant to this Committee and so they are in order.

—I was not, of course, challenging whether or not they were in order. There is no further answer to this question. There was an answer provided to this. This was not one of what we considered to be the outstanding bodies of questions because an answer had been provided. It may be an answer that is considered unsatisfactory at this stage by the recipient, but there is an answer. To those matters which are on notice and to which answers have previously not been provided, there will be answers but they will not include subsequent information on this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not unsatisfactory just to me; it is a question that has not been answered. Perhaps the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer would like me to read it again so he can understand that it has not been answered. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Details of capital city switchboard complaints will be made available when this information is collated on an Australia-wide basis.
The Minister assured me that he had asked the ABC to have those figures available before we sat. Is the Parliamentary Secretary telling me that those figures are not available? Is that correct?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—So the ABC has defied the Minister. There are a couple more questions. I do not know how the Committee feels about this but I will come to it in a minute. I asked how the Managing Director is made aware of complaints when the community is showing concern. The ABC has told me that I have to wait for even the capital city figures. It says that the number of calls to various regional ABC offices are not known. I then asked how the Managing Director is made aware of complaints. I was told that the Managing Director is made aware of complaints on a daily basis, where necessary. Can the Parliamentary Secretary tell me who makes the decision as to what is necessary? On this occasion who made the decision that it was unnecessary to inform the Managing Director that complaints had been made about The Riddle of the Dead Sea Scrolls being put to air on the first day of Holy Week?
—No, I cannot.

—Even as a direct request of mine no-one has been sent who can help. Mr Chairman, there is hardly any point in my going on, although I do have more. Perhaps we should report progress. Mr Chairman, can you advise me on the best way to handle this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the determination of the question for the adoption of the report of Estimates Committee E be postponed till after the further consideration of the votes in Group D.

I believe that the only way to deal with this is to take the precedent set earlier this evening with Senator Teague's matter; that is, the matters relating to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC), which are contained in the reservation made by Senator Walters to the report of Estimates Committee E, should be deferred until after we have concluded the matters of Estimates Committee C, which is the last one on the agenda, and Senator Teague's subsequent matter with the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs.

I draw the attention of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer to the fact that the new procedure introduced after the resolution of 5 December last stated very specifically that, in order to facilitate the debate of Estimates committees, only matters which were the subject of particular reference or particular reservation in the report should be addressed. The fact that the Committee, either by reference of a matter or by the attachment of a reservation, has sought to put the Government on notice that this is a matter requiring attention during the debate of the Committee of the Whole surely imposes upon the Executive the responsibility to ensure that the answers for the particular matter are available. Senator Walters's reservation, which appears in the report, states:
I recommend the following matters relating to the estimates of expenditure referred to the Committee be further examined by the Senate:
In relation to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, the questions which were not answered at the hearing of the Committee on 15 May 1990, but which were taken on notice-
and these are the operative words-
with an undertaking by Senator Collins, the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, that answers would be provided . . .

It is quite clear that the answers to the specific matters have not been provided. Saying `We do not know' or `We will get you the information in due course' is not a satisfactory answer. The Parliamentary Secretary knows full well that if the additional estimates which relate to the ABC or this Department are passed tonight, then the chances of getting the Department back for proper answer and proper consideration next week are virtually zero. The ultimate power-in the final analysis, the only power-that this chamber has is not to pass appropriations, not to give the Government its money, if the Senate is not satisfied that certain things have been done. At the end of the day that is the only ultimate power this chamber possesses: the power not to grant the Government the money it says it requires for a particular undertaking.

Mr Chairman, I suggest that in relation to the matter of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, which is the subject of the reservation entered by Senator Walters in relation to Estimates Committee E, in the absence of satisfactory answers to those questions we should defer dealing with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation part of Estimates Committee E and, therefore, the final resolution of the motion to approve the expenditures referred to in Estimates Committee E until after we have dealt with Estimates Committee C later tonight, or whenever we get around to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it would be neater if it was dealt with after Estimates Committee D. Senator Teague has one outstanding matter for that Committee and Estimates Committee D has been deferred for that reason.

—I think that is absolutely correct. We should deal with the balance of what is in Estimates Committee E, then, hopefully, deal with Estimates Committee F, then Estimates Committee C, then with the one outstanding matter in Estimates Committee D, and then with the one-I hope it is only one-outstanding matter in Estimates Committee C.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will address that matter. We do not have a situation where a question about which a reservation has been made has not been answered. The only outstanding matter from the reservation is the question of the details of capital city switchboard complaints. Everything else that was part of the original question about which the reservation was made has been answered. It is true that more questions have been asked tonight that were not part of the reservation, about which concern is now being expressed. But this was not perceived as a matter that had not been answered.

SPEECH.PARA: A quite comprehensive and detailed answer was given on all the information that was available and, it seems to me, quite promptly. We do not have a situation where a reservation was made and no action has followed. A reservation was made, an answer was provided accordingly, and we are now finding tonight that someone wants to say, `But there is an extra question I wish I had asked and about which I would have made a reservation had I known the answer to the first question and therefore I want to make a retrospective reservation'.

I was not present, but it appears from the written record in front of me-as far as I can tell it is comprehensive; if someone can point out that something is missing I am happy to listen to it-the only matter about which a detailed answer has not been given is the details of capital city switchboard complaints. That was not specifically in the question, but quite clearly the question states `number of concerns'. So that is properly a part of it. Everything else has been answered in writing, and not tonight but previously-yesterday, as far as I know. The only reason we have concern is that now, as a result of the answers, subsequent questions are being asked to which we are happy to provide answers, but they cannot be provided now.

It is not a situation in which the reservation has not been addressed at all. Therefore, while it is proper to protect the Committee's right to have reservations dealt with and to have these new procedures properly adhered to, in this circumstance they have been. It is not appropriate to proceed with the motion-even though it is one in which there are circumstances where I could envisage it would be appropriate. I do not believe these are such circumstances. I therefore urge Senator Puplick not to proceed with the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) has already said that there is at least one question unanswered. That question refers to the capital cities. I have told the Parliamentary Secretary that the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) requested that that be answered prior to the sitting of this Committee of the Whole. I draw the attention of the Parliamentary Secretary to the fact that when I asked how many similar requests had been made to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC), I was told that I could get a part answer to that eventually, at some future time; so it is not answering my question at all. I have been told that the number of calls to various regional ABC stations is not known. However, I am told in answer to another question that the Managing Director of the ABC gets regular, daily reports when it is considered necessary. I am sure that the Parliamentary Secretary understands that my request for the number of reports of complaints has not been answered, although it could have been.

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite ridiculous to tell me that the regional numbers are not known. I am told that regular reporting takes place and that the Managing Director gets regular reports on a daily basis when necessary; yet the number is still being denied to me. Therefore, I believe that I have not been given the answer. The Minister informed me that he had requested that the answer be made before we sat on this particular item. So I believe we ought to report progress.

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion is not to report progress; it is to defer consideration of this issue until after consideration of Estimates Committees D and E.

—Just in case the motion happens to be passed, I would like to make a short statement in relation to something that was mentioned earlier because I would like my comments to be in the same part of Hansard as this debate. Earlier, Senator Walters mentioned that a remark made by David Hill was an insult to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins), to the Chairman of the Committee, and to the Committee itself. I cannot speak for the Committee or for the Minister, but I would like to have it placed on record that I do not feel insulted at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is important that, if any honourable senator considers that his or her question has not been answered by a statutory authority or a government department, the Committee should go on to the next estimates, so that time can be given for appropriate answers to be provided. I recall what Senator Puplick said in his motion, that at the end of the day the only thing that is available to us is to hold up or vote against Supply. There is another matter that the Committee should consider when the time comes. I can well recall that from time to time Estimates committees have been frustrated by the replies that have been given by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC).

SPEECH.PARA: Quite rightly, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer indicates that it is not the Government's intention to dictate to the ABC what its programs ought or ought not to be. That is one thing. The ABC seems to be carried away with the idea that it is a law unto itself, answerable to absolutely no-one. It seems to me quite extraordinary that, if it felt it was answerable to the public, it should not have readily available overnight the answer to the question posed by Senator Walters.

All that that question seeks to elicit is the number of complaints received in the ABC's offices concerning a particular program. If the ABC is going to be in some way responsive to the people who pay its bread and butter-who pay their money to it-that information should have been available immediately to the Chairman of the ABC and he should then have been able to respond to the question asked by Senator Walters.

I think I proposed to a broadcasting Bill at one particular stage an amendment that would have established a watchdog over the ABC, an independent authority that would have been able to receive this sort of complaint from the public, rather than the situation as now, where a television viewer or a radio listener who is concerned about a particular program is required to complain-where to? To the ABC. It is appealing from Caesar to Caesar. The ABC sets up a committee to consider these complaints, and that is where they live or die.

If it is good enough for the commercial television stations to have a system whereby the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, to a certain extent, is the institution with which complaints can be lodged by viewers or listeners, then why not for the ABC?

I simply take this opportunity of reminding honourable senators that Estimates committees have previously been frustrated by the ABC. I believe this Committee is entitled now to defer consideration of this estimate until such time as it receives the answer to the question raised by Senator Walters, given your ruling, Mr Chairman, that, despite what may or may not have occurred in the Estimates Committee, nonetheless, because of the reservation that has been made, this matter is properly before this Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I urge the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer to agree to a deferral of the question raised simply because I think we could then move on quickly to the other items.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The next matter on the list is the reservation by Senator Panizza.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer for any further explanation of the $960,000 relating to a claim by the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) for unpaid accounts following the transfer of Sydney Airport. It seems to me from the bit of information I got out of the Estimates Committee that this $960,000 was left over from the transfer of the Sydney Airport. One would have thought that with the transfer of property of such a size, everything would be cleaned up in one sweep before any settling was done.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Chairman, you know that in the transfer of any property all searches should be done of what is owing, what is credited and all that sort of thing before the transfer goes ahead. Yet here is an account-I do not know quite how far back it goes-for $960,000. If the claim was known, it should have been in the estimates last spring session. Could I have an answer please?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Panizza. The provision of $960,000 relates to accounts which were paid by the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) following the transfer of airports on 1 January 1988 for goods and services which overlapped or which were billed for after the formal transfer date. In the first instance, liability for these accounts was disputed by the Department's New South Wales regional office as there were legal problems in establishing the proper liability for the accounts. It would not have been appropriate to have made provision in the principal estimates because there had been no agreement. Liability had not been accepted.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue was eventually referred to the Department's central office for resolution. There were negotiations with the FAC. It looked like it was getting to the point where liability might have been denied totally by the Department, but that would have led to continuing contest. There was sufficient ground to support the FAC's view that the Department should accept responsibility for some of the accounts, and agreement was eventually reached for payment to the FAC of $632,741 to cover those accounts which were the responsibility of the Department. That is how it came about. We could not do it in the estimates at Budget time because at that stage liability had not been accepted. It is accepted now. Agreement has been reached. The appropriate amount has therefore been transferred and the Department has paid.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McMullan mentioned a figure of $650,000-odd. Could he explain where the rest came from? He could not make an allowance for it in the last estimates, as liability was still in question, but why was there no notation saying that there could be a contingent liability? If a note was made in these estimates of why the figure was there at all, I might not have been asking this question.

—I am reliably assured that the statement in the explanatory notes makes the situation clear. The amount of $960,000 arises from the transfer of $800,000 of salaries funds to administrative expenses. Senator Panizza would appreciate that we normally get that 1.2 rate-that leads to the $960,000 figure-but it was not all required to meet the amount in challenge by the FAC. Again, the amount eventually, to be precise, was $632,741.
—In other words, it was disputed.
—Yes.

—I move on to the next matter, which is on page 28-a rental adjustment for tax years 1982 to 1986 at the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's former Northern Sydney premises at 153 Walker Street as per advice from the Department of Administrative Services of $198,000. I think that is the figure I queried. Once again, could I have an explanation as to why those amounts have been hanging around for six years? I presume that that rental property was on a lease with certain conditions about renewal, what would be done about the new rent and how it would be set, whether by arbitration or by agreement. Could the Minister please explain? Once again it seems to be sloppy bookwork to me that that figure was hanging around considering that it goes back to 1982. Senator McMullan could probably blame the Fraser Government.

—The honourable senator is right that the property was leased, but it was not leased by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal; it was leased by the Department of Administrative Services to a number of Commonwealth agencies and over those years the ABT used differing amounts as different instrumentalities occupied the space.
—This is in Walker Street?

—In Walker Street, yes. The ABT was aware that an adjustment was outstanding, but at the time of the budget did not know the exact amount. It was informed by the Department of Administrative Services of the amount on 30 August 1989 and, therefore, a supplementary appropriation was made on this occasion to meet the detail that was provided by the Department of Administrative Services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I presume then that that was an internal argument between the lessees of the building. Is that correct?
—I prefer to call it an internal discussion.
—It is an internal discussion of who occupied the premises. The parties settled on a cost of $198,000. Once again, it is not explained too well.
—Sloppy management.
—I believe that is sloppy management.
—By the ABT.

—I do not know who it was. Once again we could have had an explanation of why it came about. It seems unbelievable that an amount of that dimension-$198,000-was let go for that long without coming to a head.

SPEECH.PARA: I will move on to the next matter, an amount of $885,000 for a residual claim from Telecom Australia relating to the national broadcasting services. At least that cost was incurred from the previous year, 1988-89, but was not claimed until recently. I ask: Why was there no notation in the previous Estimates in the spring session? The responsible Minister must have known that it was there. If the Minister did not know the total amount, why was a notation not made?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the honourable senator is saying that there should have been a notation in the Budget Estimates to the effect that a further unspecified amount was outstanding, then I think that might be a point that needs to be looked at in future in the presentation. I have not thought that through, but on the face of it it seems to have some merit. I will ask the Department to look at that matter.

SPEECH.PARA: If the honourable senator wants me to explain the circumstances on this occasion I will do so. As I understand it, it arises each year because of the nature of the relationship between the Telecom broadcasting directorate and the Department. It operates and maintains Commonwealth transmitting stations on behalf of the Department and the size of the program is such that it cannot be finally reconciled until after the close of the financial year, so there is always a little left over. That is why it occurs. It is not a special circumstance, but I think there is some merit in the honourable senator's general point about advising people in what would be, in a private enterprise sense, a note to the accounts. That is a matter I will draw to the attention of the Minister. There may be a reason why it cannot be done, but if it can be done, I will make sure that it is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator McMullan for the answer; it is the answer I wanted. If it is occurring annually, firstly, the knowledge is there and, secondly, there must be a good estimation that it is there, and an estimation can then be provided in the Budget session. I thank Senator McMullan for his promise, and I presume that it was a promise, that he will be looking at it to improve his bookkeeping for next year.

SPEECH.PARA: I move on to the next area on page 36 of the explanatory notes-the $75m Telecom is to pay to Aussat Pty Ltd as equity capital. TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding is that, in effect, Telecom is being given the option of putting up $25m or diluting its ownership of AUSSAT. At this stage, no final decision has been made as to what it will do.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Dear

I refer to your personal representation of 21 February 1990, to the New South Wales State Minister for Health concerning the waiting time for surgery at the Repatriation General Hospital (RGH), Concord. Your letter was referred to me for reply as the matter you raised comes within my portfolio responsibility.
I understand the surgeon examined the veteran at RGH Concord and recommended his admission for surgery on the right knee.

He performs one major and one minor surgical case each week at the hospital. He also usually performs one procedure per week at Departmental expense at a private hospital. As at 17 April 1990, he had 85 patients on his waiting list, 30 of whom had the same or a higher priority for admission than him. As a result he could not be guaranteed admission as a patient until November 1990. That is a waiting time of 30 weeks, which is more than the average waiting time for orthopaedic surgery.

As part of the hospital's strategy towards waiting list management, patients on waiting list were invited to transfer to the care of alternative orthopaedic specialists whose waiting times were significantly less. This proved quite successful as one third of his patients have accepted the offer.

On learning of case, the hospital contacted him and gave him the opportunity to have his condition treated by an orthopaedic specialist other than . . . I understand he has accepted this offer and arrangements were made for him to be reviewed by a Staff Specialist whose waiting time is seven weeks. A tentative admission date of 12 June 1990 has also been set with surgery planned for 14 June 1990.

I should point out that with the recent opening of the new operating theatres, RGH Concord will have ten operating theatres, with one dedicated to orthopaedic surgery for five days each week. It is anticipated that the current average waiting time for orthopaedic surgery of 19 weeks will be reduced.
I am pleased to have been of assistance.
Yours sincerely
BEN HUMPHREYS

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to take the matter further here. I just want to place on record the fact that officers have gone to some trouble to try to deal courteously with this problem, and I would like that to be known. I do not know whether there is any need to speak to the answer that we received from the Department at the time of the Estimates but I have since received a letter from Dr Gregory Pemberton, University College, the University of New South Wales, Australian Defence Force Academy, and I seek leave to table that letter.
—You may incorporate it if you wish.
—I would like the letter read.
—Senator Crowley has the difficulty that she is not strictly relevant but I think the feeling of the Committee is-
—It is absolutely relevant.

—I have just received some further information, Mr Chairman. I apologise to you, to the departmental people and to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate), but I thought this was the end of the time to address the matter of veterans' affairs so, with your tolerance, I will proceed to read this letter. —I beg your pardon. Then I would ask whether somebody could get you a copy of that letter forth- with. I read into Hansard the first letter from Dr Gregory Pemberton that has caused this matter to arise:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Senator Crowley,

I refer to the questions asked by the Senate Estimates Committee, about the Official History being completed at the Australian War Memorial, reported in the Canberra Times on Tuesday, 15 May. I would like to correct an apparent error in the Committee's record.

In October 1989, the Estimates Committee was informed that the diplomatic volume of the history was being completed by Dr P. G. Edwards (photocopy of Hansard record enclosed): the implication was that he was writing that volume alone. In fact, I was co-author of the volume at that time and, indeed, had written the majority of that volume so far written at that date. I have now left the Official History Unit but intend to press my claim to co-authorship.
Yours sincerely,
(Dr.) Gregory Pemberton

I received that letter, I think, earlier today and I drew it to the attention of the Secretary of the Committee and asked him to write to Dr Pemberton telling him that we would include that answer in our consideration of the estimates. I believe he contacted Dr Edwards, who is the Official Historian, and I received a letter from Dr Edwards, a copy of which I have just given to Senator Walters as it was she who asked the question. I beg the Minister's pardon that I have not been able to provide him with a copy of that letter. I seek leave to incorporate Dr Edwards' answer in Hansard, as further information for the Estimates Committee record.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Official History Unit
Australian War Memorial
GPO Box 345
CANBERRA ACT 2601
Senator Rosemary Crowley
Chair
Senate Estimates Committee C
The Australian Senate
Dear Senator Crowley

The Secretary of your Committee suggested to me today that I might write to inform you briefly of some of the factors relating to the duration of the Official History, along the lines discussed in the interview reported in the Canberra Times of 16 May. This letter is in addition to the material forwarded by the Memorial in response to the questions raised by Senator Walters in the Committee on 14 May.

An Official History of Australia's involvements in the post 1945 conflicts was discussed by the Memorial with the Government of the day at various times in the 1960s and 1970s. In 1982 the Fraser Government agreed to the proposal that an Official Historian be appointed for Australia's involvement in the Malayan Emergency and the Vietnam War. In advertising the position, the task was described as the largest and most prestigious official history since the publication of Australia in the War of 1939-45. The series of books was to include at least 5 volumes, but no upper limit was set. On the recommendation of a selection panel, I was appointed by the Government in October 1982, after consultation with the then Leader of the Opposition. A bi-partisan appointment was essential, both because of the political sensitivity of the task and because access was required to the records of both Labor and Coalition administrations. I was granted complete and unrestricted access to all relevant Government documents. Like previous Australian official war historians, I was assured that the volumes would be published without censorship, subject to certain provisions which do not detract from this basic principle.

No deadline was set for the task, but the advertisement stated that: `It is not expected that the project could be completed in less than 7 years.' Accordingly I was appointed for an initial term of seven years. (The Government, in consultation with the then Leader of the Opposition, has recently re-appointed me for a further five years.) No deadlines were set for previous official war histories. The Official History of Australia in the War of 1914-1918 (which the Official Historian, C. E. W. Bean, initially thought he might conclude in five years) took from 1919 to 1942 to conclude. The Official Historian for the 1939-45 war was appointed in 1943; the last volume of that history was published in 1977. The Official History for the Korean War took more than a decade to complete. Similar experiences could be quoted for official histories in the United Kingdom, the United States, Canada and other countries.

A fundamental problem is that an official historian is the first person to be granted unrestricted access to a Government's records. Thus, at the outset, no-one knows precisely how much relevant material there is, how it is organized, what indexes (if any) exist, or even where the material is located. In this case, for example, there have been occasions when there has been considerable uncertainty about whether a particular collection of documents was held at the Australian Archives or in the originating department. Unlike the Official Historians for the two world wars, I was not appointed during the conflicts but long afterwards. There was therefore no opportunity to supervise the collection and organization of relevant material while the conflict was in progress. (It was suggested that historical officers should accompany the Task Force to Vietnam, but the proposal was rejected because of the strict limits on the size of the Australian contingent there.)

In 1988 the Government decided that Australia's involvement in the Indonesian-Malaysian Confrontation (1963-66) should be included in the Official History. I welcomed this decision, as it enables us to deal in a co-ordinated way with Australia's military involvement in Southeast Asia over the third quarter of this century. It does mean, however, that the History is to cover three conflicts over a total period of 27 years, from the outbreak of the Malayan Emergency in 1948 to the end of the Vietnam War in 1975. By comparison, the previous Australian official war histories were concerned with conflicts that lasted four, six and three years respectively. The inclusion of Confrontation has also entailed, of course, substantial revisions to the schema of volumes and the programme of research and writing.

The sheer volume of material involved in this History is difficult even for professional archivists and historians to comprehend. Reference was made in the Canberra Times article to 9.74 shelf-kilometres of Defence Department records. (A typical substantial file occupies about 3 centimetres when placed vertically on a shelf.) This figure in fact relates only to the more highly classified material of that Department for the period 1950-1970. It does not include a number of other relevant Defence Department collections, such as minutes of the Defence Committee and the Chiefs of Staff Committee. In addition there are all the records of the Cabinet and its Committees, the Prime Minister's Department, the Department of Foreign Affairs, the Department of Labour and National Service and others. Coverage of `the home front' requires extensive use of Hansard, newspapers, the records of various political and other organizations, and private papers. Oral history is a very time-consuming activity if it is to be conducted in a professional manner, but it too has been necessary in certain areas. Because the Malayan Emergency and Confrontation were fought as Commonwealth operations, and because the Vietnam war was fought in association with the United States, there are many records in London and Washington which are necessary to an understanding of Australia's involvement, both political and military, in addition to those held in Australia.

The advertisement for the position stated that the Official Historian's tasks would include `engaging and supervising the work of a supporting research team' and `appointing writers for individual volumes'. At the time I took up the post in February 1983, no firm decisions had been taken, or guidelines established, on staffing arrangements or budgetary provisions. These were to be handled through the annual appropriations for the Memorial. During the ensuing years the severe constraints on public expenditure meant that attempts to build up the staff required for the Official History took place in a most difficult climate. Like other areas of the Public Service, the Memorial faced many competing demands on its limited resources. Nevertheless it provided funds for four research officers and one administrative support officer.

To augment these resources, assistance has been sought from other organizations. Two historians at the University College, Australian Defence Force Academy, are writing parts of the History. They receive no remuneration, but the Memorial funds a research assistant for them. Through the co-operation of the Chief of the Air Staff, a historian will next month start work at the Air Power Studies Centre on the RAAF operations in Vietnam. The Memorial Council has made a special grant from its Fund to allow the appointment of three short-term research contractors in the current financial year. By these measures, it has been possible to build up a team of writers and researchers commensurate with the task, but it has taken some time and effort to do so. Moreover, administering a team which is geographically dispersed presents its own demands.

I believe that, given all the circumstances, progress has been remarkably good. Five volumes are currently being researched and written. I have set target dates for the completion of the manuscripts of all seven volumes in the History. I enclose a list of the proposed volumes and the completion dates at which we are aiming. It is my intention to have the whole project completed by the mid-1990s, which would compare favourably with the record of most official histories of comparable scale.

You may be assured that the members of the Official History Unit do not see their positions as sinecures. As professional historians, whose reputations rest on publications, it is in our own interests to publish volumes as quickly as possible. At the same time we are conscious that this is not a private endeavour, but the nation's official history. It must meet the highest standards of fairness, accuracy and comprehensiveness. It is to that end that my colleagues and I are working.
Yours sincerely
(Dr) Peter Edwards
Official Historian

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a number of questions and a reservation concerning the Vietnam war history. I have received answers to the questions I asked which were put on notice, but as a result of those answers, many other questions have arisen. I would like to deal with the staffing situation first. The following comments were reported in the Estimates Committee C hearing:
—Who has been given the task of writing the official history?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Pearson-The official war historian was appointed seven years ago by the then Government in consultation with the then Opposition. The official historian is assisted by a small team of writers and researchers.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was not what I asked; I asked who.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Pearson-Dr Peter Edwards.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many people are working on the history?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Pearson-It has an ASL of six and assistance is also being given by two historians employed by the Australian Defence Forces Academy.

I was told that there was a small team of writers and researchers employed to work on the project. I then asked how it was progressing. I was told that it had been going for seven years and that the official historian had just been given another five years, I think it was, but that no volumes had yet reached the publication stage.

As a result of some media comment, Dr Edwards went public in an article which appeared in the Canberra Times on Wednesday, 16 May. The letter which he sent to Senator Crowley-as Senator Crowley said, I have only just received this and have not been able to read it in full-seems to me to be a recycling of the Canberra Times article, which stated:
However, since his appointment,-
it was saying that Dr Edwards had been appointed for seven years-
Dr Edwards had been forced to seek researchers and writers because funds had not been made available, although his clear understanding had been there would be a `team of historians'.
The article continued:
Dr Edwards said he was eventually able to appoint three researchers but it had `proved impossible' to get the resources for the appointment of writers.

I ask, particularly following the letter from Dr Pemberton: Were the co-authors Dr Pemberton, Ms Jordens, Dr O'Keefe, and Ian McNeill? Did Dr Pemberton write the diplomatic volume of the history or the strategic one? Was Ms Jordens writing about the home front? Was Dr O'Keefe writing about the medical side of it? Was Ian McNeill writing about the combat operations? Were they co-authors? Could I have the duty statements of those officers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —For the benefit of Senator Walters, I shall set out the names and qualifications of those historians who are writing parts of the official history, other than Dr Edwards. Two are permanent officers of the War Memorial. The first is Ian McNeill, who is writing on combat operations in Vietnam. He is a former Army officer who has postgraduate qualifications in history. He is the author of The Team, a history of the Australian Army training team in Vietnam, in which he served. Brendan O'Keefe, who is writing on medical aspects, has degrees in both history and dentistry and a diploma in archives administration. He has several publications in local history and medical history.

SPEECH.PARA: Three are not remunerated by the Memorial and are not included in the Memorial's ASL. The first, Peter Dennis, who is writing on combat operations in Malaya, is professor and head of the department of history at the University College, Australian Defence Force Academy. He has a doctorate in military history and is the author of several works on British and Commonwealth history, including Decision by Default: British Politics and Peacetime Conscription; Troubled Days of Peace: Mountbatten and South East Asia Command 1945-46; and The Territorial Army 1907-40.

The second is Jeffrey Grey, who is writing on combat operations during confrontation and on Royal Australian Navy operations in Vietnam. He has a PhD in military history and is a lecturer in history at the University College, Australian Defence Force Academy. He is the author of several works on Australian and Commonwealth military history, including The Commonwealth Armies and the Korean War: An Alliance Study; A Military History of Australia; and The Vietnam Years: Australia and the Impact of Vietnam, which is a forthcoming publication.

The third is Chris Coulthard-Clark, who in June will begin work on Royal Australian Air Force operations in Vietnam. He is the author of several works of military history, including a history of the Royal Military College Duntroon, and two military biographies, Heritage of Spirit on General Bridges, and No Australian Need Apply on General Legge. He has just completed a major study of the RAAF between the two World Wars. He will be located at the RAAF's Air Power Studies Centre.

The two research officers working with the official history unit on permanent appointments funded by the Memorial appropriation list and included in the Memorial's ASL are Dr Chris Walters and Mr Ashley Ekins. Three researchers are working with the unit on short term contracts funded by a special grant from the Memorial Council and are not included in the Memorial's ASL. They are Ms Elizabeth Stewart, Colonel David Chinn, MBE, and Dr Bridget Brooklyn. A research assistant is located at the Australian Defence Force Academy to assist Professor Dennis and Dr Grey. This position is funded by the Memorial but is not included in the Memorial's ASL. At present this position is vacant but arrangements are being made to fill it.

Duty statements for the permanent officers of the Memorial-Dr Edwards, Mr McNeill, Mr O'Keefe, Dr Walters and Mr Ekins-are available. I will table them. Professor Dennis, Dr Grey, Dr Coulthard-Clark, the research assistant at the Australian Defence Force Academy, and the researchers on short term contracts are not officers of the Memorial and therefore duty statements are not held for them.

The former non-administrative members of the official history unit, their qualifications and their former tasks are as follows: Dr Gregory Pemberton holds a PhD degree in diplomatic history. He is the author of All The Way: Australia's Road to Vietnam. He was working as co-author with the official historian on a volume which was initially on strategy and diplomacy but subsequently included domestic political aspects to become a volume on politics and diplomacy. He left the unit at the end of 1989. He currently holds a post-doctoral fellowship at the Australian Defence Force Academy.

Miss Ann-Mari Jordens holds two masters degrees and is the author of The Stenhouse Circle. She was working as co-author with the official historian of a volume on homefront aspects of Australian involvement until that area was merged with strategy and diplomacy. Miss Jordens left the unit in early 1989 to take up a position with the Department of the Senate and is now with the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs.

I have already mentioned Dr Jeffrey Grey. In relation to Dr Pemberton, I am assured by the official historian that no final decision has yet been taken on the attribution of authorship for the volume, which, I have indicated, changed its objectives during the course of the writing. Appropriate acknowledgment will, of course, be given to all those who contribute to research and writing of the various volumes.

In November 1988 the Memorial Council resolved that the designation of authorship is a matter for the official historian. As I have told Senator Walters, the official historian advises me that he has made no decision as to the attribution of authorship in relation to the volume in question. But, in general, quite apart from authorship, in accord with the canons of proper academic attribution those who contribute to the research will be properly acknowledged in the pages of the volume.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it a fact that Dr Pemberton and Miss Jordens spent five years writing their histories?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that they were engaged in work for the official history unit for about that duration.
—Were their histories virtually completed?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The official historian advises me that they were not.
—Could the official historian advise the Minister as to what remained to be done to those volumes for completion?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that a considerable amount of research and writing was required in the case of both volumes.
—Was that rewriting or remaining writing to be done?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a little difficult to disentangle but I understand that a lot of writing remained to be done. There was also research to be done. Obviously, the elements of the new writing would include taking into consideration the new research. If I understand correctly the contrast Senator Walters is trying to make, there was more to it than writing in a more graceful or a different style research matters already completed.
—Could the Minister ascertain why Mr Edwards said that it had proved impossible to get the resources for the appointment of writers?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the letter to Senator Crowley contains a fuller version of Dr Edwards's views on this, not edited in any way by a reporter-not that I am suggesting that there was any misreporting in the article. But the full story is outlined in the 3 3/4 pages written by Mr Peter Edwards at the invitation, as I understand it, of the secretary of the Committee. There is a full account in that letter of the fundamental difficulties in writing this particular major piece of research.
—Could the Minister tell me why Dr Pemberton and Miss Jordens left that section of the history writing?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that no official reason was made available. I do not know whether any speculation would be of any use. I certainly cannot engage in any. Miss Jordens has left the unit to take up a position with another department-I think it may actually have been the Department of the Senate-and Dr Pemberton took leave without pay in order to take up an appointment with the Australian Defence Force Academy. No official reason was stated for their departure.

—Could the Minister tell me the reason for the merging of their work-I was going to say virtually completed work but I have been assured that it was not virtually completed-that had been considerably under way after having been written for five years?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the international and domestic aspects of the engagement of Australia in the conflicts which are the subject of the history were so intertwined-perhaps that is a feature of modern waging of warfare even though it is conducted overseas-that the official historian felt that the division would be too artificial and crude and the influence of one on the other was such that it was best to forge an amalgam.

SPEECH.PARA: The official historian does not work alone in these matters. There is an official history advisory committee consisting of Professor Inglis, Professor of History at the Australian National University, Professor Nancy Viviani, Professor of Political Science at the Australian National University, Dr A. W. Martin, Senior Fellow in History at the Australian National University and Dr Hudson, Editor of Historical Documents, Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. I am told that they commended the official historian on his decision to amalgamate those volumes of the history and to approach it in the coordinated and complementary way that he devised and thought best.

TALK.START.PARA: —At what Public Service level were Dr Pemberton, Miss Jordens, Dr O'Keefe and Ian O'Neill employed?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know what the figures I have been given mean; I have never understood Public Service jargon. I understand that the people Senator Walters mentioned were appointed at ASO5 level and received promotions to ASO7 level.

—Two of the authors have spent five years each, so we have had 10 years spent on work done on two volumes. After that time not only have they not been published but we have been told by Mr Pearson that he believes the first volume will be published in 1991-that was the information provided at the Estimates Committee hearing. According to the Minister's information, I gather that those two volumes are now merged and are not yet completed after 10 years work. TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think that it is as straightforward as just putting together two salaries for people at various levels over five years. Perhaps it could be attempted; I am not sure whether it can be. Obviously, it cannot be done tonight but, if we can get that information for you, in some sensible form, that will be done. The time being taken to complete these volumes is a matter which a lay-person, such as I am, finds to be out of the ordinary. To put it in context, it ought to be mentioned, as is the case in the letter to Senator Crowley, that the official history of Australia in the war of 1914 to 1918-Senator Walters is shaking her head; I am trying to put it into context, which I am entitled to do--

—I intend to go down that road. The official history of Australia in the war of 1914-1918 took from 1919 to 1942 to conclude. Am I being misled? The official historian for the 1939-1945 World War was appointed in 1943. The last volume of that history was published in 1977. Am I being misled?
—I will respond to that in a moment.

—The official history for the Korean War took more than a decade to complete. I think that Senator Puplick studied history at one stage. Perhaps he has a better appreciation of the research that is involved in putting these official histories together. After all, this is not a private indulgence by somebody trying to get a PhD out of a university. This is writing an official history for the people of Australia which will be the record for centuries to come of this particular series of conflicts in which the Australian people were engaged.
—When did the first volumes appear of the history of World War II-not when they were completed, but the first volumes?

—We will get the exact dates. We believe the volumes for the First World War were completed in the early 1920s and the volumes for the Second World War were completed in the early 1950s. That will give some indication to the Committee of the target dates.

—The histories of World War I and World War II were done on a part-time basis, I believe. Would the Minister like to check that? This war history has been done on a full-time basis for the last seven or eight years. I think that is the difference.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the official historians were full-time appointees. In any case, I certainly have not been misled. Senator Walters may offer some fresh information, but it is quite improper to suggest that I have been misled in giving my answers. I have nothing more to add.
—Did the Minister say that he would table the duty statements of Dr Pemberton and Miss Jordens?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

—We will now turn to the Department of Community Services and Health. The first matter referred by the Estimates Committee was family planning and regional centres. Is there any discussion on that matter? If not, the next matter is the family medical program announcement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report we made on the family medicine program (FMP) related to a change in policy. There were two issues involved: the first was whether or not the policy should have been changed in relation to those eligible for the higher descriptors under vocational registration. I do not wish to enter into that argument; that is a policy matter. Government can take it up and argue with us at an appropriate time.

SPEECH.PARA: The other matter which emerged was the manner in which this changed policy was made known. It was important to report to the Senate the way in which it came to our notice. A member of my staff drew to my attention a publication from the family medicine program in New South Wales which contained within it a letter signed by Joan Lipscombe, Assistant Secretary, Health Care Strategies Branch of the Department of Community Services and Health, which indicated that a decision had been made that certain people, without the requisite qualifications but in advanced stages of training, should become eligible for the payments under the vocational register. That is a policy decision, so I do not want to question it.

The questions that we asked in the Estimates were as follows: was this decision made known to the Parliament? The answer we received was no, it had not. Was this decision then made known to the public? The answer we received at that time was no, it had not. So the information we had received, unless it is to be modified now, was that this information, which appeared in a journal of the trainee doctors indicating that they could get some more money for what they are doing, was announced to them and not announced to the Parliament or the public. I will read just one paragraph of the letter that appeared because it really did make the matter clear. It states:
As a result of these discussions the Minister for Community Services and Health has acknowledged the concerns of trainees on this matter. Dr Blewett-
the then Minister-

is particularly concerned to ensure that there are no barriers to practices accepting FMP trainees. Consequently he has approved in principle new arrangements to allow the use of the new content based descriptors by FMP trainees subject to specific conditions.

What that means, when the jargon is translated, is that Dr Blewett had agreed that the FMP trainees could attract higher rebates. It was an agreement in principle. It did require further details to be worked out, but the fact remains that this decision, which was available to every FMP trainee in New South Wales who read the journal, had not been made known to the Parliament or to the public. It is of particular concern because this Parliament had taken upon itself the establishment of the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance to look at the question of vocational registration-a committee which had studied the matter under the chair of Senator Crowley, had reported to the Parliament, and had made some recommendations about vocational registration.

The point we wish to make is that this was an act of gross discourtesy to the Parliament by the Department of Community Services and Health. We want to understand how and why it happened. Could the Minister explain that to us?

TALK.START.PARA: —While the Minister is getting that answer ready, could I just be clear on what Senator Peter Baume has said. He read a letter which suggested that the family medicine program trainees would be able to attract the higher fee. —Senator Crowley is right, but let us be quite clear what she is saying. For services rendered by the trainees the principal would be able to attract higher rebate level. The point that I am making remains valid. Senator Crowley is correct: the higher rebates were to be made to the practice. My point is not to question the policy content-that we can do in another place in another way-but to question the process and to say that it is a matter of gross discourtesy to the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand the process itself, the various proper authorities such as the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners and relevant trainee organisations were advised of a decision in principle.
