In this way, the Parliament will have the ordinary opportunity to consider whether the proposal should be permitted to go ahead. The relevant regulations would be tabled and, of course, would be subject to disallowance.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the whole substantive matter, the decision in principle, which Senator Peter Baume says that he is putting to one side, I do have a lengthy statement by the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) which I was asked to read in anticipation that Senator Baume would be concerned about the policy and not merely the process. I could read it but it would take some time. As to the process part of the letter, it is acknowledged that the correct parliamentary process is that this matter be dealt with by way of regulation and subject to the normal surveillance by this chamber pre-eminently, but under parliamentary sanction as is the case with regulations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make the point, but will not belabour it too long, that what the Minister has indicated has made the situation even worse because he has now said that the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners was not made aware of the decision. We asked in the Estimates Committee whether a press release was issued; was the public let into the secret, because it appears that it was not. I make the point again that it would have taken very little to have issued a press statement to let the public know. Of course what the Minister says about the regulation process and the disallowance of regulations is correct; I am not contesting that. All I am asking is that if the Minister is going to tell interest groups what he is doing, would he please tell the public and let the Parliament in on the secret as well?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that that is a fair comment. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the statement by the Minister with regard to this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
VOCATIONAL REGISTRATION FOR FAMILY MEDICINE PROGRAM TRAINEES

Given the criticism that the Government should have informed the Senate of its intentions in relation to vocational registration for family medicine program trainees I wish, on behalf of the Minister for Community Services and Health, to inform the Senate of the Government's considerations on provisional vocational registration in certain circumstances for such doctors.

The family medicine program is an integral part of the vocational registration arrangements. It is the only comprehensive, formal, post graduate vocational training course for general practice. From January 1995 completion of this program will be the main way for doctors to become eligible for the vocational register.

The program is run by the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners. The report of the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance on vocational registration of general practitioners recommended that the college examine the content and structure of the FMP with a view to providing options with regard to the length and intensity of the course to accommodate different trainees' requirements while maintaining appropriate standards. Since then the College has reduced the minimum training period from four years post intern year to three years by making the training more intensive. It is still possible for doctors to complete the training over a longer period if they wish.

These three years involve at least one year in hospital on rotations relevant to general practice, one year on formal training placements in a general practice under close supervision and one further year spent in general practice under the supervision of a mentor. Time spent in acquiring other special skills which may be required for remote or rural practice, such as training in anaesthetics, paediatrics, may also be encompassed within the program.

In its report on vocational registration for general practitioners, the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance recommended that FMP trainees not be eligible for vocational registration, but that the case for provisional registration be considered further by the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners and the Department of Community Services and Health as part of the evaluation of vocational registration. FMP trainees have continued to express major concerns that being prevented from using the new content based descriptors limits the effectiveness of the training periods in general practices and creates financial disadvantages for training practices, as well as making trainees less attractive as potential employees during these periods.

After extensive discussions with the RACGP, which has liaised closely with trainee representatives, the government has acknowledged these difficulties. It considers that it would be appropriate to permit FMP trainees to be placed on the register under specified circumstances. Trainees would be permitted to be registered for the duration of their formal training placements in general practice and in their mentor year, but only where they are under the direct supervision of a vocationally registered GP and where the trainee does not benefit personally financially from the arrangement. In the case of the formal training placements in general practice it would be a condition of the arrangement that the trainee not practice elsewhere. Should these conditions not be met or should the trainee fail to complete the program successfully the trainee would be removed from the register. I understand that this approach has the full support of the RACGP and trainee organisations. I understand also that the AMA does not oppose the proposals.

The Government is mindful that these trainees are doctors who have not completed the requirements for appropriate training and experience for vocational registration. The Government therefore will not be proceeding with the proposed changes unless it can be unequivocally assured that the trainees will not benefit financially from the changes and that the trainees are under proper supervision to ensure the highest quality of patient care.

The proposals are designed to ensure that training practices are not disadvantaged by taking on FMP trainees and that the trainees are properly trained in the use of the content based descriptors during their placements. It is crucial to the success of the scheme that sufficient training placements be made available to accommodate all doctors who wish to undergo vocational training for general practice. While the government has provided sufficient extra funds to finance the extra training placements in general practices, the training places will not be forthcoming if there are substantial barriers discouraging practices from taking trainees.

The Attorney-General's Department has been requested to draft appropriate regulations. If regulations can be drafted to ensure adequate safeguards then the Government would wish to proceed with the proposals. In that case the relevant regulations will be tabled in the Parliament in the usual manner.

—The next department is the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. The first matter referred by the Estimates Committee was the Australia Council news release containing party political opinion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the report of Senate Estimates Committee C it will be seen at paragraph 9 that the Committee reports as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: On 2 March 1990 the Australia Council made a news release in which comments were made concerning the proposal by the Coalition Parties to abolish the Council, and a claim was made by the Council that the Shadow Minister had `misled both the Australian people and his own Party'. The Committee is of the view that statements of party political opinion should not be canvassed in news releases of government agencies.

I should, lest anybody be unaware of the situation, indicate that I was the shadow Minister for arts, heritage and sport at the time that that news release was made. The point which the whole Committee is seeking to make-and I remind the Committee that this is the report of the whole Committee, not just of some members of the Committee or of the Opposition members of the Committee-is that there are proper ways in which governments and oppositions engage in partisan debate about differences of policy.

There are also limits which should or should not be observed by departments and statutory authorities, essentially by public servants, which go to the question of preserving the integrity of a genuinely neutral or apolitical Public Service. This country, in best Westminster tradition, has been well served for the whole of the period since Federation by a Public Service which has prided itself properly on the question of an apolitical ambience of a neutrality of behaviour on the part of public servants in relation to what are legitimate discussions between the political parties about various aspects of policy.

Let me make the point quite clearly that on 17 September 1988 the coalition parties-as I said, I was the shadow Minister responsible for the arts portfolio-released their arts policy in which a reference was made to the Australia Council. The Party policy says:

The Australia Council will be abolished and its functions transferred to the relevant Department responsible for the Arts, thus bringing Commonwealth policy into line with that adopted in each of the States.

The document goes on to deal with the advisory board mechanism which was proposed, with the principles of arm's length funding and peer assessment and with various other directives which may or may not from time to time be given to the Department in the discharge of its responsibilities in accordance with what would have been the policy of an incoming coalition government.

March 1990 was the middle of a very vigorously fought election campaign. The policy document to which reference has been made had been in the public domain for a period of some 15 or 16 months. On 2 March the Australia Council put out a news release in which I, as the shadow Minister, was described in a number of disparaging references. The policy which I was advocating was described as an arbitrary act of cultural vandalism. I was named on a number of occasions in that press release. For example, one part said:
The Australia Council regards with amazement the statement of Senator Chris Puplick, the Coalition spokesman for the arts, that the staff of the Australia Council would be safe in their jobs.

This is despite the fact that I had given a number of assurances that because the staff of the Australia Council were members of the Public Service their security of tenure was to be guaranteed. The statement of 2 March made a number of further disparaging comments. It concluded with the following paragraph:
The Council is deeply concerned that this misstatement of Senator Puplick's, is merely one of many in which he has misled both the Australian people and his own party.

I was somewhat offended by that and offended by the press comments, particularly since this comment was made and this press release was issued during the Adelaide Arts Festival which, as Senator Crowley rightly pointed out during the Estimates Committee hearings, is one of the great arts festivals not only of Australia but internationally. I was particularly offended at the comment that I had misled both the Australian people and my own Party and that this was alleged to be one of several occasions in which this had occurred. I indicated my concern about that and the fact that I thought it was actionable, as indeed I believe it was.

Three days later, on 5 March, the Australia Council put out the news release again, only on this occasion it simply deleted the offending last paragraph which referred to the misleading of the Australian people and my own Liberal Party. So the release was, in fact, put out a second time. The attack upon me was nevertheless continued and I was again named. There were implications that I was threatening the jobs of the employees of the Australia Council and that my assurances of their security of tenure as Commonwealth public servants were worthless.

During the election campaign I had a number of vigorous run-ins with Government Ministers. Senator Richardson, who is now in the chamber, and I debated at the National Press Club on environment matters. I had two debates with Mr Holding during the election campaign, one at the Victorian Arts Centre and one on radio about arts policy. I take it as the absolutely legitimate and proper way in which political parties operate that the representatives of the political parties debate each other on questions of alternative policies. What I do not accept as legitimate is that Commonwealth statutory authorities should engage themselves, any more than public service departments should engage themselves, in the partisan debate during an election campaign. It would have been quite interesting if this debate had taken place immediately in September 1988 because that was when the original statement was made. But the Australia Council decided that it would wait until the heat of the election campaign to buy back into the particular argument.

It is not as if this was simply some whimsy on the part of the Chairman of the Australia Council, Professor Horne. If we look at the record of the hearing of Estimates Committee C on Thursday, 17 May 1990, we see that Mr Max Bourke, General Manager of the Council, was before the Committee and I asked him a series of questions, one of which was:
Do the news releases represent the official view of the Australia Council on particular matters that are contained within those releases-the Council's official view?

Mr Bourke replied, `Yes.' I then went on to ask him whether the description of me as a cultural vandal and a person who had misled both the Australian people and my own Party was an official view of a statutory body. Mr Bourke replied:
It was a view expressed by the Council, yes, that is right.

Mr Bourke was unable to provide details at that time of the distribution or cost of this news release. I note that despite his assurances that the material would be provided it still has not been provided to this date. I still do not have provided to me, as was undertaken by Mr Bourke, the details of the distribution or the cost to the Australian taxpayer of the Australia Council's participation in this particular election campaign.
When I asked Mr Bourke in what way he believed I had misled people, Mr Bourke's reply was:
I do not believe I can do that,-
that is to say, give me the information-
as chief executive officer.
In other words, he said, `Well, I'm not part of the Australia Council; I am only its servant; therefore I am unable to tell you that'. I asked Mr Bourke subsequently:

. . . can you recall previous releases by the Australia Council which have, over any number of years, sought to personalise attacks upon shadow Ministers or upon members of parliament, in relation to what is clearly a live matter, in the course of an election campaign.

Mr Bourke replied, `I cannot'. He qualified that by saying that he had not been at the Australia Council for all of that period, but he could not recall any such previous releases. I then asked him whether the Australia Council had made comments about the two political parties' policy speeches which were issued by Mr Peacock and Mr Hawke during the election campaign. Mr Bourke indicated that the Council had made no evaluation of the respective policy statements of the two parties. I asked whether, in fact, discussions between the Ministers of the Government and the--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. I seek your clarification on this, Mr Chairman. It seems unnecessary and, in fact, repetitious and probably contrary to the intention of the changed Standing Orders for the conduct of consideration of the Estimates for the honourable senator to read in detail, word by word, what is on the public record.

—The purpose of the debate here is so that the matter can be aired in the committee of the whole. If Senator Puplick feels it necessary to read extracts from the record of the Estimates Committee hearing, he would be in order to do so. It is a decision for Senator Puplick.

—If Senator Crowley wishes me to read the lot, I am more than happy to start at page C91 and proceed, with the assistance of my friend Senator Crichton-Browne in a series of 15-minute addresses until we get to page C94. I am perfectly happy to do that. However, for the sake of expedition I will resist the temptation unless Senator Crowley interrupts me again.

SPEECH.PARA: I went on to ask Mr Bourke whether in fact discussions between the Ministers and the Australia Council, particularly where there might have been any disagreement between them on policy questions, had ever led to official Australia Council press releases on policy questions. Mr Bourke confirmed that they had not. Whereas discussions which I had had as shadow Minister with the Australia Council had in fact led to the issuing of formal press releases by the Australia Council.

Regardless of the merits of the particular argument-you, rightly, Mr Chairman, prevent me from canvassing the merits of the particular argument-what the Estimates Committee has done, with the unanimous consent of the three Labor members and the three coalition members of the Estimates Committee, is draw attention to the fact that the Estimates Committee does not believe that it is appropriate that statutory bodies should put out statements which are of a party political nature in their official press releases.

I want to make the point that the adoption of the Committee's report implies quite clearly to statutory authorities and agencies that this is the view taken by a Senate Estimates committee and may in fact be the view taken by this chamber: that it is not a legitimate role, if we are to preserve the apolitical integrity of the Public Service and its statutory authorities, for authorities to engage in behaviour which is seen as partisan political, particularly bearing in mind that this occurred during an election campaign and that the policy which was being discussed was not a policy that had suddenly emerged during the course of the campaign and, therefore, had not been in the public domain, had not been subject to debate between the Australia Council and me, or between the Australia Council and other commentators in the public domain but was in fact a policy which was 15 or 18 months old.

One of the underpinnings of the parliamentary system that we have is the belief, held by members of the Opposition, that when they get into government, the public servants with whom they will be working, as Ministers, will serve them with the same degree of commitment, fairness and neutrality as they served their previous political masters. If that is broken down by the partisan intervention, particularly during an election campaign, of those senior public servants and statutory authorities, the loser will not be the politicians who are involved one way or the other in the dispute and the debate; the loser will be the integrity of the Australian political and Public Service system. That, in fact, is far more important than the egos or the feelings of any politicians who are involved and it is something worth fighting for to preserve. I think the Estimates Committee and the Senate, in noting this in its resolution, in fact will make a contribution to that important preservation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well done, Senator Puplick. SPEECH.PARA: At the time of formulating our report, the Committee did make qualifications which may not be understood. For the record, it is important to note that the Committee did not think public servants and heads of departments were to be equated with officers of statutory authorities. There is an independence and a distance from government pertaining to statutory authorities that is not true of public servants and, particularly, heads of departments.

I think it is reasonable for a statutory authority to make a comment about matters political. It may be that there is a fine line between what is party political and what is partisan political. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Myanmar-Member for McEwen-Representation of Western Australia-Tasmania

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak tonight on the adjournment debate about the forthcoming elections in Myanmar which are to occur on Sunday, 27 May. Recently in the Senate some questions have been asked by senators regarding these proposed elections. I know that Senator Jenkins from Western Australia has asked a couple of questions over the last year or so and has also put forward notices of motion indicating her interest in the affairs of Myanmar. I noticed today that Senator Newman asked a question and tried to draw some parallels, on the ground of inconsistency, between this Government's policy towards South Africa and its policy towards Myanmar. That was a quite erroneous and irrelevant comparison and I think it shows that Senator Newman, in drawing that comparison, does not understand much about either country.

SPEECH.PARA: I have spoken before in the Senate about my interest in Myanmar, which has been generated as a result of my visit to that country in February last year. Since then I have maintained an interest in the affairs of that country and have maintained regular contact with people from the Myanmar community in Australia, as well as overseas. I have had correspondence with Congressman Solarz and Senator Moynihan from the United States of America, who are both interested in the affairs of Myanmar, and also with groups of people around the world who, in many cases, are expatriates who have left that country during the long regime of General Ne Win.

The proposed elections to be held on Sunday have been, in my view, rightly criticised on a number of aspects concerning the conduct of the election campaign. It is quite clear that by any definition that we would use in Australia, these are not free and fair elections because most of the major Opposition politicians-particularly Aung San Suu Kyi, U Tin U and others-have been arrested, detained or held under house arrest and have not been able to participate in the election, either by campaigning or by being able to stand in the elections on Sunday. There have been restrictions on campaign techniques, advertising, on the way in which rallies have been able to be held, and so on. So, as I say, I agree with the criticism that, by any normal examination, this is not a normal, free and fair election as we in a Western democracy would believe.

But I also want to put information before the Senate which indicates that there is some evidence that the actual voting on Sunday-if it is carried through by the regime-technically will have some validity. I wish to present the information that I have received from a number of contacts both here in Australia and overseas concerning the arrangements that the authorities in Myanmar have put together through their electoral commission for holding this election.

The first thing is that it appears that the people running the polling booths and administering the election at the local level will not be party members associated with the present regime but will be administrators and, in many cases, community elders who are recognised and respected in their local community. It is estimated that 20.7 million registered voters will be eligible to vote, but voting is not compulsory. The present regime says that there will be 18,190 polling booths, one for approximately each 5,000 voters. About 80 per cent of wards and villages will have only one polling booth. In a polling booth of 5,000 voters will be one polling booth officer, five persons to check the electoral rolls, five persons to issue ballot papers, five persons to look after the ballot box, and 10 voting cubicles or rooms.

To ensure the security of a ballot paper, the emblem of the Election Commission will be printed on the back and each paper will have a security thread. In addition, the polling booth officer is required to sign each ballot paper as it is issued. The names of candidates, emblems of the parties they represent and voting squares opposite each name will be printed on the front of the paper. Voters are identified in the electoral roll by serial number. Voters are also required to prove their identity by producing to the polling booth official their identification cards.

Voters will mark their ballots with a cross in the box of their preferred candidate in the privacy of a voting cubicle using a rubber stamp provided. Ballot papers will be declared invalid if there is a cross marked on the ballot paper in a place other than in the box opposite the name of the candidate, is misaligned between the boxes, is on the name of the candidate, is on the candidate's electoral symbol, or if the cross marked is stamped repeatedly. Moreover, if ballot papers are stained, marked in other than the approved manner, or torn, they will be rejected.

The completed ballot will be placed in a single ballot box located in public viewing in the polling booth. Representatives of the candidates will be present at polling booths as well as the polling officials. The booths will be closed at 4 p.m. and if there are persons queueing outside the polling booths waiting to vote, they will be allowed to do so even after 4 p.m. The votes will be counted at the individual polling booths in the presence of members of the polling booth team, the candidates, or their designated representatives, and the general public.

Invalid ballot papers will be so declared by the polling booth officer stating the reasons for so doing. The polling booth officer, members of the polling booth team and other witnesses will be required to sign on the back of the rejected ballot. The composite result of each booth is to be entered on a form which is to be signed by those persons listed. The form and ballots for each candidate will then be conveyed to the relevant township sub-commission. The Central Election Commission, after scrutinising the relevant forms and signatures for the constituency as a whole, will declare the winning candidate. The names of the successful candidates will be broadcast daily on radio and television, starting on the election night, the 27th. No-one will be allowed to canvass votes within 100 yards of the polling booth.

Information that has just come to my attention in the last 24 hours says that army commanders have indicated in briefings to their officers and troops that the responsibility for the security of polling booths rests with the Electoral Commission, but in the event of disturbances at a booth, troops will not intervene unless requested to do so by the Commission, and where such a request is made, will do so only after a statement is signed indicating that the intervention is taking place at the request of the Commission. It is understood that troops have been instructed to stay well away from polling booths in order to avoid accusations that they may be intimidating voters or electoral officials or otherwise interfering with the electoral process.

One area of concern is that if a determination of a valid vote is the use of the rubber stamp, it is suggested that if the ink is not dry when people fold their ballot paper and put in the ballot box, the smudging may lead to a stain which may lead to invalidity of the vote. There has also been some concern expressed about whether 5,000 voters could be processed through one booth in a 10-hour period. As the voting is not compulsory, no-one expects there to be a 100 per cent turnout and, as suggested previously in my remarks, the booths will stay open past 4 p.m. if a queue is formed.

With the information that has come to my attention from a number of sources in the last few days, if those procedures are carried out by the regime, as far as the actual voting is concerned on the day, one could see that the election will be reasonably fair as far as the technicalities are concerned. It also means that we have on record enough information to indicate that if these procedures are not carried out the election will certainly not have been free and fair.

I also point out that the major opposition party-the National League for Democracy (NLD)-is contesting around 440 of the 485 seats, which means that, as the major opposition party, it does have a chance of winning the election if it gets the support and the voting is free and fair on the day. In a late press report tonight I noticed that some diplomats in Myanmar are now saying that, despite Aung San Suu Kyi being detained and not being able to participate in the election, the NLD, as the leading opposition party, may have some chance of winning the election. Personally, I would applaud very much if the NLD could win the election as the main opposition party.

There is evidence that the election campaign is very low key and very calm because of the limitations placed by the regime on normal election activity. Public rallies, with up to 2,000 or 3,000 people attending in some cities and villages, have been held. Over the last few days limited television coverage has been provided to the various candidates, including opposition candidates.

My final observation of the election is that up until yesterday it was apparent that the regime would not allow outside observers into Myanmar to observe the election. For example, Congressman Solarz from the United States of America, who had requested a visa to visit Myanmar and observe the election, has been rejected. But late this afternoon the regime announced that it would allow 60 journalists to visit Myanmar over the weekend and observe the election. These journalists are based mainly in Bangkok and have been covering Myanmar affairs over the last couple of years. That is a very welcome development. I would be surprised if those 60 journalists were not able to make some relevant comments about the conduct of the election.

If there is substantial support for the Opposition in the election of the national assembly, the real test will be what will happen with the transition of power from the present army regime to the national assembly. The final test of democracy being partially restored in any sense in Myanmar will be whether the army accepts the result of the election and arranges for the transition of power to a civilian government; whether it accepts the result of the people if the voting in the election has been properly and fairly conducted.

Over the last 18 months a number of honourable senators and members of the House of Representatives have shown interest in affairs in Myanmar. I hope that the Australian Parliament will watch closely the events in Myanmar next week and subsequent weeks after the election and be willing to make public comment and express views about what may occur, particularly if the present military regime is not willing to hand over power or arrange for the transition of power to a democratically elected civilian government if the election is properly conducted.

I certainly wish the people of Burma, now called Myanmar, all the best for Sunday. I hope they get the chance to vote properly and fairly and to elect the government of their choice. I urge the military regime to respect the result so that in the years to come Myanmar can once again develop a proper democracy and economic policies that restore prosperity and a decent standard of living to the people of that country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased that Senator Bolkus, the Minister for Administrative Services, is in the chamber this evening because I have a story which has taken on the proportions of the Epic of Gilgamesh or The Forsyte Saga. I have no doubt that he knows about it, but I want to reiterate it to the Senate and put it on the public record. I was delighted, in fact thrilled, that on 9 April this year Mrs Fran Bailey was formally declared the elected member for McEwen. She came into this Parliament to join me as the first female Federal member of parliament from Victoria to represent the Liberal Party of Australia in the lower House.

SPEECH.PARA: The concern I raise this evening is that Mrs Bailey still does not have an office. When Mrs Bailey was declared elected, the Department of Administrative Services in Melbourne identified suitable premises in Epping at her request and negotiated with the landlord. The size of these premises is below the entitlement area for a Federal member of parliament's offices. Because of this, Fran Bailey originally put forward a submission applying for temporary accommodation, but was always mindful that, as there was a dearth of suitable office accommodation in Epping, this accommodation may have to be permanent. She waited and waited for a response from the Minister on her submission. When told that the Minister had refused her submission for these premises to be temporary, she was also informed by the Minister's Department that she had to use an electoral office that already existed in Seymour as a temporary office.

She was left with no other resort but to bring her plight before her constituents through the use of the media, which she did on 3 May. Once pressed by the media, the Minister then declared that he had given approval for Mrs Bailey to proceed with an office in Craigieburn. During the campaign Fran and I looked at the offices in Craigieburn-in fact, Fran and I had talked about these as a possible location because I was pretty convinced that she would win the seat. Unfortunately, the Minister had not kept up with the current information being provided to him. The premises which Mrs Bailey had suggested originally and which the Minister had approved were already occupied by a video shop and were no longer available.

After consulting with her staff, Mrs Bailey accepted that the 103 square metres of office space-which is below a Federal member's entitlement-in Epping would be appropriate as a permanent office given the fact that there was very little office space in the southern area of her electorate. It should be noted that the temporary office in Seymour which the Minister was urging Mrs Bailey to occupy was approximately 75 square metres and, in the opinion of the officers of the Department of Administrative Services, totally unsuitable. I have been led to believe that this office was never the sole electorate office of the former member for the electorate, who worked mainly out of the office of Senator Gareth Evans in Greensborough. That office is no longer within the boundary of the McEwen electorate.

Since applying for 738a High Street, Epping as permanent office space on 4 May, Mrs Bailey has been fobbed off with answers such as that the Minister will approve `shortly', `soon' or whenever. I think that the time that has elapsed between 4 and 24 May comes well between the bonds of the definition of `shortly'.

The only concern the Minister's office has expressed relates to a technical report on the building. Officers of the Department in Melbourne-and Mrs Bailey has found these people to be nothing but helpful to her-arranged for a technical inspection to be carried out and a short verbal report was given. The report suggested that heavier duty glass be used in the panel on the front door and that it may also be appropriate for insulation to be put into the ceiling to make it more comfortable during summer. These could hardly be excuses for the Minister to continue to delay giving approval.

If we look at this matter and consider the plight of the landlord, who has been waiting patiently for a decision since 9 April, we can see that the Minister, in continuing to delay this decision, is preventing Mrs Bailey from effectively carrying out her duty as an elected member of parliament in representing and looking after the needs of her constituents in McEwen.

What do the constituents do now? They either track her down at home or they track down her staff, some of whom were operating out of her home until they got temporary accommodation at 400 Flinders Street. The conditions there are not appropriate either. One staff member is using a coffee table as a desk. The only progress that seems to have been made so far is that Mrs Bailey has shifted her card table from outside the temporary premises-and her telephone, typewriter and other equipment from out of her boot-and from the streets of Epping. The card table has moved and has now become a coffee table in Flinders Street. I ask the Minister: When will Mrs Bailey know? What reasons can he give for the fact that there has been an undue delay in the approval? I believe that every effort should be made to ensure that the people of McEwen have their representative located in their electorate and not at 400 Flinders Street.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise to the Senate for speaking at this very late hour-I do not make a habit of doing it. I promised last Thursday-also in the adjournment-that I would take out some facts surrounding a statement made by Senator Crichton-Browne about the delay in the swearing-in of Senator Campbell to this place last week. I remind the Senate that last week Senator Crichton-Browne accused the Western Australian State Government of being incompetent and inept over the delay surrounding the swearing-in of Senator Campbell. He implied that the Government had had from 30 April until 16 May to go through the formalities surrounding the selection of Senator Campbell and his final swearing-in in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: I indicated in my speech, following Senator Crichton-Browne's speech, that I would check out the record and that some time this week I would seek to put it straight. I now intend to do so. On 20 March this year, the Premier of Western Australia wrote to the Liberal Party asking it to nominate a replacement for now Mr Fred Chaney. The Leader of the Liberal Party in Western Australia, Mr MacKinnon, replied on 3 May-not 30 April as Senator Crichton-Browne suggested-nominating Mr Ian Campbell as that replacement. On that same day, the Governor of Western Australia, Sir Francis Burt, sent a message to the Speaker of the Legislative Assembly in Perth and the President of the Legislative Council notifying them formally of the vacancy caused by Mr Chaney's resignation. Between that date and the actual joint sitting of the two Houses of the Western Australian Parliament, which took place on 16 May, there were four sitting days of the Western Australian Parliament-not three weeks as was implied by Senator Crichton-Browne. There were four sitting days and no more. That joint sitting did duly take place.

One further element that caused some delay in bringing about the swearing-in and bringing the Western Australian representation in this place up to its proper level was the fact that Senator Campbell himself had to be contacted to ensure that no tricks were being pulled on him and that he was willing to accept the nomination of his Party. After going through a tortuous preselection exercise, I doubt that there was any doubt about that, but the formalities had to be followed. Also, Senator Campbell was in Canberra for some of that period and did take some tracking down.

All the way through this scenario the Western Australian Government acted properly and in accordance with all of the conventions that apply in the filling of a casual vacancy. At no time did it stoop to some of the tricks that have been pulled by other conservative governments around Australia in the replacement of new senators. Perhaps the most famous of those happened in the first half of the 1970s when the then Premier of Queensland, Mr Joh Bjelke-Petersen, replaced the late Senator Milner with Mr Albert Field. At no time did the Western Australian Labor Government consider doing such a thing. At no time in the history of casual vacancies in this place has any State Labor government ever pulled some of the stunts that were pulled by the Bjelke-Petersen Government in Queensland in the 1970s or the Liberal-Country Party Government in Tasmania when it replaced Mr Arnell-

TALK.START.PARA: —There was never a Liberal-Country Party in Tasmania.

—I thank Senator Calvert; it was New South Wales. In 1962 the Nicklin Government forced the Australian Labor Party to remove its nominee, a Mr Arnell, and replace him with a Mr Whitside who was then nominated as the Labor senator for the State. In 1975 Cleaver Bunton, an Independent, replaced the late Lionel Murphy who went on to the High Court. Of course, in most recent times, there was the delay the then Liberal Government in Tasmania brought about following the selection of Senator John Devereux to this place. It was not a question of a delay of two or three days as Senator Crichton-Browne stated. It went on for some months. I accept that here members on the Opposition benches accepted the convention and balanced the numbers. When our side was in a similar situation we did exactly the same thing.

SPEECH.PARA: On Thursday night I rejected and refuted the assertions that Senator Crichton-Browne put into his statement on Thursday night. I have now put the facts into the record and I trust that he will be humble enough to accept that he has been misinformed, and the error that he has caused has now been corrected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly about the Tasmanian situation tonight. I am a Tasmanian, as is generally accepted, by birth, by choice and by conviction. Tasmania is certainly God's own country. It is beautiful. It has been generously endowed by nature and it is a wonderful place to live. I find it absolutely appalling right now that this wonderful State is having such a terrible battering when it should be going ahead in leaps and bounds.

SPEECH.PARA: As we approach the conclusion of the first 12 months of this disreputable Australian Labor Party-Green accord Government in Tasmania it is fitting that we look over the period and assess the results. The Premier's Party, after its ignominious 34 per cent election result-incidentally, the lowest vote ever by the Australian Labor Party in any State election held in Tasmania-has done nothing to reflect other than that the vote was overgenerous.

The dismal decade, as it was known, from the early 1970s to the early 1980s, with such notables as Nielson, Holgate, Lowe and Batt-it followed the great period of the Party under the Reece-Fagan regime-has returned with a vengeance. Tasmania is now in the worst condition it has ever experienced. Tasmania in the past, the present and the future has depended and will depend for its existence and prosperity predominantly on its traditional pursuits and natural benefits-primary industry, mining, forestry products, fishing and tourism. Any unthought-through or unplanned change to the relativity of these will be disastrous as anyone with any real consideration and appreciation will know.

Now, there is no progress, no plan, no imagination, no vision and no hope, and it is almost 12 months since the arrangement came into being. The early efforts to panic industry, commerce and ordinary individuals over the state of Tasmanian finances has produced volumes of dubious figures to support dubious claims.

It is now, of course, a matter of record that there was more than $300m-or 20 per cent-less debt in 1989 than when the Gray Government took over at the end of the dismal decade in 1982. During the same period Tasmania's debt to gross product fell by 2.3 per cent, and that is more than in any other State over that period. All this while, Canberra cut Tasmania's funding by $505m in real terms. Mr President, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the table produced by the Tasmanian Treasury to support that figure.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is in real terms $505m less than it received in 1984-85, while the same Canberra government engineered policies that produced the astronomical interest rates which we know so well as the cornerstone of its financial policies and which imposed a vast extra cost on the established and necessary capital borrowings of the State. I have to ask, therefore: Is the Field Government poor? If it is, then let it start by selling off the first $200m in government-owned assets that could be sold and that have already been identified and listed. But, no; it will not do that. Again, if it is poor, how about curbing the extravagances with its ministerial staff and the facilities they have lavished on themselves and their new-found friends? It should look at the new glorified superannuation and termination arrangements for its new staff members.

SPEECH.PARA: In June 1989 the entire Liberal Government had a staff of 62 receiving $2.1m per annum in salaries. In March 1990, just nine months later, the Greens and the Australian Labor Party had 82 staff and a wages bill which was up 50 per cent, to over $3m per annum. The new head of the Premier's Department also receives a greatly increased salary package, including a fully maintained car, which alone is costing $8,800 a year, plus full running costs, superannuation, severance and all sorts of other things. Senior private secretaries' salaries have gone up 41 per cent, from $42,363 to $59,733. How is that for restraint? Does this smack of poverty? Twenty per cent of the ministerial staff are now paid more than the Speaker, who receives $59,141, when under the Liberals there were only two.

The range of services and facilities turned on for the razzle-dazzle of the five Independents to keep them in the standard to which they would like to become accustomed is ridiculous and amounts to far more than the services available to the entire majority Party. So, one would surely say that it cannot all be bad.

So what progress has come to Tasmania under the great new Government? After nearly 12 months, industry and business are yet to find out the philosophy or intentions of the Field Government, if they exist. The Government is yet to look at the simple issues. It has been talking of shop trading hours, price control, equal opportunity in the public sector and so on. At the time of the election there was much talk about the 35 major election promises. Where are they? What has happened to the ban on cigarette advertising, the HIV-AIDS package, the battery hens debate, the gun laws, freedom of information and so on? Who in all honesty would expect anyone to invest in Tasmania while we have no idea of where we are going, no certainty in the crazy accord and no clear direction? Is it any wonder that the Institute of Public Affairs has projected a 30 per cent fall in investment this financial year and a further 27 per cent fall in 1991. I noticed that Terry McCrann was making comments to this effect in the Melbourne Herald under the heading of `Tassie heads for the red under greens'. We all understand exactly what he means.

So which way is Tasmania going? It can be going only one way, and that is clear to everybody. Then there are the other things that have been stopped including the Huon Forest Products development, the International Antarctic Centre and cutbacks in various roads-primarily the Smithton-Zeehan corridor-and other public works. But what has been started? And what of the future? Nothing. When is something productive or constructive going to be implemented or even discussed? What about our children and their futures? What are we educating our children to do? Is it just basket weaving, wood carving, making beds and washing dishes? If that is the intention, it just will not do.

During the first year of this Government, businesses suffered most sorely. The list goes on and on of those which have closed their doors or gone into receivership. I mention just a few: Oystas Pty Ltd, ANI fabrication plant, Waverley Woollen Mills, Norsewear Industries Ltd, Launceston International Hotel, Hadleys Orient Hotel, Gray Holdings Pty Ltd, the owner of nine hotels, Argyle Developments, John de Jong, builders, Capitol Constructions, Loones Agricultural, South Cape Ltd, ISAS (Tasmania) Pty Ltd, and Grays Sawmills Pty Ltd. Nobody in Tasmania really knows who is running the State. Both the Independents and the 34 per cent Australian Labor Party will, we presume, continue to cling desperately to power for as long as they can, and we may as well expect all sorts of crazy and unprincipled deals to be produced with just that end in mind.

Of late, members of the parliamentary wing and/or their associates in the Wilderness Society have produced a wonderful range of well researched methods to really close down Tasmania forever. Everybody knows the basis of the various wood product developments that have been terminated, as they do the rapacious and never ending advances for the listing of whatever is left unclassified, irrespective of people's lives, jobs and futures. And remember: already 21 per cent of Tasmania is under heritage listing.

The Government has produced a schedule involving, in all seriousness, pulling down huts and shelters in national parks; tearing up all maps with a scale of 1:25,000 because there is too much detail on them; draining and demolishing hydro dams; preventing horseriding on the plateau and boating on many waterways; banning any new fish farms; no new roads and the closure of some we have. Why, for goodness sake? Surely all these things are for people to enjoy in their various ways. Surely we do not all have to dress alike and do the same things in the same places. In a well-balanced society people have different ways of getting their relaxation and enjoyment, and we all want to use Tasmania in our own way.

Finally, all that was only the beginning and was before we were urged to remove all introduced flora and fauna, starting with honey bees, rainbow and brown trout and, I presume, blackbirds, goldfinches, rabbits, most vegetables, flowers, shrubs, trees and so on. If the European wasps were taken away, I would be satisfied. This is genuine; this is what they want. It is not some crazy Monty Python episode but what has been seriously proposed by some power-crazed group of very difficult unTasmanian extremists with no thought of the hundreds of thousands of Tasmanians who see it as where they want to live, work, recreate and pass on to their children for exactly the same or different purposes, but mainly simply to enjoy into posterity. That is all they seek. I for one get terribly tired of those zealots who drop in, declare that they have discovered Tasmania, and then tell us what they think we ought to be doing. But there is more: the latest. As the State slows down and becomes more and more disillusioned, we now have the parliamentary wing recommending a solution to all the woes and problems by, firstly, doubling the electricity rates for all Tasmania's major employing and productive industries; secondly, doubling all mineral royalties; and, thirdly, forcing the Forestry Commission to make greater dividend payments and so on, irrespective of the work it is doing. The fact that such nonsense would close many of them immediately and certainly prevent any others from starting is of no consideration.

The Premier must decide and declare whether or not this is being said by people who are part of this great accord. He must tell us where he stands long term. Between them they are a laughing stock for their total irresponsibility. All this is based on some crazy, mixed up philosophical grounds with no thought of economic capacity or of the effects on investment, present or future, employment, or anything practical or balanced in any way. We know that there are Green representatives who have no concern for posterity, but most Tasmanians do, and they want increased living and work opportunities in Tasmania for their children and grandchildren.

So people say that, if it all sounds so bad, what effects has it had? It just so happens that I can give the Senate one example to think about. Research that I have obtained from the Tasmanian branch of the Australian Hotels Association shows that in 1987-88 seven hotels and accommodation places in Tasmania were listed for sale. In 1988-89, there were 12 for the year. But in the first nine months of the first year of this Green-Australian Labor Party accord, the figure had reached 48. That is what the people who have invested in Tasmania think of the future prospects.

Tasmania is not a museum; it is home to those of us whose families have been there for generation after generation, and who hope our families go on for many more. We seek stable, predictable, balanced and sustainable development to benefit everyone. Not just the few, not just the extremists, not just the developers or the non-developers, but everybody. We cannot afford to let things go on like they currently are.

Would these vandals sell all or part of our famous and invaluable agricultural research farms? Would they seriously prejudice our mining industries that currently employ directly or indirectly over 20,000 Tasmanians, pay $600m a year in wages and produce $714m a year in sales? Do they relish the grave likelihood of being responsible for getting unemployment in Tasmania up to the 10.3 per cent, or 22,000, that has been predicted by the Savings Bank of Tasmania? Are they happy with the business closures and the building decline? I simply ask: What of the future of Tasmania under this Green-Field liaison? SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree fully with the way Senator Archer spoke glowingly about Tasmania. It is a great State. I want to go very quickly to Senator Patterson's point about Mrs Fran Bailey, the new member for McEwen. Senator Patterson raised the case of Mrs Bailey's electoral office and I regret that she did not raise it with me earlier during the day because maybe we could have come to a satisfactory resolution of the problem. I have tried to approach this particular case, as I have with all others, sensibly and sanely, without resorting to the sort of histrionics that Mrs Bailey seems to have indulged in in her lust for publicity. I have had a chance to discuss this with Senator Patterson, and undertake that tomorrow we will very quickly get into the case.

SPEECH.PARA: I must ask both Mrs Bailey and Senator Patterson to acknowledge that there are currently some 50 proposals for accommodation variations before the Department of Administrative Services as a result of not only the recent election but also the redistribution in Victoria and Western Australia. That meant that requests for new accommodation in those States were deferred until after the election. I am further informed by the Department that, at Mrs Bailey's request, my Department investigated a permanent location for her office at Craigieburn, but it will not be available for occupancy for several months.

I have rejected a temporary arrangement on the basis that it would cost something like $24,000 of Commonwealth funds, and asked Mrs Bailey to do what other members of Parliament are doing-that is, occupy the office of the previous member. I felt that $24,000 for an interim period was an expense that we should not incur.

There seems to be some confusion between Mrs Bailey's Melbourne office and the information I have been getting. I have undertaken to ensure that this matter is fixed up as soon as possible. What I do say to both Senator Patterson and Mrs Bailey is that if they really want these things fixed up, they should do what other members from both sides of the Parliament are doing-come to my office and have their requests attended to. Many members of Parliament from both sides are in temporary accommodation until their ultimate requests are satisfied. Mrs Bailey does not deserve to have $24,000 spent on her while we indulge her with an interim measure. I will ensure that this matter is attended to tomorrow so we can sort out where the hold-up is.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.15 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport, upon notice, on 2 November 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: Can the Minister advise the number of long-distance road coaches, defined as all vehicles used for inter-urban, interstate and intrastate operations, but excluding those used for metropolitan purposes only e.g., government and private suburban buses, operating (on an annual basis) within Australia each year since 1979.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Land Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised that there is no government body or organisation that keeps historical records of the type of service provided by a bus or coach.

One of the difficulties of collecting the relevant information is that any suitably appointed bus or coach is capable of providing a range of transport services. Many such vehicles can provide inter-urban, intra or interstate services all in a single week. For this reason it is virtually impossible for any government or industry organisation to know with any precision the actual number of buses or coaches performing a particular type of service.
Although I am unable to provide the honourable senator with the precise information he is seeking, the following information may be helpful.

The Australian Bus and Coach Association advise that there are some 14,000 buses used for general route, school, tour and charter services. Of these 14,000 buses, only around 20 per cent or 2,800 buses are appointed with facilities for intra or interstate long distance services.
The Australian Bus and Coach Association also advise that there are currently some 700 buses which provide the basis of Australia's interstate long distance services.
Some 200 buses are currently registered under the Federal Interstate Registration Scheme.
